author: {'steamid': '76561197986527965', 'num_games_owned': 726, 'num_reviews': 412, 'playtime_forever': 563, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 563, 'last_played': 1490120610}
review:
Pretty good 2d hack'n'slash metroidvania.

You run around several different locations hacking down enemies with your sword, killing bosses, and gaining upgrades that allow you to access previously inaccessible locations.  You'll start off weak and grow more powerful with every upgrade including more health, more energy, long range attacks, etc.  Enemies and bosses have tactics and weaknesses that you learn and exploit.  There's not really much of a story to the game, you're there to assassinate the baddie, that's pretty much it.  Characters aren't really explored and are cliche for the most part.  Expect the dialogue to be not so good.  Game is pretty much constant action/exploration which makes it enjoyable.

The game does have several issues.  The biggest is probably the wall grapple controls.  You can attach to almost every wall/ceiling in the game and move around.  Getting off of these can be problematic at times.  You'll press the jump button to detach and instead he'll keep on hanging there.  The game automatically moves you up platforms if you get to the edge of them instead of waiting for a prompt from you to do so.  This can get annoying at times if you're trying to get close to the edge of a platform without wanting to go up on it.

The second problem is that the difficulty is inconsistent.  I played on hard and while I found the very beginning to be sufficiently difficult, it got easier from there, especially once you get the first 2-3 health upgrades pretty quickly.  Some areas are overabundant in health pickups & killing enemies gives you a little health back as well.  Save points recover all missing health.  There's occasionally an area or two where the difficulty spikes for a little, but not too often.  Once you learn the basics of enemies, they'll usually give you little problems.   Later on, you can usually just run by enemies and mostly ignore them.  Bosses also suffer from the same problem.  There're 2-3 that are pretty tough and will probably kill you a time or two until you learn from your mistakes and win, but others are incomprehensibly easy.  The Pooh Sisters will barely put up a struggle and will probably only take down a fraction of your health before you slaughter them.  I beat both the final boss and his alternate form without dying once, and I arrived at the final boss with only about 40% of my total health.

The game can get a touch repetitive as you'll be fighting most of the same enemies throughout with occasional palette swaps which grant them different health/damage/special abilities/weaknesses/etc.  Would've been nice to have more enemy variety, though enemies do use different weaponry (Rifles, Snipers, Shotguns, Rockets, Machine guns, etc) which do make fights feel different.

You don't unlock the quick travel points until about 60-70% of the way through the game and the most that any one area will have is 1.  Some areas don't have any.  This can make backtracking for upgrades/pickups a little annoying later on when you've got all the special abilities.  Especially since some areas are relatively sizable and could take 5+ minutes to run through.  Most 'essential' stuff is usually somewhere close by where you find a new special ability.  It's usually only the unlockable art/intel/character info that are far off somewhere, so it'll only be really annoying for people trying to 100% the game.

Graphics are fine, music is hit and miss but is decent enough for the most part.  Didn't run into any bugs/crashes at any point.  Most of the games problems are minor points, though I would have really liked the game to be much more challenging, especially the bosses.  It's a solid entertaining game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008101589', 'num_games_owned': 609, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 1076, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1073, 'last_played': 1519008146}
review:
Excelente esse reboot de Strider, excelente!

Quem jogou o original vai encontrar ação bem fiel à do original. Aquela espadinha de plasma maneiríssima, aqueles saltos muito loucos (agora com direito a salto duplo e outras acrobacias), tá tudo aí. E assim como no original, o jogo não é moleza: as fases em si não são exatamente difíceis, mas os chefes... não é nada no nível de Dark Souls, mas alguns dão trabalho. Eu não sou nem pereba nem mestre supremo em jogos de ação, e para mim a dificuldade ficou no ponto exato: você perde para os chefes, tenta mais umas vezes, sua um pouco e acaba vencendo.

Uma coisa legal nos chefes é que o jogo exige que você aperte os botões loucamente para sentar o pau nos caras, mas ao mesmo tempo exige que você se movimente com inteligência. É uma combinação rara e ideal de aperta-aperta-aperta com esquiva-pula-escorega. Funciona bem pra caramba.

Para completar, tem um monte de collectibles pelo caminho, um monte mesmo. E o melhor é que eles não são só para riscar da lista não: são upgrades, artes conceituais e afins, o que te motiva a procurá-los. Como a ação do jogo é realmente muito boa, acho até que vou jogar uma segunda vez em outro nível de dificuldade e tentar catar tudo.

Pontos negativos? Meu notebook não é lá grandes coisas, mas eu imaginei que a GeForce 840M dele fosse dar conta tranquilo de um jogo 2.5D como esse. Até que deu, mas tive que botar as configs no mínimo, baixar a resolução e mesmo assim às vezes o jogo ficava lento. Nada que comprometesse.

Recomendadíssimo o Strider, excelente mesmo!

author: {'steamid': '76561197981543135', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 232, 'playtime_forever': 642, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 642, 'last_played': 1489657330}
review:
Strider est un metroid like avec un gameplay assez fluide et de nombreux combats de boss. Les phases de plateformes sont assez faciles notament avec la possibilité du personange a pouvoir s'accrocher et grimper sur toutes les parois dés le début. On débloque petit a petit divers pouvoirs qui vont nous permettre de progresser dans les niveaux qui sont plutot courts, ceux ci sont plutot classiques pour le genre : double saut, glissade,  propulsion de saut etc...  On a aussi quelques améliorations d'armes mais plutot secondaires (kunai, pouvoir du phénix, de la panthère...). L'arme principale étant toujours la meme, on possèdera 4 améliorations permettant de passer divers portes selon l'amélioration équipé mais rien de transcendant dans tout sa, on équipera la plupart du temps l'amélioration augmentant les dégats de l'arme, le reste ne servant qu'a passer ces dites portes.

Le jeu possède de nombreux combats de boss, a peu près 1 toutes les 20 min de jeu, ce qui est le point fort du jeu selon moi. Les combats de boss sont plutot interessant et variés. Bien qu'assez simple vers le début ils se corssent au fur et a mesure de notre avancée dans le jeu. Par contre pour ce qui est des combats contres les ennemis basiques ceux ci manquent cruellement de variétés (ennemis robotiques humanoides) et sont trop nombreux la plupart du temps que sa en devient lassant.

Il y a pas mal de choses a débloquer pour les complétistes, amélioration de vie/énergie ... et divers backgrounds a débloquer, vous en aurez pour une bonne vingtaine d'heures voir plus pour le 100% et une dizaine d'heures pour le terminer en fouillant un peu, temps que j'ai mis en ayant 65% de contenu débloquer.

Je le conseille pour ceux aimant le genre, ce n'est pas non plus le jeu a faire mais j'ai quand meme passer un bon moment, c'est un bon reboot de la série et il est disponible a petit prix.


Points positifs :
-Les actions sont très fluides et rapides, on a vraiment l'impression d'etre dans la peau d'un ninja.
-Graphiquement assez joli, le jeu est en "2.5D" et les arrières plans sont détaillés.
-Un "metroid like" très accessible avec plusieurs modes de difficulté.
-Des combats de boss nombreux et assez variés. On réaffronte parfois certains boss mais dans des arenes ou avec des attaques bien différentes.


Points négatifs :
-Il y a un filtre avec des traits blancs transparents horizontaux présent en permanence, pas très génant en soi mais une option pour pouvoir l'enlever n'aurait pas été de refus.
-Ennemis peu variés, on affronte toujours les memes. Ceux si on une couleur différente et possèdent plus de points de vue quand on avance dans le jeu. De plus ils sont trop nombreux et on passera plus son temps a les esquiver qu'a les combattre. Les combats n'ayant peu d'interet en soi car cela ne rapporte rien et on perdra plus de santé en voulant les tuer.
-Système de combat qui n'évolue pas beaucoup, on ne débloque pas de nouvelles armes principales ou d'améliorations notables.
-Pas tellement de scénario.
-Les enchainements de gel et d'étourdissements des ennemis vers la fin du jeu.
-Pas de moyen de se téléporter rapidement d'un lieu a l'autre et obliger de se retaper les cinmétiques de boss

author: {'steamid': '76561197964551557', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 665, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 665, 'last_played': 1489343667}
review:
Above all else, this is a game for anyone who gets a kick out of precise controls - assuming you have a decent controller to hand. Strider's signature katana arc is in full evidence here, allowing you to let loose a pleasing flurry of attacks or charge up for a longer-range strike. Movement includes an array of somersault jumps and combine with a wall-climbing mechanic that is never too clingy (as such mechanics can sometimes be). Basically, every room of enemies can be a fun, adrenaline-filled dance - and this is just with the basic toolset the game starts with.

There's some interesting depth here - you not only get ranged kunai attacks, a short teleporter hop and three extra modes for your sword, but each of these get different effects in combination, giving you plenty of high-energy options to take down even bigger foes with finesse. There's also a chain-based higher damage mode you can get to if you score a high succession of hits - I never popped the achievement for doing this 25 times, but I managed to quickly take down the one boss I had any real trouble by trigging a succession of these, and like everything else in this game's combat, it has the capacity to make you feel like the ultra-badass you probably aren't.

Elsewhere, the game can be unexceptional, though not in any significantly detrimental way. This Strider goes full Metroidvania, and while the aforementioned puzzles are great to track down, it lacks the clever item placement of something like Super Metroid (and for better or worse, there's nothing like that game's shine sparking to test your skills/patience). The environments are thoughtfully if visually unspectacular in their construction - though gameplay is on a 2D plane they've done a great job of layering things in the background and foreground, but it can all look a little samey and the series' distinctive cyber-soviet environments seem a little low-key this time round.

Enemy design is a similar story - in terms of function they've nailed it (on sight you have a good idea how an encounter is going to go down, and attacks are appropriately telegraphed so you can get on with the business of dodging and obliterating) but the designs don't really stick in your memory. Bosses are a little better on this front, though they're ultimately lifted from earlier games (and they have some over-used chatter before you encounter them).

Still, unless you've recently burned yourself out on Metroidvania-esque titles, there's more than enough style and substance in this game. I've owed this one a review for three years now - taken me around this time to actually have a machine that can run it (oddly) - Chris covered for me on thereticule (http://thereticule.com/strider-the-verdict/), but I couldn't resist singing it's praises myself, especially as three years on, it seems to have largely been forgotten. A shame.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025902156', 'num_games_owned': 734, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 487, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 487, 'last_played': 1488110278}
review:
[b]Strider is a good action game, but a lame Metroidvania. [/b]

Strider is a reboot of... well, the Strider franchise. Strider was a dose of intense arcadey goodness, and when I heard it was rebooted as a Metroidvania, I was pretty surprised, but ready to give it a chance.

On the side of action, the game succeeds. Unfortunately, there's not a lot I can say that speaks to this. It feels as flashy and wild as it should. Bosses are frantic, enemies are dynamic, and the abilities you acquire are fun and empowering, kunais, dashes, new blade types, etc. My only real complaints here are that at the occasional gravity warping sections within the game, you never feel quite as in control as you should, and that switiching blade types on the fly can feel stressful. Oh, and turning around is kind of weird? But anyway. Graphically, it's exactly what it should be, throwbacks to the old games show up in proper spaces, but also aren't carbon copies. The soundtrack is actually really sick, unfortunately it is turned down too low to appreciate, like a lot of soundtracks nowadays. I recommend cranking it up a little! But otherwise, the combat is nice, the presentation works. Playtime is around five hours, and that's just about the right length. It all checks out.

But then we get to the fact that, again, this game is a Metroidvania. That means backtracking to get collectibles with new found power ups. But the issue with Strider's layout is that backtracking is genuinely annoying to go through. There are only a few warp points in the game, and they are far out of the way from the "Plaza" (the place you consistently return to over the game). The collectibles, too, are almost never worth going to get, with the exception of a few upgrades to your health and mechanical upgrades. Furthermore, rather than in a, well, GOOD Metroidvania, you aren't led silently to where you need to go to next by map design and the designer's invisible hand. You're given a waypoint on the map to head to. What was the point of making this a Metroidvania, then? If the areas were stacked in order, the game would have felt relatively the same, though a bit funky to backtrack through small parts of areas. I often feel compelled to collect everything I can in games like this, but in Strider, I just didn't bother. They're not hard to get, usually, theyre just not worth it. I didn't want to waste my time.

That being said, Strider is still a fun game. The action is frenetic and fun, but I'm honestly hesitant to recommend it. I actually felt like it wasted my time often when playing it. This is one of those many times I wish I could give a middling review score rather than the binary of "Yes" or "No". It's a good action game, but whenever it tries to be like a Metroid game, it just becomes boring. Buy at your own discretion.

review:
It starts out slow but once it gets to going this game is pretty amazing. It seems like itll just be a straight up action game but once you really get further into it, it turns into a metroidvania of sorts. Really enjoying it so far and the amount of different bosses is really fun and challenging. 

There is one huge problem though and it may or may not bother you but the dialogue boxes are HUGE and when the characters talk it takes up the whole bottom of the screen. It makes it really hard to get through some parts because theyre constantly jabbering and you cant even see where youre trying to land. If you can ignore this one oversight though the game is otherwise a very excellent action adventure platformer i think youll really love if you give it a chance. 

I played the original back in the day and i remember it being one of my favorites but i honestly dont remember too much about it its been so long. But this reboot i would say definitely did it justice. I just cant for the life of me figure out who the heck thought the giant dialogue boxes was a good design decision???

author: {'steamid': '76561198159387182', 'num_games_owned': 536, 'num_reviews': 285, 'playtime_forever': 2260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2259, 'last_played': 1639126956}
review:
20-30 senelik eski bir arcade oyununun geliştirilmiş versiyonudur. Müzikler bile orjinal versiyonundan. Oyunda kompleks bir haritada, yüksek teknoloji üstadı olan Strider Hiryu isimli A-Sınıfı olan bir ninjamızı yönlendiriyoruz. Hiryu , Uçan Ejder anlamına gelir. 

Hikayeye göre, görevleri sebebiyle Hiryu kendi bacısını ve yakın arkadaşlarını öldürmüştür ve üstüne de kafayı yemiştir. Emekli bir ninja olan Strider Hiryu, Mogolistan'da huzurlu bir emeklilik geçirirkene 2050 sularında dünya dışı güçler tarafından Kazakh ( Kazakistan ) da kurulan disutopik bir sistemin toplumuna verdiği zararı ve bu sistem liderinin tanrılaştırılmış olmasını daha fazla hazmedemez. Bunun üzerine "yeminimi bozdum Hiryu - ya Allah" diyerek önüne çıkan sayborg, android ve mutantlaştırılmış mahlukat karışımı robotumsutrak türlerini çektiği kılıcı ile kesip biçerek hurda haline getirir. Bu kargaşaya çözüm getirmek için savaşır.  Ninjamızın potansiyeli olduğundan yeni dünyanın düzeni için üretilen üstün varlıkların üretildiği tesiste deneylerden geçmesi mevzuları olmuştur ki bu sayede daha da üstün yeteneklere ulaşır kendileri.

Oyun içinde de 1984 'teki ( George Orwell'in ünlü romanı )  Big Brother'ın sloganlarından göndermeler ve benzetmeler yapılmıştır. "Labor is freedom. Labor is progress." Ayrıca düşman askerleri ve robotları ara ara Rusça konuşmaktadır. Aralarında yanlış duymadıysam İngilizce olarak "Freedom is slavery" yani "özgürlük kölelik etmektir" diyenler de var. 

Oyun önümüze gelene bir tekme diyerek oynandığında 1-2 saat içinde harala hurala bitirilebilir. Steam başarımıydı felan filan oyunu leşini çıkarmak dahil diye oynadığınızda en fazla bir kaç gün, bir hafta sürer. Detaya inince harita gözünüze ara ara Moskova Metrosu kadar karışık gelebilir.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970314107', 'num_games_owned': 2302, 'num_reviews': 917, 'playtime_forever': 369, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 360, 'last_played': 1692421385}
review:
I don't know Strider from anything outside of Marvel vs. Capcom 2, so you won't find a hint of nostalgia in this review. It doesn't need it though, being as expansive and fast-paced a platformer as it is. There are plenty of metroidvanias out there but I can't think of many that let you play as a spastic cyber-ninja, and that's just as fun as it sounds. Despite a few design hangups it stays fun the whole way through, too, so it's an easy recommendation for an action-heavy take on the genre.

Strider dumps you into the cyberboots of Strider Hiryu, out on a mission to kill the mysterious despot who rules the world from high-tech Kazakh City. This isn't really explained in the game intro which drops you into the snowy outskirts of the city, leaving you to pick up the pieces of the story through the game's terribly talkative bosses. I can't say I minded too much because right from that intro I was somersault-slashing robot soldiers into cyberfillets and speeding across rooftops, and at that point I wasn't questioning it.

This game wastes no time in getting you to the action, so I'll waste no time lauding them for it: This is one of the most viscerally fun metroidvanias out there to tear around in. Combat in Strider is always fast-paced, kinetic, and full of possibilities. Your spry protagonist will quickly unlock a full suite of combat moves including charged slashes, sliding kicks, diving strikes, and air dashes. Even his basic attack is a lightning-fast swing you can rapid-fire like the Crissaegrim from Symphony of the Night, in any direction no less. On top of that are the plasma types, allowing Strider's sword to reflect bullets or freeze enemies, throwing knives which can share those plasmas, and three combat options like a holographic panther and orbiting drones.

All of those tools will be necessary for cutting down the hundreds of cybernetic foes standing in your way. Enemy troops carry all kinds of firearms and almost every group has a shield soldier to dispatch with a charged slash or a specific plasma. Then there are flying drones, turrets, and larger mechanical menaces that make for longer encounters. You'll need to be agile to take on beefier foes but flipping willy-nilly all over a giant robot as you hack it up never gets old here. Once you master the movement you can control the flow of battles, slipping between shots and removing threats as you see fit.

Your swift, fluid movement will help you traverse the vast metropolis of Kazakh City as well. The map is divided into thematic districts, from rain-soaked cityscapes to cramped industrial complexes to vast underground caverns. Strider starts the game with the ability to cling to and climb along any surface, walls and ceilings included, which greatly multiplies the spaces that can conceal secrets. And indeed, there is stuff to find stuffed into every corner of the sprawling world. This is actually one place where the game's design works against it, because the levels are a little too vast to comfortably retread to find new secrets. There's no fast travel system either, so hiking back to the starting areas can be a laborious undertaking.

The level design is definitely the weakest part of Strider, which is a pretty big deal for a metroidvania. And it's doubly painful because the levels LOOK great, with tons of little details in the fully-3D landscapes. But all that detail can make it tricky to pick out the walls and platforms in the foreground, especially when things get cramped. They get cramped pretty often as well, with many levels going overboard on long, featureless halls to sprint down. Strider's normal running speed makes this less of an issue, until you need to backtrack somewhere. But that's the other part that got to me, the backtracking. It's to be expected in any metroidvania especially after you score a new power, but here it feels particularly forced. You'll be sent to a new level to do something and all of a sudden you'll get a notice that you need a new option or plasma to proceed. It could be as simple as one locked door between you and your goal, but the game will happily send you through three enormous side levels to get a new power to open that damn door. Or it might arbitrarily send you back to the middle of an early level, or into a back entrance of an old map, or so on. It's not the worst thing in the world since you get more to explore, it just tends to be terribly arbitrary.

I feel pretty confident that the action will help push you through the worst offences of the level design, though. The fights never get boring and the bosses all have fun gimmicks and lots of dynamic attacks. Strider isn't a terribly difficult game on normal, either, so it should be clear sailing right up to the final area. The journey will take you a good 5 or 6 hours and there are additional difficulties and challenge modes to top it off. The sound design is great, with plenty of rich metallic tones and a pumping soundtrack to keep you pushing on. The graphics are nice and clean but leave the characters looking stiff and plasticky in the cutscenes, but at this point I'm just nitpicking. There are certainly nits to pick but honestly if you like metroidvanias and ninjas, just get it and immerse yourself in hours of quality skulking and slashing.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/audish#curation]curation page[/url]!

review:
Well-built Metroidvania game with as much focus on plot as I imagine the original NES game had (none). Feels ultra responsive and withstanding a couple of exceptions plays very well. When you're on a wall, you can't melee below you. Really seems like they just didn't have time to implement it. Gameplay is definitely the strongest part and as you pick up skills it becomes varied and challenging. Exploration is rewarded and the levels are very well designed. Complex but I never felt stuck nor accidentally backtracked though you are generally able to.

Looks pretty nice. Voice acting and remnants of plot are mostly atrocious. Would almost be better if it was just silent. Music could have been cooler too. I guess like.. the game didn't really have much character and felt super generic and the bosses and well everything had no context. The game is good, but I feel it will be fairly forgettable.

review:
・隠しアイテムで主人公・飛竜をパワーアップさせたり仕掛けを解きながら任務を遂行していく、メトロイド風の探索系アクション。主人公のアクションはスピーディな上、獲得できるスキルが多彩。スライディング、２段ジャンプ、投擲武器(クナイ)、空中ダッシュ(カタパルト)、炎・氷・磁力の武器属性付与、３種のオプション攻撃。これらのスキル獲得で攻撃の幅が広がると、それに伴って、移動可能エリアも広がっていく。
・POWやアイテムコンテナ、仲間ストライダー達のコスチューム集めなど、やり込みが楽しい。
・空中エリアからの落下死や電磁ネットワークに触れた際の感電死など、たまに強力な一撃死の強力なトラップがあるが、一撃死した際はリトライが軽快。
・分かり易いナビがあるため、進行ルートで特に詰まる所はなし。

author: {'steamid': '76561198286510960', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 150, 'playtime_forever': 612, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 612, 'last_played': 1486107287}
review:
I haven't been that much thrilled while playing a game since a long time. The game is very enjoyable to play and the normal difficulty is very well balanced and accessible for nearly evreyone and there is a hard difficuly option for those who seek challenge.

The bosses in thd game are very well designed and fighting them will definitely give you a high dose of adrenaline, and the good thing is there are a large number of bosses considering this is a relatively short game.

I paid $1 for this game in humblebundle and I can say it deserves much more especially if you like metroidvenia games that offer good combat and don't mind the short length of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024423322', 'num_games_owned': 1307, 'num_reviews': 203, 'playtime_forever': 431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 431, 'last_played': 1484746827}
review:
Strider war für mich ein kleiner Überraschungstitel. Das Remake des Sidescrollers von 1989 sieht nicht nur super aus,
sondern spielt sich auch verdammt gut. Die Steuerung ist intuitiv, wobei ich einen Controller definitiv empfehlen würde.
Längentechnisch sollte man jetzt nicht allzu viel erwarten, 4-6 Stunden werden aber auf jeden Fall drin sein, und auch wenn
es ein einigen Stellen ziemlich knackig werden kann, sind die Checkpoints jederzeit fair gesetzt. Desweiteren ist die Welt ziemlich groß und bietet eine Menge Geheimnisse, die man finden kann, wie zum Beispiel Statusupgrades, aber auch Outfits und neue Ausrüstung. 
Was mich bis zum Ende motiviert hat war nicht die Story, die sicherlich nicht schlecht ist, aber auch eben nichts überragendes, sondern vielmehr das Gameplay, die Erkundung der Spielwelt und die spannenden Bosskämpfe.

Rundum kann ich Strider allen empfehlen, die auf stylische Sidescroller und schnelle, herausfordernde Kämpfe stehen.

review:
So boring=_=
感觉是一款粉丝向作品，有听闻过出击飞龙这款游戏也在街机平台上玩过当时觉得这不仅是一款很难的游戏而且是一款操作很难受的游戏。
现在这款重置版虽然操作不那么难受了，但是操作性不强只能以平砍为主，而且难度大大降低普通难度可以无双，困难难度也一点也不难，还加入了大量无所谓的收集要素（如：飞镖的升级），故事也是简单的故事框架，音乐方面没有太大感触，可能没有领悟到出击飞龙这一系列的精髓吧，总之个人感觉是一部蛮平庸的作品。（PS：还有少量BUG,会让你回到上一个检查点……）
个人评分5.6分

review: Strider is a good game that I would recommend whether you love Metroidvanias or not. Maybe not the best of that genre, but good. author: {'steamid': '76561197971034014', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 2117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2117, 'last_played': 1483932361}
review:
Strider by Double Helix is a great side scrolling adventure, the game features crisp controls a variety of abilites, power-ups, tough yet reachable achievements and a few good play throughs. The design and methods our crafty Ninja Hero Hiryu goes about climbing, flipping, slicing, dicing, teleporting, and projecting himself through the multiple levels of this game is a blast, the action, the pace, the difficulty at not getting hit, loading up your cypher sword and going all out on some unfortunate Meio kronies is a thrilling ride...for awhile.

One of the achievements and probably the most worrisome is the complete in 4 hours achievement - this is totally possible on any setting as the games areas to travel and places to go are limited, with the help of a few maps from online you can plot a course that will take you directly or almost near direct paths with almost all power ups to beat the game in 4 hours. I completed it in 3:05 and think I missed 1 power up.

Strider had very few cons, I think 3 overall:
The first and biggest one is that Double Helix the designer of the game is no longer in business. Strider has such a comfortable blend of action, evasion, and puzzles while it glides along quickly enough that you can beat it in under 4 hours once youve honed your skill. 
The Second con would be that is it such a short game, there are some extra modes like survival where you try to survive wave after wave of enemies or the time trials where you run around the maps hitting beacons in a certain time frame to collect A - F rank, but they got old quick. 
The Third is the Direct X, if you dont have DX11 it cant run on your machine, some people have posted about this, and there is supposedly patches (unofficial patches)- youve been warned.

If your a platform player this is a must, wait for a sale and enjoy. If you dont usually play platform style games and seek a top of line experience in this genre with top notch quality and representation - Strider is a excellent choice.

review:
キーコンフィグが無い。

キーが変えられないだけで操作しやすければいいですが、キーボードでやろうとした場合かなり厳しいのでレビューさせて頂きます。
一般的なゲームの左手で操作するWASD等のキーが攻撃技で
キーボード右の矢印キーがキャラ移動なために思ったように操作ができない。
やっていると頭がこんがらがってきます。スーパーマリオを左右反対の手で操作できる人なら問題ないかと思われます。

PS2のコントローラーでは一切動きません。
XBOXコントローラーならば外部ツールで動くようです。

author: {'steamid': '76561197993362526', 'num_games_owned': 2641, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 1218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 231, 'last_played': 1566664057}
review:
Where can i double like this title? Or the second store page trailer, more precisely when he says 'we think we delivered' and 'the most fast paced game you will find out there'?

How come this game didn't make a whole lot more fuzz when released? I expected another passable remake and was blown away. TRAILERS DON'T DO IT JUSTICE- IT *FEELS* AMAZING. Amazing, fast, super responsive... are you familiar with the concept of being on 'the flow'? I tought i felt it with games before, how wrong i was- but here not only it got me in the flow, it did so mere minutes into the game. Before i noticed i was ninjaing my way without blinking!

Im a game design enthusiast so let me indulge in details: this is possibly one of the best paced games i ever played if not the best. It isn't just the speed and loop between slashing and exploring- how naturally it eases you on controls and possibilities, the frequency and placement of upgrades, bosses, secrets, how tight and well designed is the big metroidvania world... i can go on and on.

GRAB IT. Its worth full price, at sale its a steal. It doesn't matter what genres you're into, this is one of the rare games i would recomend anyone without blinking. BUY IT. NOW. I MEAN IT!!!

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561197982011454', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 177, 'playtime_forever': 264, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 264, 'last_played': 1481680797}
review:
I read a bunch of reviews since I've owned the game from day 1 and have been thinking about writing one myself for a while now. As you can see from my playtime, I've never played the game much, and when I considered why that was, I didn't find much overlap between my view of the game's shortcomings, and the negative reviews.

The main complaint I see in negative reviews is that this game is too easy and the non-boss enemies are way too easy (some say the bosses are too easy as well, personally I don't mind a game where I can kill the boss after figuring out his tricks over 3-6 attempts). I think this complaint mostly stems from imo misunderstanding what this game is and isn't supposed to be.

As I see it, this game is not supposed to be "I Wanna Be The Guy" with a Strider skin, and the open world enemies aren't supposed to privide much, if any, challenge (though to be fair, the Heavy Trooper Mechs come in different variations that can be fun/interesting to handle). They're there to provide scenery and something to slash with your increasingly powerful skills as you fly by, and that's it.

The main thing that put me off playing the game for longer was the open-world approach they have taken with map-design. If I need to spend time looking at the map, frankly, I'd prefer a minimap. It just kind of makes me wonder "who asked for this", but I guess it was probably cheaper to do it this way and stuff some collectibles in there. I for one find the idea of exploring to find my way and traveling between zones via phoenix in this kind of game off-putting. Ori and the Blind Forest did a similar thing and I didn't like it there either, just give me a linear level path imo.

That said, if you want to play a metroidvania style game that makes you feel fast, agile and powerful, which isn't very hard but a quick blast of fun, I can definitely recommend the game (as long as the map thing doesn't turn you off). I'll finish it one day, surely...

author: {'steamid': '76561198338871773', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 823, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 275, 'last_played': 1485990232}
review:
Plasma swords, double jumps, flying bounty hunters, and oppressive dystopian regimes. This game is awesome.

The gameplay is simple and rewarding. You can do all kinds of cool acrobatics and explore a surprisingly large world, but the controls are simple and easy to master.

Recommend this game to anyone who wants a simple, yet awesome game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992723591', 'num_games_owned': 342, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 508, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 508, 'last_played': 1480714062}
review:
This game brings a heavy dose of nostalgia. It's fast paced, smooth and, with a few exceptions, controls nicely. Artistically, I think it looks great with a modern and almost cartoon like appearance particularly in the backgrounds. My main complaint is lack of enemy and environment variation. You'll be fighting the same guys over and over and most of them serve to just get in your way as they're almost on 1 - 2 shot kills. Everyting takes places within a gloomy futuristic Eurasian-like setting.

In keeping with its nostalgic feeling, the game doesn't improve upon gameplay very much from its 1989 counterpart. There's running, wall climbing and anti-gravity platforming.

Sound is mediocre and, in keeping with Capcom tradition, the voice acting is some of the worst I have ever heard.

Fairly quick to play, this game easy with the rare frustrating moment. 

All in all I enjoyed it and didn't blow me away.

6.5/10

review: Gran bel gioco!! Un platform con un pizzico di gdr e una curva di apprendimento molto semplice. Più si va avanti e più appassiona, non tanto per la storia quanto per la ricerca degli angoli più remoti e come arrivarci per poter acquisire più potenziamenti e seminare la devastazione tra le robotiche file nemiche. Un solido H&S che diverte per l'estrema agilità del nostro personaggio che saltella senza stancarsi mai per una buona manciata di livelli e si fa largo a suon di legnate. Se siete abituati ad andare avanti senza tanto rigirare per i livelli suppongo che si possa finire in molto meno tempo, anche se credo che così perderà parte dell'incanto. Io lo presi tempo fa su humble bundle ad un prezzo ridicolo ma per me vale tutto il prezzo di Steam senza ombra di dubbio.

review: Although it isn't the most progressive or intelligent game out there, Strider definitely does the series justice. Appealing art direction, extremely responsive controls, good pacing, and responsive gameplay definitely make this title worth the little it costs. Admittedly, Strider does suffer from lack of narrative, most major stealth elements (Strider being a ninja makes this a little problematic), and stagnant combat mechanics, but the game is just a really fun time on the whole. If you're looking for an experience rich in story or unique mechanics, you'll be sorely disappointed. But if you just want a fun, flashy, sword-slinging adventure, you're in the right place.

author: {'steamid': '76561198146945822', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 826, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 728, 'last_played': 1514560510}
review:
Exponencialmente surpreendente. Nunca tinha jogado um jogo da série, mas acabei amando e esperando mais jogos da sequência. No começo parece meio motótono, sem muitos golpes (basicamente dois ataques diferentes), mas no decorrer do jogo, você vai ganhando cada vez mais poderes. Ao final, você tem tantas opções que acaba se perdendo no combo.

Pontos positivos: instiga a criatividade e diversidade de golpes, trilha sonora boa, ótimos gráficos, desenvolve a agilidade do jogador e capacidade de pensamento rápido. 

Pontos negativos: pouca variedade de inimigos e cenários.

review:

I have never felt so much like a ninja.  The action is amazing.  The graphics are beautiful.

Plot is funny and cliche, as is the writing/voice acting.  Everything else is artfully done, imo.

review:
Akcja gry została osadzona  w ponurej wizji przyszłości,w której naszą planetą rządzi okrutny dyktator znany jako Meio.
Wcielamy się Hiryu – wojownika, który osiągnął rangę  jako najmłodszy agent w historii organizacji Strider,gdzie naszym zadaniem jest zamordowanie Meio.

Autorzy nie położyli dużego nacisku na fabułę,zamiast tego scenariusz jest głównie pretekstem do walki z hordami wrogów.
Klasyk nie różni się zbyt dużo od poprzedniczki,tylko poza grafiką.

Strider niestety posiada kilka błędów słabe walki z przeciwnikami,a co za tym idzie niewygodne sterowanie.
Plusem są otwarte poziomy,i klasyk który został odświeżony.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097914385', 'num_games_owned': 570, 'num_reviews': 103, 'playtime_forever': 257, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 145, 'last_played': 1481081817}
review:
这个游戏很像一部90年代末的特技大片，简单，粗暴，从不拖泥带水，游戏开始直接把主角丢到敌人阵地，没有前因后果，开杀吧！

一进入游戏第一感觉有点像老版的忍者龙剑传，但是稍稍一玩就会发现完全不是一回事，这游戏的全部内容就是冲和杀，主角比assassin更能爬，比zero还能砍，随着游戏的进行，敌人数量越来越多，跳跃和滑步是主要的规避方式，基本上不能好好走路，也没有时间让你停下来，一直在上窜下跳，尤其主角在空中的跳跃是个侧翻，在枪林弹雨中，有点黑客帝国的味道。这也是为什么我说他像部90年代的大片，也许他没什么内涵，但是看起来非常的爽快。你甚至不需要去考虑走哪条路，凭着感觉就向前冲就好。

游戏整体难度还是比较简单的，即使是游戏后期，枪林弹雨看起来很唬人，但是实际上遍地血包，杀敌也加血，boss也故意设计的攻击方式都很规律，抓好破绽基本都能一次过，我玩的normal难度，hard可能会难些吧。另外boss妹子很多，好评。

缺点就是音乐，这么爽快的游戏，如果能配上一些燃的音乐那成为经典不是问题，可惜本作的音乐存在感实在是薄弱的可以，基本上没起到什么烘托的作用，可惜啊。还有就是攻击手感虽然算不错了，但还是有点怪怪的，打到怪身上没有那种回馈感，也有点遗憾。另外因为游戏节奏整体很快，导致苦无，特殊攻击等技能存在感大幅下降，因为出手略慢，前摇的时间已经中好几枪了。杂兵里有一种盾牌兵，也让人有点不爽，蓄力击破无可厚非，但是也该提供点其他的击破手段，如迅速绕后攻击，滑铲从下方攻击等等，然而游戏都没设置，强迫玩家用蓄力，有点影响爽快感，但总体来说也算是增加了难度。

这游戏进过包，很便宜的价格能买到，现在入手很值了。推荐用手柄，酣畅淋漓。

author: {'steamid': '76561197962657563', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 199, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1494680218}
review:
Beautiful visuals but horrible controls.  Most people will probably love this game but I'm very picky about controls.  I prefer direct responsive controls, not scripted animations. This game isn't as bad as fly-by-wire games such as the Arkham series, but it was still annoying.  

If I'm running left and I press right, I prefer the character to start running right, not to do a nifty slide animation that causes you to lose control of your character for a half second.  I also hate wall clinging, especially when it is very difficult to get your character off the wall.  The only wall clinging I'm ok with is when you have to hold a key to cling to the wall and you let go of the wall when you release the key.  This is one of those games were the walls seem to be made of fly paper. Getting off of them requires pressing jump and the thumbstick away from the wall at the same time.  And by "away" I mean exactly 180 degrees on the thumbstick.  190 degree or 170 degress causes you to flip upward on the wall rather than letting go of it.  Similarly, when you jump and try to press up to attack an enemy above you, if your thumbstick goes SLIGHTLY left or SLIGHTLY right your character flys left or right very quickly instead of aiming up. An example of scripted movement is that when you get close enough to a waste high platform in front of you, your character automatically hops up onto it and takes a few animated steps forward, often running into a damaging obstacle.  This kind of scripted behavior makes for a very cool looking demo video but a very frustrating game.  Like many games, the most challenging boss was the controller boss. 

If you are not as anal as I am about controls, you will probably like this game. I love how it rewards exploration with lots of little hidden secrets.  And the boss fights would be really fun if the controls weren't so mushy.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964798094', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 159, 'playtime_forever': 509, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 509, 'last_played': 1477948108}
review:
Deserves the 'Metroidvania' tag, doesn't deserve the 'ninja' tag because there's no stealth 

+ nice skill progression, I had no clue at the beginning and 8 hours later, I had beaten hard mode.
+fluent movement that motivates 
+ level design and respawning that keep the frustration level in the yellow zone
+ music and sound fit the speed and add to the atmosphere
+ awesome boss fights

- a really minimalistic approach to a equally minimalistic story. I restarted twice because I thought there must have been an intro cutscene that explains who I am and what's going on. Well, there is none and even after the final cutscene, I didn't really have a clue why I was killing all those enemies. There are unlockable story entries though that are hidden within the levels.
- not much variety when it comes to weapons and enemy types. You can get 4 weapons that also unlock doors of the same colour. They are pretty different but it could have been more variety. Same goes for enemies, even the big ones appear again and again. At least you got the tactics correctly at the end.
- no stealth, would have been nice though.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979209026', 'num_games_owned': 667, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 469, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 425, 'last_played': 1477265328}
review:
I picked up Strider at some point in one of the many bundles I've bought on sale over the years and went in blind. I expected some sort of platformy hack and slash, I ended up with a fairly engaging ninja-themed metroidvania game.

As with most metroidvania games, you start out with fairly minimal abilities. Minimal to the point where I was not very impressed at first since I was just spamming the slash attack. Once you get a few power ups though, your combat options open up immensely and it becomes way more engaging. This isn't to say that it's perfect, I found the combat actually got annoying at several points in the game as some enemies were bullet (slash?) sponges no matter which powers you used, to the point where I found myself skipping over a lot of enemies. I also found some enemy types incredibly annoying to fight against due to the fact that they can stunlock you to death in large packs. Sure you could dodge the bullets, but if you mess up even once, a sufficiently large pack will refreeze/stun you as soon as you break out. Aside from those fights though, I found the boss fights to be very fun with varied mechanics.

Movement in this game was great, especially as you unlock powers to increase your movement options and unlock new areas. I always felt like I was in control when moving, which is great for combat. My only complaint is that some maps are fairly large and I found myself wishing for a quick way to traverse large flat areas, such as with some sort of charge/sprint power seen in some other games in the genre. I also found it annoying that the dash skill you eventually unlock completely kills your momentum. It's great for giving you more fine control, but it makes traversing through old areas to look for unlocks annoying.

review:
Strider is a great game for Metroid/Vania fans.

Pros
-----
- Great Graphics
- Fast paced, hectic gameplay
- Great range of abilities; every ability has a use
- Lots to collect

Cons
------
- Map layout is very confusing, compounded by no fast travel options
- Bosses are incredibly predicatable/easy, the hawk summon ability is op as fuuuu

Overall, great game, would highly recommend it if you are a metroidvania fan (I am).

author: {'steamid': '76561198025820005', 'num_games_owned': 1706, 'num_reviews': 149, 'playtime_forever': 384, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 384, 'last_played': 1466992015}
review:
Fun "metroid-vania" style of game where you play a cyberpunk ninja. The story is fairly unremarkable, but serves it's purpose of carrying you through various zones and boss encounters. 

Level design is pretty solid, and each area is full of skirmishes with mooks, hidden secrets, and secrets that are obvious but require items that are obtained later in the game. Enemies can be threatening and require use of a decent amount of combat techniques learned throughout the game. 

There are definitely some overpowered weapons available to use, but they are optional items, so they may not be encountered without some searching around the level. The blade-changing mechanic is well-implemented, and there were never situations where I felt like I needed to rapidly switch back and forth between various powers. 

Boss fights are the highlight of the game, ranging from reflex-testing fights to bullet-hell dodging and positioning tests.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004658683', 'num_games_owned': 1753, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 396, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 396, 'last_played': 1476737228}
review:
Strider spielt sich wie ein Metroid Spiel von Nintendo. Die Spielwelt lässt sich relativ frei erkunden und überall gibt es etwas zu entdecken. Wer sich ein bisschen genauer umschaut, der wird Power Upgrades finden wie z.B, mehr Lebensenergie. Des Weiteren lassen sich unzählige Goodies freispielen wie z.B. Artworks, die man sich im Hauptmenü anschauen kann.
Während des Abenteuers erlangt man immer mehr neue Waffen und Gadgets z.B. eine Eiswaffe, mit der man Gegner einfrieren kann. Es gibt viele Bossgegner, bei denen man eine Taktik erlernen muss, was die Bossbegegnungen herausfordernd macht.
Generell ist das Gameplay sehr schnell und sehr flüssig. 
Das Spiel hat mich sehr überrascht, würde es jedem weiterempfehlen!

author: {'steamid': '76561198090139349', 'num_games_owned': 637, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2027, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1750, 'last_played': 1478175166}
review:
[h1]游戏不错！[/h1]
但是没有汉语字幕
22016-10-17

1. 剧情老套
       本作讲述了主人公Strider克服艰难险阻、击败成百上千的敌人，最终打败大魔头，阻止其阴谋的故事。这种喽啰——头目式的故事，是上个世纪后半页常见的影视、游戏题材。游戏的剧情充满了个人英雄主义色彩，闪耀着正义的光辉，同时又极其荒诞不经，完全是凭空捏造出来的，既满足了玩家的想象，又不经意的灌输着勇敢、正义的价值观。

2. 横板过关
       对于上个世纪九十年代，以及更早出生的玩家而言，横板过关是我们对于电子游戏的最初概念。这种游戏往往节奏快速，在打完一大批喽啰之后，迎来一个头目，叫人眼前一亮。随着计算机技术的发展，游戏机硬件水平的提高，三维游戏越来越多的出现在我们的生活中。三维游戏以其更贴近人视觉感官的呈现方式，成为了现如今电子游戏的主流。而本作一反常态，采用横板过关的方式，以二维形式将游戏画面呈现在我们面前，既能在同样的屏幕上显示更多的虚拟人物、空间建筑，也能唤醒几代人的记忆。

3. 画面鲜艳
       游戏中大量使用红色、黄色、蓝色、紫色等色彩，使得画面鲜艳、富于变化。不同颜色的敌人，意味着需要采用不同类型的技能攻击。这种鲜艳的画面，与荒诞的故事情节相得益彰，增强了游戏性。

4. 动作到位
       轻击、重击、跳跃、二段跳、冲刺、滑铲等动作，基本上涵盖了动作游戏的所有操作。游戏中有些地方，需要很好的操作，不然是没法通过的，这点的设定非常合理，这也是动作游戏常见的场景。同时，游戏中反重力等场景，一反生活中的常识，叫人非常不适应屏幕画面，恨不得头上脚下看屏幕。

5. 最后总结
       这款游戏非常适合使用手柄，再配一个大尺寸的显示器，基本可以在客厅沙发上玩，很像一款家用机游戏。美中不足的是不能联机，也没有双人模式，不能和朋友各拿一个手柄一起玩，这是个缺憾，毕竟独乐乐不如众乐乐。游戏没有汉语界面、字幕、对白，显然是最大的败笔。汉语界面、字幕与对白最大的好处，在于帮助玩家理解剧情，明白游戏讲述了一个什么样的故事。不明白剧情，那游戏就失去了很多乐趣。这也是我给差评的原因。

author: {'steamid': '76561198044194853', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 141, 'playtime_forever': 487, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 487, 'last_played': 1475486782}
review:
To start it off, I enjoyed this game.

 In the beginning, I felt it was fairly bland, but it slowly turned into something much better. I initially felt this way due to simply being able to go through the metroidvania-like map by dashing forward and pressing one button to go through enemies. While it was like this for the first 90 minutes or so, it became much more challenging. The enemies changed from being one dimensional and the bosses were actually challenging. They weren't impossible to beat, but it did require that you face them 2-3 times and learn their attack patterns. 

This game has much more to offer than what I experienced/was willing to do, but that's generally the type of gamer I am. I prefer to play for the story instead of trying to unlock every single little thing. There are unlockables scattered all over the map, but I pretty much just went after the power/energy upgrades instead of actively searching for hidden content. 

Overall, this is a fun game and I recommend it. 3.5/5

author: {'steamid': '76561198059341061', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 945, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 945, 'last_played': 1473767360}
review:
Don't be fooled by the modern look: Strider is still an arcade game at its core. 
The one thing to be aware of is that this is by no means a metroidvania game: there's a map and a few traversal abilities, but the navigator always points you in the right direction, and detours only lead to basic upgrades. The focus is not on the exploration at all, but rather on avoiding enemies and environmental dangers, be it by deflecting bullets, or wall-climbing, or blinking: "fast" is the keyword here.

The combat is extremely straightforward, relying mostly on oldschool button mashing with no combos. A rather big flaw can be found in the game's pacing, lacking any new combat option or major upgrade for the first couple hours, which might be a boring start for most players. 
Mid-game onwards, though, the combat becomes more engaging, balancing button mashing with more precise striking in order to reflect bullets, ranged options and cool "special" abilities, without ever slowing down the action. 
The level design actually encourages making full use of the strider's arsenal, mixing plasma swords (reflecting, explosive, freezing, magnetic) and turning an otherwise too-straightforward, one-button combat into a fun, fast hack'n'slash. Despite lacking tight, tactical approaches, or complex enemy movesets, the combat still feels engaging and satisfying.

With fun and speed at its core, the game doesn't slow down on any meaningful story or characters' background, instead throwing at the player a number of bosses with little context but very solid ideas, at least visually. This is probably where the futuristic, cyber-warfare setting shines the most.

Additional game modes (time trials, enemy/boss rush) can be unlocked by finding collectibles, for those who find the game too short (it actually is). This, coupled with the lack of any real customization and very linear progression, speaks clearly about how Strider retains its arcade soul, compelling the player to play just for the fun of slashing away at cyber-troops with style.


Despite a few shortcomings, Strider manages to turn a very oldschool concept into a fun, fast paced game, even by today standards, aided by some neat polish and good visuals. It doesn't want to be a metroidvania, it doesn't add customization or rpg elements, it just sticks with the classic hack'n'slash and makes it fun and good to look at. 
The one highlight of Strider is that it perfectly nails the feeling of being a badass ninja with stylish powers fighting an army of cyber-soldiers. An amusing experience, to be sure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118582166', 'num_games_owned': 528, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 2386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2386, 'last_played': 1473460795}
review:
Strider is nice game and as every other game has good and bad sides.
The good ones are: 
- Nice fluid gameplay with good abilities
- Good sence of progress and becomeing more powerfull
- Very good graphics and animation that completely suites the game style
- Excelent boss design
The bad ones are:
- Very repetitive level design with little changes in looks. Same goes for enemies with only few variations.
- Map has very little usefulness. There are no indications where are level exits or enters and given that levels are almost labyrinths its very hard to navigate between areas.
- Game is only challenging on hard difficulty. Easy is i think for 5 year old kids :) and medium is decent until you get 2-3 powerups. Hard is only ok mode.
Maybe its sounds like flaws are bigger then posistive ones but dont get me wrong this is game where you can really enjoy. But i think it should be played in smaller game sessions so the repetitivity doesnt become too obvious. I enjoyed the game in first playtrough on normal but on hard was best feeling since it has more challenge. Anyway i recommend this game and i would say it has score 8/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073927253', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 2043, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1887, 'last_played': 1565793887}
review:
Normal playthrough: 10h 23min
Hard playthrough: 10h 43min (though it might as well be 20+ hours)

So after I beat the game on normal I though I'd get my moneys worth and play the game on hard. It was deffenetly a challange if not fully frustrating at times and I got all but 1 achievement doing so as well as 100% of the items & upgrades.
I did find a lot of flaws while doing so as well namely the game is locked to vsync and forcfully unlocking it is a bad idea. On windowed fullscreen it locks to 50hz on my system: I get it, PAL retro being assigned that. The visuals seem garnered for 720p so on a 1080p 24'' monitor the textures really suffer even with all the injected AA & AO.
Soundtrack is fantastic, nothing wrong there.
Some cinematics hide loading times, so expect some to be partially if not fully skip-able.
You need a gamepad, though that's very much a given for 2D platformers.
Then there are the bugs, like when I catapulted on a ledge in the research secot and teleported me all the way down (specifically the platforming challange part trying to get intel orbs). There are more, but I have to go back and catalogue them.
An enjoyable game, but it has caveats.
Also Meio's Tower can go die on the Hard difficulty, the last phase of the elevator is really annoying.


Old Review: If you like Metroidvania this one does a lot right. Give it a go.
If you like the Stider stuff this is very faithful and a loveletter to it.
Could use some polish here and there, but nothing major.

author: {'steamid': '76561198262936317', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 737, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 714, 'last_played': 1487948391}
review:
I beat Strider a couple of days ago, and it was awesome.
Being a big fan of metroidvania genre, I wanted to play this game for a really long time. I've heard that people were having problems with repeated crashes, frame-rate drops and some confusing level design, but on my playthrough of Strider I didn't notice any of that stuff, well, maybe some FPS drops, but I can't call game a bad one just because of that.
It was refreshing, yet familiar experience. I haven't played a whole lot of previous Strider games, but in this one I felt right at home. Graphics were stunning, ambient sounds and music that played occasionally were giving me right feel at the right time - there was some perfect sound both for action and for atmosphere. Controls were solid, if a little too complicated, but once I got used to them, everything became just right. Kazakh City was decently big and really fun to explore with rich variety of zones, though, some areas like Underground were a bitch to get to. I was aiming to collect every collectible besides large green containers (they're nothing but a health refill item anyway) and this led to some frustration, because some of the little Strider icons, which give you costumes, were really challenging to collect. Other than those, I loved collecting all the items, but I missed a few optional icons with concept art, which isn't a big deal.
The core gameplay of Strider was fun and addictive, I spent hours just running around, killing bad guys in style and jumping on the rooftops like madman. Bosses were memorable and very challenging, except for Gravitrons (I was seriously just sitting in one spot and throwing exploding kunai at them until they broke). Final stage was epic and fight with Grandmaster Meio felt like complete joke after such a hard stage. Still, I enjoyed it and the victory was pretty sweet.
The game was constantly throwing new stuff, enemies and objectives at me, helping to learn new tactics and kept me entertained until the very end.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981980615', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 1047, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1047, 'last_played': 1472723596}
review:
Strider is a 2d action platformer that has exploration and item collection much like other metroidvania-style games. I recommend playing with a controller. Fortunately for me I didn't run any into bugs, glitches or crashes while playing.

You don't have to be familiar with the other titles in the Strider series to get into this one. This is a perfectly fine standalone title and the first one to have a seamless metroidvania-style of progression in it. It has 3 difficulty settings (I beat it on normal) and some difficult steam achievements. You play as the Strider, Hiryu, who has been sent on a mission to hunt down and assassinate Grandmaster Meio. It's not quite that simple though as many obstacles and diversions are put in your way. Meio lies inside of a tower, sealed by 3 Gravitron power cores you will need to destroy. As you go you'll find different powerups that will teach you new moves, increase your health and energy, unlock shortcuts and this game's version of elemental attacks to your main weapon, the Plasma Cypher. It's worth noting the elemental upgrades are a key mechanic to the game as they will allow you to defeat specifc enemies and open specific doors you'd otherwise have to ignore. 

It's really fun to play and see just how versatile Hiryu is. He can slide, jump, double jump, air dash, ground pound, climb up walls and across ceilings and reflect enemy bullets back at them. There's a lot more too as you get more Cypher (weapon) upgrades. The enemy variety is decent. Most times it's different difficulty variations and palette swaps of the same foot soldiers but it is done in a way that keeps it fresh as you go through this 6+ hour adrenaline fueled ride.

The boss fights are where this game really shines. The mid to end game boss fights are challenging and will no doubt test your reflexes to their limits. Without going into spoilers, I will say there is enough unique variety of boss encounters to always keep you on your toes. Another high point is the world the game takes place in, each area is interconnected with areas you can backtrack to and unlock other secrets or create shortcuts as you progress and learn new abilities. You don't necessarily have to walk back on foot the whole way though, you get the ability to summon an eagle and a panther that will take you to other areas if you find the right tile to use them on. The map system is excellent, areas that are currently inaccessible will be marked as such so you can find it later when you have the right ability to get through it.

The soundtrack is okay. Not bad but I wasn't impressed with it either. The voice acting isn't the worst but it is pretty bad. The sound effects themselves though were both crisp and fitting of the theme & technology found in the game. The biggest flaw I found, which may be considered a nitpick by some, is that when Hiryu climbs a wall and gets close to a ledge, he'll automatically pull himself up. Now that might sound like a good thing but there are some precision platforming puzzles where this is an absolute rage inducing annoyance and I've unintentionally pulled myself up right into an electrical grid or a laser beam more times than I'd like to count. Or when I'm trying to jump down onto a wall right below the ledge only to pull myself back up. The way Hiryu handles can feel a bit floaty too when you're trying to do some precision double jumping and air dashing for some of the harder end game areas. Aiming his cypher with the analog stick also doesn't feel 100% accurate.

When all is said and done, I recommend this game. I had a blast and enjoyed the challenge it offered. I think Double Helix did a great job with this Strider reboot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089110753', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 748, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 748, 'last_played': 1472074879}
review: I wanted to like this game.  Well, at first, I wanted to hate this game, because it could barely run full screen - Strider was more like SlowWalker.  Even though I have a relatively nice, new computer, I turned down the graphics, and it ran more smoothly (read: MORE, not completely).  Once I actually got to the game play, I wanted to like this game - a fast slashy ninja game is always fun.  Except this one, where they mess up various aspects of the game play and game mechanics, especially jumping away from walls, their stupid gravity thing, and the useless plethora of attack types.  So while the game had promise, it certainly let me down.  Then there's the length -  I finished the story mode in just over 5 hours, and I think I was eating dinner for 2 of those hours, so you're not getting a lot for your money.  Finally, theres' the laughable plot. There's less plot than in an early Sonic game, and of what is there, I think it's supposed to be a satire of Dragon Ball Z and Star Wars mixed with some Russia.  All in all, I would only buy this if you're okay with several flaws, or if it's less than $3....

author: {'steamid': '76561198119626352', 'num_games_owned': 422, 'num_reviews': 108, 'playtime_forever': 566, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 566, 'last_played': 1471753089}
review:
出击飞龙系列其实我是这作才开始接触，MD和ps等都奇妙地错过了。
首先盖棺定论一下，卡婊的动作游戏手感上还是比较保证的，
和某些需要大量练习反复尝试菜可以打得行云流水的不同，属于可以很舒服地玩下去那种流畅，
即便你是手残也可以尝试与投入进去，不会因为太过于难而删除游戏。
难度上升相对比较平缓，不会突然过难导致摔手柄。各种判定也算宽松。
BOSS战也是，多熟悉熟悉套路后，要通过也不难（默认难度下...）
当然虽然难度不算高也不会有割草无双就是，还是需要动脑多搭配一下攻击方式才可以通过的一类。

然后是缺点
首先剧情基本上没有，说穿了就是问答无用，就是干，虽然这个也不算缺点。
然后敌人种类太少和单一，无非就几种，换个盾牌换把枪就算新敌人了？
总给人一种BOSS比敌人种类还丰富的感觉。
然后BGM也和没有没有多少区别，反正通关一次没有留下任何印象。
然后最坑爹的就是闪退........我辛苦打掉boss然后读取画面几率闪退这个超无语
后期还挺频繁的，弄得重打几次boss手累得不要不要的。

假如十分满分的话，这作也就7分吧，
踏过了及格线，但是远不能说多优秀
单周目不刻意收集各种要素9个多小时的流程很难得了.
不过一刀包里买的，还算很超值的，看了一下原价95，很好....不愧为卡婊。


[spoiler] 看了一下好友这个游戏的时间.....怎么都是4-5小时
orz.........怎么打的那么快的...[/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198080503768', 'num_games_owned': 319, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 109, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 109, 'last_played': 1471747030}
review:
スマブラXのサムスの半分も機敏じゃないストライダー飛竜が、雑魚殺すのにも数回攻撃せにゃならんファッキンブレード一本で敵地に乗り込むゲーム。
全体として恐ろしくすっとろくしたうえで爽快感やら達成感やらを削りとってひたすらストレスフルにしたメトロイド・アザーエムと化しており、端的に言ってクソゲー。
ストライダー飛竜が好きならメガドラ版やったほうがいい。

とにかく何もかもが遅い。処理が間に合っていないのかと思ったがFPSはしっかり出ている。倍速でようやくそれっぽいぐらいか？
判定もおかしい。ほとんど止まっているパンチや引き戻し中の突き出しトラップに吹き飛ばされ、どうみたってつま先さえかからないプラズマ防壁にぶっ殺され、明らかに逆方向に掲げられている盾に剣を止められる。
グラフィックだけはそれなりと見せかけてモデルは雑、モーションはFCロックマンのほうがよほどかっこいい始末。
マリオのコイン並みにばらまかれた謎球体は回復アイテムであり、モーションや判定の問題もあって戦術はゴリ押し一択 (回りこんだはいいがノーモーションで即反転されちゃあな！) 。
挙句の果てにチャージ攻撃は壁を貫通してギミックを作動させるし、パワーアップアイテムはボス撃破ドロップ……と見せかけてボスとの対戦エリア初期配置 (倒さないと開けられない) だし、敵配置は適当。

買わなきゃよかった。ゴミ。

author: {'steamid': '76561198326494224', 'num_games_owned': 77, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 739, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1558982218}
review:
Changed my review to not recommend because of the final fight.  I liked the game up until the end.

The final fight is MUCH harder than all prior content.  It is a long drawn-out slog with multiple phases and no checkpoints, so if you can't finish it in one go and have to quit the game and come back later, you must start all the way back at the beginning.  I hate it when games do this.  It is not fun at all to get stuck at the very end of a game, and denied the sense of completion after all you did to get there.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983984954', 'num_games_owned': 1043, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 604, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 604, 'last_played': 1471122007}
review:
Strider is a great metroidvania-style game - the pacing is good, the bosses are fun and the environments are varied. All that said, I don't know what Double Helix did with this version of the game, but it crashes nonstop. I've tried it on two PCs, one an i7-4790k with a GTX 1070 and the other an i5-6500 and GTX 970. Both are more than capable of running this game, yet at random points it will just crash inexplicably. It's doesn't seem to be tied to what's going on in the game at the moment, and it can be really frustrating to have the game lock up before you reach a save point. 

If you can tolerate the crashes, there's a good game here. But there's plenty of great games in this genre that take quality control a little more seriously.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039500657', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 223, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 223, 'last_played': 1470061889}
review:
The last few years have seen a flood of retro games in the Mario mold, emphasizing twitch reflexes and perfect gameplay. They're unforgiving races against the clock. They're ... not that fun. (YMMV.)

Strider isn't one of those games. A remake of a Capcom "guy game" classic from the arcades and home systems, Strider rewards creativity and exploration. It feels great with a controller--and I'd only play it with a controller--and true to Metroidvania roots, it's not an "instant death" affair.

I haven't noticed any major bugs or issues, although it slows down sometimes when the screen zooms out to maximum. (Edit: I did have a bug where Hiryu disappeared for a minute or two while riding the Ouroboros. That kinda sucked.) As some have mentioned, this is a short game. I'm only about a couple hours in, but it does seem like it wouldn't take me more than a weekend to beat it.* With that in mind, I'd recommend waiting for a sale rather than buying Strider at full price.

* This was also true of Megaman, Bionic Commando, and other Capcom games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012111055', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 249, 'playtime_forever': 1044, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1044, 'last_played': 1469975449}
review:
Es un recomendado 'por los pelos'. Si lo encuentras en un bundle o de oferta y te gustan los plataformas de acción seguramente te guste. Técnicamente está muy bien pero me ha resultado muy aburrido.

Un consejo: juégalo en máxima dificultad. Bajar de ahí es pasear siendo invulnerable por plataformas. Y no puedes cambiar de dificultad a mitad del juego. Si la cambias vuelves a empezar y pierdes la partida anterior.

Como decía antes técnicamente está bien: los gráficos son correctos, el movimiento del protagonista es fluído, las acciones que lo caracterizaban (colgarse de las paredes, saltar y repartir espadazos como si no hubiera mañana) también se 'sienten' bien. Vamos, que cumple. 

El problema para mí es que se me hizo muy, pero que muy aburrido. Aunque hay zonas distintas de la ciudad en realidad todo me parecía lo mismo. Hay poca variedad de enemigos y al final todo consiste en avanzar casi linealmente dándole al botón de matar. No encontré nada que me motivase a seguir jugándolo. Las 16h que constan en mi ficha son del maldito IdleMaster, por los cromos. En realidad debí jugar unas 4 horas. 

En otros juegos me ha motivado la historia (aquí es casi inexistente) o el diseño de las fases (aquí es todo el rato lo mismo). Aunque hay zonas diferenciadas (exterior, metro, zona resindencial, palacio, etc...) su construcción es exactamente igual siempre. Hay juegos que incluso careciendo de escenarios diferenciados notas que se ha puesto un poco de interés en la disposición de los enemigos o en el formato de los desafíos para que el jugador sepa que está avanzando hacia algún lado. En Strider me da la sensación de que se limitaron a poner plataformas, dejar caer enemigos a mansalva y poco más. No hay una construcción de niveles interesante. En uno de los vídeos promocionales insisten mucho en que han trabajado en la libertad de movimientos y la consecución de poderes del protagonista pero creo que se han olvidado de poner unos desafíos a la altura.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068432648', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 726, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 726, 'last_played': 1469630182}
review:
Hiryu ritorna nel nuovo Strider più potente che mai... forse anche un po' troppo!

Il titolo, a differenza dei suoi predecessori, action platform di stampo più classico, si presenta come un Metroidvania veloce e frenetico, con un buonissimo level design e un comparto tecnico arricchito da esplosioni e particellari scaturiti dai potentissimi poteri a disposizione del protagonista. Proprio questi ultimi sono però un tantino sbilanciati, e con l'avanzare dell'avventura Hiryu diventerà sempre più forte, diventando una macchina da guerra inarrestabile verso la fine del gioco.
La varietà dei nemici è scarsa, con i mob avversari che spesso si presentano come un semplice upgrade delle versioni incontrate nella zona precedente. Divertenti e ben strutturate le boss battle, ma in generale una difficoltà un tantino più alta avrebbe giovato al titolo tutto.
Ottime le musiche, discreto il doppiaggio.
Consigliato a tutti gli amanti della saga e a chi piacciono i Metroidvania; potrebbe far storcere il naso a chi è alla ricerca di un action platform puro o a chi è alla ricerca di una sfida ardua.

Finito in 5 ore e 38 minuti a Normale, con un completamento dell'87%

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=730967022

This up front: I have played the old arcade Strider game from long, long ago.

That aside, I still quite enjoy this game. The action is quick and flashy and, most importantly, fun.

It feels and runs like a solid, 2D, action platformer. It gives you upgrades that significantly change gameplay as you go on, throws new enemies at you every major "level", and is, simply, quite fun.

It CAN have its frustrating moments, however. Sometimes it's bad about telling you where you need to go, as sometimes the arrow on the minimap seems to bug out or simply not point in an intuitive direction. There has been a time or two that the game's difficulty jumped up quickly on me for a section out of nowhere. 

Despite this, I recommend it, especially if you can snag it on a sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016420785', 'num_games_owned': 460, 'num_reviews': 140, 'playtime_forever': 1217, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 422, 'last_played': 1485733833}
review:
This game was on my wishlist since the beginning of time, and was forgotten as many of them. Now become alive, and is striking harder!

STRIDER is a great side-scroller, not fantastic, but well made. I have to be honest : the very first minutes were kinda boring. Simple smashing button and jumping frenetic to evade attacks from enemies, cuz you dont have a parry(block button), but..."hey!...this is what these games are made of... so keep playing!"

After the intro, and 1st stage, i realize that some potential was painted into horizon, with unlocks, upgrades, and new challenges. And i wasn't wrong. The customization is minimal, but the progression is massive. You can have at least 20 upgrades, from classical -double jump- to aerial strikes, slides, charges and why not?
 "ultra-MO-power-THA-des-FA-tru-KA-ction kills" XD

Basic enemies are easy, and a bit repetitive. Same soldiers over here and there; with some improvements over the journey. The Bosses are a little harder but not frustrating. Overall you can defeat 'em all in two tries after analize its weak points.

Health Regeneration is not allowed, but you can gain some from destroying enemies and crashing "boxes".

Checkpoints are way too far from your objective, but is the only way to advance from point to point.

About the graphics, i must add that they are nice, some old vibe (robot anime series) here.

The sound is quite simple but satisfying, not intrusive.

Menus are classic, you can feel as you were playing some Super NES game, which made "nostalgia" grows. 

You can beat the game in 10 hours. (my real gametime isnt showed, cuz i lost internet connectivity all weekend, so i had to play offline)

All in all, is a good game. I recommend to fans of the genre and alike.

Received a free copy for testing/reviewing purposes. This review is part of the Steamified Community Review program. For similar reviews and fantastic giveaways please visit http://www.steamified.com/

author: {'steamid': '76561198026674109', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 415, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 336, 'last_played': 1686959038}
review:
[h1]Fun and finely crafted remake that outshines its predecessor.[/h1]

Strider is a remake of a 1980s era action platformer.  By every measurable criteria, the modern Strider far surpasses its predecessor.  I was not a fan of the original and though it looked great, the action was clunky and overly challenging in spots, which were hallmarks of the time.

The modern Strider, released in 2014 by Double Helix Games is a graphical delight and a blast to play.

The combat is fast paced and represents gaming at its best.  Lower tier enemies are quickly dispatched and it is quite enjoyable to utilize your speed, mobility and ninja moves to savagely respond to a group of rifle toting cyborgs putting you under fire.  Bossess and larger enemies take some pattern recognition, which is reminiscent of the finest old-school gaming.

Strider simply has the best platforming mechanics in gaming as well.  Double jumping, wall climbing and ceiling climbing have never been done better than this.  Jumps are fast, controllable and tight and climbing a wall is not a chore to accomplish.

The game has leaderboards and is littered with hidden collectibles and unlockable options adding quite a bit of content and replayability.

This remake was refreshing to see and Double Helix did a fantastic job here.  Though the game has top-notch graphics, they did not try to force 3D and perspective change to modernize the game as the Castlevania series regrettably did.  This is how you remake a game, by taking what was good about the original, do it better, focus on fun gameplay, improve and modernize the graphics and add in a ton of extra content.

review:
1st and only run through: 4 hours, 23 minutes.

Quite possibly the most linear game ever.  You can go around the map to get extra items like max hp boosts but you'll end up with 8/10 of every item like that just playing the game with only minimal backtracking and exploration.

I do not recall getting much of a story at the beginning of the game that explained why you're fighting.  Basically the story is "they bad guys, you ninja."

The gameplay is where this game shines and, what can I say, it's a Strider game.  There are only two times in the game that feel especially cheap to me, both of which took an extra 5 minutes to get through.

If you want a 4.5 hour, no-story, high-quality-gameplay 2-d platformer with some decent boss fights then give this game a go.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005654804', 'num_games_owned': 814, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 1002, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 897, 'last_played': 1468602532}
review:
画面很不错的伪恶魔城（其实地图更像银河战士）游戏。之所以说伪是因为地图上巨大的标记时刻为你指示着阶段性目的地、各种机关和锁的类型也在地图上标明了;岔路都很短，升级道具一般就放在这种岔路结束的地方。整个游戏直白的很，玩起来没什么弯弯绕绕的也基本不需要解密或者找路，实际体验还是更像普通横版动作游戏多一些。
     整体还算好玩，不过有几个缺点要提一下：
     1）敌人类型太单一，虽然每个区域的敌人有一些变化不过在玩家眼里应该就是同一个敌人的换色版本。这点拖累了整个游戏的体验。
     2）主角能力完全开放后玩起来非常爽快，但是流程安排的有些问题导致这些能力大多都集中在游戏后期扎堆解锁。这点和前面说的敌人种类少的缺点加在一起就很要命了：游戏前半段你只能用少的可怜和攻击方式攻击种类少的可怜的敌人。最初的新鲜劲过了以后会有一段时间变得非常枯燥，直到后面解锁各种能力后才好转。
     3）主角受伤后的无敌时间很短，遇到敌人扎堆经常被打得起不了身。不过这和上面两条比算不上什么大问题。

      总得来说打折或者进包的时候买了的话还是很值得玩的一款游戏，原价买就不推荐了。

author: {'steamid': '76561198046980920', 'num_games_owned': 11651, 'num_reviews': 140, 'playtime_forever': 519, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 519, 'last_played': 1467676160}
review:
It's been a while since I played this genre, a metroidvania that is played on 2D but has 2.5D graphics. No fps loss and spikes whatsoever and the graphics are very intuitive except on bosses. Settings gave me an option to set it @ 99 hz or 119 hz but it was still locked @ 59fps. Not a big deal, just found weird.

I really liked the first 1-2 hours of the game, it slowly gives you the abilities on the game making it feel like a tutorial after the first boss. As you continue on the game, you are presented with up to 4 different plasmoids and with their different uses with the kunai having a secondary effect as well. The pacing was just great.

The difficulty scaling on enemies is perfect and all the bosses are unique though some can be cheesed especially the second evolution of the final boss. It was the most underwhelming boss fight even though it was also the final one.

The controls are somewhat finicky on keyboard when aiming for the kunai as well when sticking on walls, but that might be just me sometimes since I always want to charge your attack (holding the atk button). Despite of that, the fighting controls feels very responsive and you get this nice feeling when you are juggling you plasmoids on bosses.

The game has been bundled twice now but if you missed those and are planning to get it, I'd buy this at least 50% since it is quite short but nevertheless you'll have great fun with it.

Overall Rating: 81%
