author: {'steamid': '76561198250128808', 'num_games_owned': 230, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 8, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1455454084}
review:
Rating: 7/10 - A fun platform game, with light Metroidvania elements. Completion time: 7:30.

= THE GOOD =

- It's a very fun game to play; you slay eniemies, upon enemies, upon enemies
- Very stylish graphics
- Very responsive controls
- The weapons, and their upgrades, are quite interesting, and make sense (although at the end, you'll use only plasma type 3 and 4)
- The enemies are relatively varied
- The bosses are quite fun
- The maps are relatively large

= THE SO-SO =
- Although the graphics are beautiful, it lacks the variety and creativity of the first Strider, which is a big big shame
- This could be somewhat classified as Metroidvania, although it's quite linear - in reality, you're only going to do a big backtrack at the end to pick up the missing powerups
- The NPE/Bosses don't move their mouths while talking; this makes them a bit weird looking.

= THE BAD =
- You can't customize the keys. Arcade stick is not supported
- You need 11 keys (ELEVEN!!) plus the 4 directions when playing, plus another 6/7 other ones used exclusively in map mode. This is very irritating; they could have made a more economic and intelligent choice.
- Shielded enemies of type 2 can only be killed with Plasma 2, not 3/4. This has no real strategic implications; it will only force the player to switch the plasma, klll the enemy, and switch back again, which is nothing else than annoying
- Many bosses will need to be killed several times over the game. It's quite boring to meet a past boss again.
- You can't skip the bosses' blabbering, which is cheesy and banal, and ultimately irritating
- The controls in "floating" gravity are a terrible mess, especially in the last boss
- There is no ending. DAFUQ!?!

author: {'steamid': '76561197994799155', 'num_games_owned': 1524, 'num_reviews': 307, 'playtime_forever': 890, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 890, 'last_played': 1456009534}
review:
A brilliant metroidvania with everything you could possibly want from the genre, themed around a cyber-ninja. The controls are tight, the level design is supurb (as is the location of the hidden goodies) and the graphics are really nice. The music is good, the array of weapons is varied and feels constantly progressive with each new item, just as the wide array of enemies steadily becomes more tricky to deal with. This game is hard, make no mistake, but they give you all the tools you need to survive, so the rest is up to learning patterns and being smart.

I only have two issues: Firstly, the occasional ambient dialogue has a huge subtitle box, which can sometimes obscure what's going on (in one encounter, I couldn't seen my character at all when he wasn't jumping). Secondly, there's no facial animation - a small annoyance, and perhaps understandable when 90% of the characters have their face covered, or are too small to see outside of cutscenes... but it is something that bugs me, in any game.

Highly recommended to any fans of the genre or ninja themes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198263236733', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 411, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 350, 'last_played': 1470950548}
review:
[h1]Highly recommended if you can play it with a controller. Otherwise...[/h1]

A solid, fast-paced action game with a Metroid-like exploration and high frame rate even on a 3-years-old laptop :D I've bought it on sale, but it would have been worth every single cent at full price XD

[b]Only two real CONs:[/b]
* on older computers (or older graphic cards) the game could perform really badly, since there is no frame skip. As a result, everything will go in slow-motion, killing the purpose of the game itself :/
* to play it with some USB controllers, it is necessary to download a third-party tool/key mapper (e.g. X360CE) - as for many other games around here :/

Oh, and trust me: [b][u]a controller is indeed needed[/u][/b]. Attempting to play this game with a keyboard will lead to frequent rage quits or key smashing. Without a controller, it's extremely difficult to play properly, given the dynamic feeling and pace of the game itself.

[b]Highly recommended![/b] Every real fan of Metroidvania games and classic arcade scrolling games should give it a try!

author: {'steamid': '76561198053960572', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1255, 'last_played': 1459520458}
review:
やりこむほどに「これぞストライダー飛竜」っていえる傑作。過去の飛竜の楽しみ方によってこの新しい飛竜が楽しめるかどうかが変わってきそう。テクニックではなく飛竜の知識の持ち合わせ方がかなり上級者向け。その分初代しか知らない知識でプレイすると半分くらいは「なんか期待した飛竜じゃない」っていう第一印象になってしまう。しかし中盤をすぎるあたりから初代のオマージュが増えてきて終盤では「すごく初代飛竜らしく」なってくる。知ったボスが登場してきてBGMも初代のものが増えてきて徐々に最後になるにつれゲームそのものが「実は飛竜でした！」ってなる謎のヴェールの取り方がすごくかっこいい。最初のボスはいきなり飛竜２のオマージュからはいってるのになぜ気づいてあげられなかったのか。演出も肩肘張らずに飾りすぎない姿勢に愛を疑うこともあったけど、そのストイックさが実に飛竜らしくてよかった。





・なかなか死なないので緊張感がない。
・マップにジャンプアクション的な面白さがない
・ボスは全部ゴリ押しで攻略できそう
・探索して迷路を覚えるのがめんどくさい
・音楽が盛り上がらない、ずっとアンビエントな感じ。

これらが序盤を過ぎると解決されてくる。２０１４ 年版ストライダー飛竜はプレイの仕方としては旧作のサイファを連打する感覚よりは「溜めて狙ってしっかり斬る」感じで進めたほうがプレイしやすいし、乱暴なプレイになりにくい。序盤は力押しでも進められるが、攻撃せずに見ているとボスもしっかり攻略できるように作られているので、変に乱斬りするより、ジャンプでかわして「溜め斬り」していくと急に面白くなってくる。体力が多めなんで、ついラフプレイをしがちだけれども、結果的には丁寧に進めたほうが、効率的に早く進行できた。重要な要素だけど新しい飛竜は「どこから落ちても死なない」という大前提を覚えておくと、急にマップを移動しやすくなる。つぎの目的地も割と近いし、意地悪なマップもなくレーダー完備。いきなり難しいところが出てきたらそれはすぐに諦めるのが時間の節約になる、そこは行き止まりだ。そのあたりの作り手のさじ加減がわかってくると初めて「探索型の迷路」を楽しい、と思えた。
そのステージの中に飛竜１＆２のギミックが地味にたくさんつめ込まれている。３Dグラフィックも素直に飛竜らしかったしイメージも損なわれなかった。実績解除の名前が飛竜２の厨二仕様でこれはこれで面白かった。フフってなる。世界観は改造人間ストロバヤ的なやつとか鋼鉄ゴリラ（メカPONG）とかもちゃんとでてくるが、８０年代風のいかれたデザインでは登場しないので、そこだけは期待してはいけない。

BGM はオプションAを手に入れるあたりから、過去の飛竜BGMのアレンジが流れだしていい感じに。なぜかmacbook airのブートキャンプ環境では空中戦艦バルログ戦でしょっちゅう落ちるが、何度でも再挑戦したくなる出来になっている。飛竜２の要素やオマージュもふんだんにあるので飛竜２の知識も必要。飛竜１の知識だけで楽しもうと思うと後半まで焦らされる。エンディングを見る前に飛竜２をもう一度プレイしておくといいかもしれない。東風戦も意外と燃えたし、飛竜１で見せた壁に挟まれるトラップもあった。ボスも被弾しないように避ければ攻略しがいがあるしラスボスの展開も飛竜２っぽい、ベルトコンベアのギミックも逆重力もちゃんとあって後半になればなるほどストライダー飛竜してくる。

３０分くらいで遊びきれる旧作とは楽しみ方が真逆になるが、そのぶん待ち焦がれた飛竜の新作を長く楽しめる。音とアクションでつむぐドラマティックな３０分を楽しめる飛竜にも期待したい。

author: {'steamid': '76561197998118312', 'num_games_owned': 2100, 'num_reviews': 388, 'playtime_forever': 875, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 841, 'last_played': 1455138862}
review:
Rating 8/10
Overview: 2D action/platformer

The Good

+ Great graphics

+ A fun if not flaws metroidvania type game. As you play you acquire upgrades which can then be used to traverse further into the game. You can also backtrack to collect more upgrades. 

+ A wide variety of boss battles which are fun and challenging  

+ Good controls and combat. Light and heavy attacks mixed in with 3 different types of magic. 

+ Easy achievements 


The Average

The overall level design itself can be a bit confusing and the method to traverse between areas can be cumbersome. 


The Bad

- Voice Acting and dialogue are really bad

- I got a lot of slowdowns despite very little happening in the game. 

- Frustrating encounters with enemies, you get knocked down over and over again with little chance of recovery. 

Conclusion

A great 2D action platformer open world game. The overall level design is not as good as some of the best out there but this is still a great game to play if you are a fan of the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025461832', 'num_games_owned': 728, 'num_reviews': 198, 'playtime_forever': 388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 388, 'last_played': 1454853709}
review:
A pesar de contar con el protagonista más ninja de la historia de los videojuegos es un juego corto, con poquísimos enemigos que se repiten hasta la saciedad, un mundo "metroidvania" que es más lineal que un macarrón, unos poderes desbloqueables que bçasicamente consisten en cambiar de color el ataque normal y poco más.

Los escenarios tienen bastante estilo, y el protagonista se maneja de forma fluida, pero hacia el final empiezan a aumentar la dificultad de manera alarmante haciendo los combates frustrantes a más no poder: enemigos que te dejan aturdido o te congelan, jefes que no callan y cuyo cuadro de texto tapa la pantalla (¡en medio de la pelea!) son solo algunas cosas que el juego utiliza para subir la dificultad artificialmente.

En los momentos más positivos el juego no va más allá de ser pasable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005079603', 'num_games_owned': 621, 'num_reviews': 117, 'playtime_forever': 49, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 49, 'last_played': 1454791887}
review:
Since I'm pretty tired at the time of writing, I'll keep this review concise.

Would I recommend this game? No, I wouldn't. Why? Because, unlike what most people claim, the game just isn't fun. Maybe I'm crazy, but I feel like the complete lack of context and the INCREDIBLY weak excuse for a "story" in the game deals a rather harsh blow to it. Adding to that, the fact that the metroidvania tag applied is VASTLY misleading, I just couldn't find anything fun about it.

Now, just to be clear, the game isn't bad (extremely annoying flashing lights during "boss intros" notwithstanding), but I honestly couldn't find any enjoyment in playing it. I suppose if I have to praise it for something, it would be that it wastes no time in letting you get to the action and start kicking äss, but the fact of the matter is that it feels like that's ALL you do. Yeah, combat is pretty centrical for ALL metroidvania games, but there's SUPPOSED to be exploration as well!

Strider has essentially no exploration whatsoever. This, in case you're not aware, is a direct violation of the entire metroidvania formula. It'd be like a Super Mario game WITHOUT MARIO.

All in all, between the completely hollow "story" and the utter lack of exploration, I can't recommend this game. It's not bad, it's just boring. For me, anyway. 43/100

author: {'steamid': '76561197979938289', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 422, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 422, 'last_played': 1453971837}
review:
Well executed open world feel makes this Strider game feel great. The controls are tight and responsive and there are plenty of moves and combinations to master. Strider feels fluid, powerful, and is a lot of fun to control. The visuals, sound, and art style are all solid and work together well.

There are a lot of secrets to find if you like exploring, but many of them take the form of "you can't get here until you learn move XYZ 2 levels later" so you'll end up back tracking a lot if you want to find everything. I didn't bother.

I beat the game in 4:40 minutes with 45% "completion" rate, so the length isn't too long. If you try to get full completion though it will take you much longer. There are also challenges that you can do for more replay value.

One big gripe: the game will decide to use one controller randomly without any in game option to select which controller to use. If you have multiple controllers, this is a pain. In order to get the controller you want, you have to manually edit a settings file in the game's directory. Weak.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080618388', 'num_games_owned': 331, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 6295, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3448, 'last_played': 1683855186}
review:
Wow! Coming into this, I didn't quite expect what I got. Strider is an amazingly fun action platformer, that you can either play in short bursts, or one long playthrough. The game boasts a progression system similar to that of Mega Man, and is an adreniline driven hack and slash. You play as Hiryu, a part of a ninja clan known as the Striders, sent deep into the heart of a technologically advanced version of Cold War Russia, where the citizens are ruled under the steel fists of Maio (Prenounced May-O). Your Mission? Get in, assassinate Maio, get out, get payed. It's not as simple as this, as Maio and his countless armies forsee your attack, and are constantly on guard. Will you defeat Maio, and free his people? That's up to you. There are only 4 problems I have with this game, and they are quite small. 
1: Cutscenes are unskippable, and some bosses have cutscenes before you fight them, so you have to watch them multiple times if you die. 
2: Some cutscenes suffer from framerate issues, and can go on, even after the characters have finished speaking. 
3: Occasionally Stiff or wooden voice actors, some of which just sound plain silly. 
4: Occasionally, Strider will get stuck on a wall for a few seconds, or the controls will go stiff for a few seconds. Besides these small problems the game is a blast, and I recommend you give it a try. My absolute favorite thing about this game is that Strider will swing his sword just as fast as you press the attack key, so if you mash it, bloods gonna fly. I give Strider a solid 8/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082453504', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 205, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1454249727}
review:
Strider is one of those series that to me feels criminally overlooked. The original arcade/genesis version was as cool as it was tough as old boots with an absolutely killer sound track. I've always had a soft spot for this series and Strider as a character but he seems to have been inexplicably side lined until now. The gameplay manages to combine the old with the new with Strider being extremely mobile and slashing his blade with unprecedented speed. The addition of metroidvania style gameplay seems like a natural fit for the franchise and the sprawling pseudo Russian capital city provides some breath taking and artistically intriguing locales to venture into. 

As a long time fan of the franchise I'm absolutely thrilled to have it back in such a blaze of glory. I only hope that Capcom sees fit to bless us with a sequel, perhaps something even more fleshed out than this already substantial for the money game.

In closing this is a stunning looking game with excellent gameplay and a swell of content. I would highly recommend this title.

author: {'steamid': '76561198111025332', 'num_games_owned': 356, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1264, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 945, 'last_played': 1467881683}
review:
Strider is a great game that any platformer, action-packed loving gamer should have in their collection. If you want to know much about this game, here are the points I have written in details, and I have avoided spoilers.:

1/ Story: The game story is nice, albeit a little bit too simple, but sufficient enough.

2/ Platforming: The puzzles, obstacles in the game are well-designed. You will need to acquire the skills in the game to get past a lot of obstacles. The Devs really have thoroughly put their thoughts and mind into designing these obstacles. 

3/ Exploration: As you play in a huge city, Strider is full of places to visit if you decide not to stick to the guide and instruction from the game. Try wandering around the city on your own, you will discover a huge lot of fun things to do.

However, bear in mind that this is merely a little open-world type of game. There won't be side-quests. And sometimes if you happen to be in somewhere you haven't been before, or re-visited randomly, there may be boss battles, so prepare yourself well. But don't worry, the game won't put you into a random boss battle if it doesn't know you have the skills required to enter that battle.

But after you get some skills, you could go around and try visiting the old places to get more power-ups. If you are afraid that you might get lost, use the Maps.

4/ Maps: However, sometimes, you will need to do some zoom-in and out for the Maps. I did had a problem with the Map when trying to switch from one area to another, since the Map of another area might disappear from the screen, and you could not see anything. In this case, I would recommend trying move the arrow keys around, try zoom-in and zoom-out, you will get over this problem easily.

5/ Power-ups, upgrades: Strider offers a good variety of power-ups you will need to win the combat. From Ice, Flame, to Magnetic, Kunai, Option A-B-C (you will figure it out what they are) or skills such as Projectile Reflecting with your sword... and much more, it's definitely great to play such as a game with so many things you can use to deal with the enemies. These upgrades will also help you in exploring the city. And using them to get to strange places you have never been to before.

6/ Combat + Boss: Definitely the best points to talk about. If there's anything I would recommend, it would be going for the Hard mode when you start playing the game.

Trust me, it's gonna be one huge fun to do. That's what I did when I first played this game. Going for the Hard mode in Strider not only makes you realize how much important it is to explore the city to get more power-ups, costumes (did I mention there are 11 awesome costumes in this game?), concept art.. but also to make you prepare yourself harshly for go into the battle with the Bosses.

For 1 or 2 first bosses of the game, you will feel like the game is pretty harsh on your Health, since the Bosses at Hard mode are no joke, they mean serious business if you don't master your dodging and sword slicing skill well enough. But after getting your hands on some Energy and Health upgrades, you will realize the Boss battles are much gonna be easier. They will only have one or two fatal strikes at you. So try Hard mode, it's totally encouraging. Even the damage of normal minions, enemies are gonna be a lot strong, so try to get a lot of upgrades. By the time you reach the Final Boss, believe me, the Final Boss would not be hard to finish.

As for the Combat: I would state it in two words "Button Mashing". I can spoil you on this one, but it means, in the boss battle, if you want to win (Well, I'm still talking about Hard mode) without letting yourself getting killed fast by the Bosses' damage, you would do well to hit those guys as fast as you could. Since the number of consecutive hits on them do matters in this game, hit them fast will help you increase your own damage. Therefore, you will have pressed a button, like , 200-300 times after this game, and that's ok :D


Well, that's about everything I can tell you. I totally would play this game all over again. Because Strider is a great game. And it's gonna be totally worthy of your own money.

Score: 9.5/10. -0.5 because of the Maps >.>

review: It feels silly for the player to be shot by someone off the screen because the view is so zoomed in (with no control over zoom by player input). review:

author: {'steamid': '76561197973647025', 'num_games_owned': 597, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1836, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1836, 'last_played': 1434999440}
review:
Strider is awesome, fans of the original and indeed any of the side scrolling classics such as castlevania or metroid will feel right at home playing this game, its is the kind of game one can get familiar with and speed run, at its highest dificulty i'd say only the mecha gorilla and the last boss pose a threat, but that doesnt mean to say the game is easy, i'd say its enjoyable enough for veterans of the genre  to blaze their way through and intuitive enough that allows beginners to settle in and enjoy this awesome hack/slash/shoot rpg platformer.

All the characters and levels are beautifully sculpted and the game really excels in its overall visual appeal.
Controls are smooth and on point.

My only gripe is there is really no replayability unless you are trying to do speed runs, once you unlock evrything and finish the main story that is it, i guess that isnt a bad thing per say i just felt that perhaps there could be chalenge levels or even a level editor to it.

i'll give Strider a solid 8/10

certainly a game you should experience once in your life.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990539789', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 173, 'playtime_forever': 1074, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1074, 'last_played': 1452630330}
review:
Strider is a 2d platform video games.

About the game:
-------------------
Strider has been resurrected from the old consoles and give it a totally remake.
Only this game has a really nice exteded whell explained story mode with cut scenes.
If you look to the old games on the Nintendo / Sega Era this game is huge.
The game is one big city you can explore and on the way you fin new powers that will unlock new parts of the city.
You play as a strider send on a mission to detroy the evil that controls the city.
On you way you play you need to collect items to get stronger.
New weapons, New Moves, and Health as Energy Upgrades.
You have a mini as big map and these main upgrade you will need are show on the map.
And not to forget to mension there are many hidden items to collect.
Like in-game challanges, art, skins and many more.


Controls?
-----------
What appeals to me in this game is the fast action and fine controls.
Climing on walls gives you a freedom to explore and the Strider response very whell what direction you like to go.
You need to keep in mind further you explore the game and get upgrades you will have more buttons cominations to used you powers.
This can be difficult when you are in a complex fight with multiply enemies or the stage boss.
So you need to remember what buttons do the powers and how to use them on the best way.

Graphics:
-----------
Check my or other screenshots that tells eneugh.


Overall:
---------
If you really like 2d platform games I can really recommand you this game.
It's not the easiest game to pick up only it will give you a lot of joy as frustration to play this.

I give this game a 10/10 score.

review:
In a nutshell it is Metroid Ninja Flavour.

Strider is honestly a great looking, smooth handling metroidvania. The only real complaints I have are that the boss difficulty felt a little all over the place (mostly with physically larger bosses being very easy to cheese with a certain upgrade) and with the lack of a central hub/quick travel system it is a hideous chore to go back and collect previously unobtainable powerups. Even the in-game map doesn't tell you which borders are the area transitions and where they lead to.

It's a touch short but of course there is always hard mode or finding 100% of the collectibles if you have a compulsive need to fulfill some kind of $X/hr of entertainment rate.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032121256', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 650, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 391, 'last_played': 1683961187}
review:
Quick paced and fun combat. Quite reminscient of the other Strider games.
Not crazily difficult, although I'm halfway through on Normal difficulty, but I've had a few deaths along the way.
Pleasantly happy with the combat style, powerups, and ways of battling the enemies.
Storyline doesn't bog down combat. And if you want to learn more of the story you can view the intel from the extras menu as you find them.
A controller is very useful and highly recommended.

Kudos for remixing the NES music for some of the battles.

Cons:
The other outfits you unlock are just palette swaps (so far to what I've found). Would've liked a few other perks and challenges associated with them.
Finding secrets is kinda easy with the on screen map. You see an icon and you kinda have an idea how to get it.
Some of the more fun bosses die quickly.
Killing most enemies give health to make the game seem kind-of easy at times.

review:

Your pet Eagle and Cat

review:
A fun, but ultimately forgettable "metroidvania" game. Effectively makes you feel like a ninja with very fluid, smooth and fast-paced combat, but the story is laughable and its environments repetitive. The combat saves the game thanks to it's great feel and bevy of options available to you. I had little to no desire to explore the environments, which really makes this game feel smaller than it actually is.

All in all, I think it's a fun little game.  The fast-paced, acrobatic combat elevates it from something ho-hum to relatively unique and enjoyable.

review:
ไอ้หมอนี่มันใครวะ ? อ้อ...นินจาจากเกม Marvel vs Capcom สมัยนู้นนนนนี่!!! 

ถ้ากำลังมองหาเกมแนวตะลุยด่านด้านข้างแบบสมัย PS1 มาเล่นล่ะก็ Strider ถือเป็นเกมที่ห้ามพลาดแน่นอน ยิ่งถ้าเป็นแฟนเดนตายเกมนี้มาตั้งแต่สมัยภาคแรกๆที่...ช่างเถอะ เกิดไม่ทัน

-เกมมาแนวตะลุยด่านด้านข้างเน้นฟันๆลุยดาหน้าไปเรื่อยๆ แต่เกมมันไวมากๆและโครตพริ้วไหวเหนือสายน้ำ มันทำให้เรารู้สึกตื่นเต้นได้ตลอดทุกๆครั้งที่เริ่มได้ของเล่นใหม่ๆมาจนช่วงท้ายเกมที่อาวุธครบ/ท่าครบ และการโจมตีของกีกี๊ที่อย่างกับสตอร์มทรูปเปอร์สาดกระสุนมั่วไปมาทั่วฉาก โดยเฉพาะบอสบางตัวนี่อยากให้มีมุมมองแบบเกมยานยิงให้มันรู้แล้วรู้รอดไปเลย 

-จุดเด่นอีกอย่างคือฉากที่ออกแบบมาลึกและสวยงามมากๆ ดูๆแล้วเอาไปดัดแปลงเป็นเกมแอคชั่นเดินลุยด้านหน้ายังได้เลยนะ ยังไม่รวมถึงความใหญ่และเส้นทางลับย้อนไปย้อนมาให้เราค้นหา ที่พอได้ท่าใหม่ๆก่อนถึงจะย้อนกลับมาเปิดได้และพวกกับดักตามจุดต่างๆที่อาศัยความพริ้วในการหลบ มีทั้งเลื่อย ไฟฟ้า หนาม ฯลฯ จุดนี้มันคล้ายกับเกม Castlevania มาก ไม่ได้หมายถึงภาคล่าสุด แต่พูดถึงภาคสมัยที่ผมยังหัวเกรียนถือกระเป๋าหนังจาคอบนู่น 

-พูดถึงข้อเสียจริงๆจังๆนี่นึกไม่ออก เกมมันสมบูรณ์มาก ไม่นับไอ้พวกบทง่อยๆแบบในการ์ตูน หรือความยากที่ก็ไม่ได้ยากถึงขนาดเกมแฟมิคอมกับฉากคัตซีนจืดๆเพราะเกมนี้มันไม่ได้ทุนหนาอะไรขนาดนั้น ได้ระดับนี้นี่ถือว่าเจ๋งสุดๆแล้วกับราคาระดับนี้


เอาเป็นว่าใครคิดถึงเกมตะลุยด่านด้านข้างสมัยวันวานที่ไม่จำเป็นต้องมีระบบซับซ้อน ไม่ต้องมาอัพเวล ใส่ไอเท็มนู่นนี่ให้ปวดหัว เน้นเปิดปุ๊ปลุยเพลินๆ ถ้าพลาดเกมนี้ไปเสียดายแย่ 

10/10

review:
Do you miss:

-Simple but edifying story/plot.
-Tight controls
-Addictive action
-Smooth visuals
-Game mechanics that are easy to pick up and learn
-Secrets galore

I did, and I almost missed out on this game, I had forgotten about it in my steam library, and dismissed it as shallow after only playing an hour or so. Recently I have come back to it and realized that this is one gem  of a game, and now I'm kicking myself for not having realized it sooner. This game is definately worth picking up, and has solid gameplay just like the games of yore, like Super Metroid and Mega Man X. If you like retro games and games with tight controls and skillful battles you'll enjoy STRIDER.

review: I always had a soft spot for the original arcade game, so I was pleased to see they were remaking it. The remake lacks some of the oddball charm of the original and has less variety in its environments, but it's a solid enough run-and-gun with lots of nods to its predecessors but not to the point of being confusing for new players. I played it to completion and had a good time with it. Expect to spend between 6 and 12 hours if you want to explore every nook and cranny and get all the hidden goodies (a mix of in-game powerups and extras like concept art).

author: {'steamid': '76561198069601794', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 498, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 498, 'last_played': 1451064188}
review:
TL;DR Play it for the exploration and platforming.

Strider is a metroidvania style game. For the uninitiated, this means it's a platformer with vast explorable levels and tons of little nooks and crannies to find unlockables and hidden items. It's also got an emphasis on combat and by the end of the game you'll find you have a lot of tools at your disposal to be able to take care of the various enemies that get thrown your way. That said, I'm going to break this review down into the various components that are considered essential in the execution of a good metroidvania and see how [b]Strider[/b] measures up.

[h1]Controls: 9/10[/h1]
Strider is an excellent protagonist. He's extremely capable and exists as an extention of your fingertips. From the moment you start the game, you'll notice how fluidly and accurate the control scheme is and this allows you to truly take ownership of the game. For the most part, if you get hit, it's because you failed to react in time and not because the controls failed you. 

Strider sticks to any wall or ceiling and is able to climb every surface from the start. Sword attacks are directional and instantaneous so you're easily able to parkour your way through the levels, slicing and dicing as you go. This feeling is unique to the game, and I think what makes it a lot of fun.

[h1]Combat: 6/10[/h1]
Combat is somewhat lacking. The majority of your experience will have you mashing the attack button repeatedly to take down enemies, and the only true variation on your regular attack is the charged form. Shielded enemies provide incentive to use your charged slash, but end up feeling like more of a nuisance that breaks up the button-mashing than a variable challenge. Additionally, you have special abilities you unlock as the game goes on, all of which better enable you to steamroll your way through the game. But you will likely rely on your sword slash for the majority of the game as it retains its strength throughout.

Not only is the typical combat somewhat repetitive, but there is absolutely no incentive to kill anything. I realized this about a half-hour into my playthrough and just started skipping all nonessential enemies. There is no kill score to rack up, no experience points or customizable character additions to get. You kill red shirts for being annoying and that's about it. So yes, it's still fun, but I think it's a huge missed opportunity not to reward a player for killscore. Add to that that it largely lacks challenge, and you find it fall short here.

[h1]Level Design: 5/10[/h1]
I have mixed feelings on this. At some points the level design is brilliant and rewarding, and at others it's equally dull and infuriating. Games in this style commonly emplace artificial barriers to progress. Think of The Legend of Zelda, where you need to get that next gadget (such as the boomerang) before you're able to reach certain areas of the game. The way strider uses this mechanic, however, can be infuriating. You'll find yourself skipping so much content because it's behind a door that you can't unlock yet or you haven't gotten the kunai. It's not fun. By the time I was able to access everything, I no longer cared to backtrack through the entire game to find the stuff. Compare this to a game like Shadow Complex, where part of the game actually has you backtracking through previous areas for actual progression after you've unlocked all the gadgets and you'll see that Strider falls short here.

Where the game shines, however, is the platforming. This is something that I can confidently say the game did well. The game gives you a lot of tools to navigate its levels and you'll find yourself using all of them simultaneously before you even realize it. This ninja-feel is something the game achieves well, and is extremely rewarding.

[h1]Boss Fights: 7/10[/h1]
One of the things I'd read about going into the game is that the boss fights were repetitive and recycled. I actually couldn't disagree more. Even though you see some bosses more than once, they are not at all the same fights in most of those cases. Now, one of my qualms is that they are sometimes unfair in that some attacks are impossible to react to on your first attempt. Unfortunately this is typically the only challenge to overcome as they generally are very easy to best. Overall, boss fights are fun if not a little frustrating at times.

[h1]Final Verdict: 7/10[/h1]

I have mixed feelings for the game overall. Up front, I'll say that I played it on Normal difficulty and don't intend to play it again. It lacked challenge for the most part, and I saw a lot of missed opportunity in a somewhat decent game. My biggest problem with it is the abysmal level design. Still, it was a fun game to play once and I think a lot of players will have found enough reason to go back for all the extras once they've unlocked all the gadgets. I do recommend waiting until the game is on sale, but it's definitely worth your time to play once you own it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074891661', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 890, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 850, 'last_played': 1449263504}
review:
Strider es un juego muy entretenido y bastante frenético, donde se premia con velocidad (no literal) el ser habilidoso y tener buenos reflejos. Es una verdadera gozada rejugarlo intentando pasartelo lo más rápido posible. Me encanta el combate y el diseño de los niveles pero se me hace pesado tener que volver hacia atrás, por suerte esto no ocurre tampoco demasiadas veces. Además tiene muchos coleccionables, que al que le guste conseguirlos le supondra un reto tenerlos todos, ya que para recoger algunos hay que superar una especie de "puzles-plataformas", como por ejemplo el ajustar tu salto a la perfección y pulsar el RB en el momento justo (juego con mando de la xbox) o acceder a un lugar para desbloquear otro sitio donde es bastante difícil moverse, etc. Aunque la mayoría de estos coleccionables simplemente están en el techo o en puntos ciegos de la pantalla.
Es bastante recomendable aunque necesitaras un buen pc para jugarlo de forma totalmente fluida (yo le tuve que bajar la resolunción por desgracia y se veia como si fuese un juego antiguo... aunque esto tampoco es que sea un punto malo xD).

author: {'steamid': '76561197999637285', 'num_games_owned': 848, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 508, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 508, 'last_played': 1451023250}
review: Well, this was an unexpected pleasure. I'm struggling to think of a single complaint... It's not an earth-shatteringly innovative game, but that's ok. Strider is a exceptionally well crafted metroidvania-style game, and I thoroughly enjoyed it. Didn't take itself too seriously, which is always appreciated. Extremely fast, fluid and reponsive character movement and combat. Backtracking never felt like much of a chore, it's fun just running around. Combat is reasonably challenging (and there's always Hard mode for the masochists out there). The addition of new abilities was well paced, and mixed things up just enough to keep it fresh. You really owe it to yourself to check Strider out, if you're at all a fan of the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119507990', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 7, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7, 'last_played': 1450953235}
review: I may not be the best person to review a game such as this, as I have never been the best at platformers. But, I do believe in a gradual scale of difficulty. Within 5 minutes, I basically hit a brick wall, as I had enemies thrown at me left and right and kept getting killed in the same spot. I know a lot of people look for the "NES" level of difficulty, but I'm not. If you can get past the difficulty, the game looks and plays beautifully. The controls are great and it feels true to its successor, which I have beating by the way. So, I'm not looking for an NES hard game-I grew up with the NES and remember how difficult it was. I'm looking for something with reasonable challange and a good story. This may be your cup of tea and definetly worth a look at.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051810419', 'num_games_owned': 333, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 770, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 770, 'last_played': 1450836647}
review:
Possibly the best side scrolling action game I've ever played.  

+ Amazing fast paced action
+Very fluid movements that feel good and allow easy mastery (With controller)
+Interesting game mechanics and level design, very large complex levels with many areas that have occasional platforming challenges.
+Enemies are smart and can be tough
+Many powerups, moves and unlockable skins,etc. 
+ Fairly good enemy variety
+ Fun and interesting Boss battles

Other than that there is not much in the way of story, its mostly cheesy non-sense but its ok. Also the "fast travel" system is quite pointless and not very accesible to use. 

Excellent game that is very cheap nowadays and worth picking up without hesitation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034106728', 'num_games_owned': 1672, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 482, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 371, 'last_played': 1455666203}
review: Polished, gorgeous visuals with an excellent sense of style carefully laid over mostly boring gameplay and a "metroidvania" experience that lacks any and all sense of what makes good examples of the genre good. The game has some legitimate highs, but on the most part the experience is dull and I found myself sleepy as I meandered through another generic set of corridors while another lifeless NPC repeated the same taunt at me three times in a row. The visuals can only carry the game so far.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999938574', 'num_games_owned': 977, 'num_reviews': 590, 'playtime_forever': 268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 268, 'last_played': 1451096659}
review:
It's probably ok for a remake/reimagination of 1988 game.

But for a game released in 2014 it incorporates THE WORST possible design decisions.

- No tutorial or introduction of some sort (the controls are pretty standard, though)
- No feasible story
- Bad placement of checkpoints. For instance, if there's a boss fight, the checkpoint is not right before the boss, but 5 minutes ago
- Boss fights are extremely repetitive (as are fights with the common enemies, but bosses don't die so quickly)
- As noted in the other negative review, all bosses are pretty similar
- Enemies respawn when you get back to a previously visited location

Overall, this feels like a 20 year old arcade game with modern visuals. I had a fair share of these games back then, so excuse me, if I don't like this one.

review:
Una buena mezcla entre el Strider Original y Strider 2, sin duda una experiencia colorida, muy colorida, disfrute este juego, tiene jugabilidad solida, rapida y satisfactoria, la trama es basicamente la misma que la de los juegos anteriores con algunas modificaciones, tiene una dificultad normal decente, un diseño de niveles que cumple con el estandar con multitud de coelccionables y mejoras en las habilidades que son opcionales, una estetica particularmente brillosa de lo cual lo unico que desentona son los modelos de algunos personajes, tiene una musica que es bastante olvidable pero esto se debe a que los efectos de sonido son mas predominantes.
En conclusion Strider es un juego muy completo que se disfruta por el gameplay y su estilo visual, es buen juego que probablemente te haga exprimirlo al 100%, lo recomiendo a los fans de Strider o a aquellos que busquen un buen desahogo.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960446959', 'num_games_owned': 699, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 831, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 831, 'last_played': 1448749370}
review:
At its core, Strider 2014 is a high-speed Metroidvania. It follows the formula pretty straight: platforming, distinct zones, collectables, and mobility and weapon upgrades that unlock new areas.

Strider's main strength is the feeling of speed and power that was clearly a core design consideration. This is a game about movement, first and foremost, much like the original Capcom arcade title. There's no XP or leveling system, making much of the combat completely optional if you'd rather just blow right past everything instead. But the fact that you can blow [i]through[/i] enemies instead is part of the appeal, part of the sense of power that the player experiences.

This would be irrelevant if the controls weren't good; luckily, Strider controls beautifully. Environments are easy to understand, boss fights are (mostly) about player performance and not trying to figure out what to do, and everything just feels very tuned and well-tested.

There’s no story to speak of. There’s a collection of enemies who are clearly made in the 90’s arcade game mold -- they exist to taunt the player, attack, and eventually explode.The voice acting is largely awful but one gets the idea that this was deliberate.

The problem, really, is that Strider 2014 is short and shallow. It’s the sort of title that was designed for a $10 - $20 price point, to be downloaded over online services. Once you’ve found all the collectables and upgrades, there is nothing else to [i]do[/i] in the world except go fight the final boss. There are challenge levels but they feel tacked-on and don't have any rewards for completion. It’s not like some Metroidvania titles where there’s radically different sorts of play styles depending on enemy drops and equipment choices, where each trip through the game can be very different. The replay value of Strider is in higher difficulty levels and speedrunning, and if you’re not interested in those, you’ll be done with the game in one relatively short playthrough.

It’s a short ride, but it’s a fun one.

review:
Strider pays homage to the classic side-scrolling action games of past, but with modern day conveniences (like no limit of retries, save files and checkpoints). 

This game has lots of fighting, lots of enemies, and a steadily increasing repetoire of abilities to use throughout. The game is fast-paced, and it always feels challenging but never unfair.

If you want a quick romp through nostalgic gameplay, but without the headache of actually playing those old games that probably suck by today's standards, Strider is a good one to play.

7/10 "Good"

author: {'steamid': '76561198212769343', 'num_games_owned': 466, 'num_reviews': 119, 'playtime_forever': 1236, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1236, 'last_played': 1450025827}
review:
Reboot of Strider (1989): a 2D platform hack and slash game.

Very decent game for those looking for this kind of game. While it does resemble the original game it was redone to fit today's standards.

Pros:
 - Controls are very responsive specially with a gamepad
 - Upgrade system similar to metroid
 - Graphics are good
 - Music is decent
 - Levels are very well designed
 - Upgrades are well designed and useful
 - Fun and it doesn't get boring

Cons:
 - Voice actors speak like they're in a cartoon, most sound like morons and there's no Japanese option
 - Altough graphics are good, I'm not a fan of dark and exagerated bloom effect
 - 3D models lack detail and some look uninspired
 - Lacks variety in enemies and backgrounds
 - In the original Strider the enemies were anime styled, much cooler and colorful
 - In the original Strider the backgrounds were much more varied and colorful
 - The collectable items are not rewarding and kind of irrelevant
 - Short game

Despite the negative points I'm not complaining that the developers spent much more time in level design than graphics or created a short decent game rather than a long crappy game. It is a much better game than the original.

Hopefully Capcom will create more Strider games like this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978637704', 'num_games_owned': 586, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1015, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1015, 'last_played': 1449710110}
review:
[h1][b]Pros:[/b][/h1]
[b][u]+ Very tight and solid mechanics[/u][/b]
~ The game is very fluid and natural. Has very satisfying feedback and feel when attacking and moving. Hiryu will attack as fast as you mash the button and mechanics like fast falling when pressing down in the air plus a brisk pace makes this feel great. The combat also feels solid with flashy and satisfying visual feedback when attacking enemies with sparks and bright colors flying everywhere.

[b][u]+ Fast progression[/u][/b]
~ You never feel like a segment is dragged out as you will constantly be unlocking power-ups. You also feel like a powered up badass if you decide to backtrack for collectibles with your upgrades in places you got your ass handed to before.

[b][u]+ Tons of bosses and unlockables[/u][/b]
~ If you like Metroidvania/Metroid-like games with a tons of bosses and unlockables, then this game will satisfy that desire. The actual upgrade collectibles are a small amount but you can unlock stuff like concept art, story info, and alternate skins/costumes.

[b][u]+ Heavily inspired by Super Metroid in game design and progression, while keeping the feeling of being a badass ninja[/u][/b]

[b][u]+ Excellent mix of platforming and action[/u][/b]
~ If you like platforming segments ontop of your action, this game has it in spades. Thankfully they aren't too tedious or challenging minus maybe one or two segments.

[b][u]+ Old school game with shiny graphics[/u][/b]

[h1][b]Cons:[/b][/h1]
[b][u]- Difficulty all over the place in boss battles[/u][/b]
~ I played on hard, and playing the game and getting around areas never felt too difficult minus a few areas. The boss battles aren't very difficult until the latter half of the game, where the order of their patterns gets faster, more intense, and randomized. However, they do the same attack patterns even if they are out of order, so that helps a lot I guess

[b][u]- Backtracking for upgrades and collectibles is time consuming due to lack of good overworld design/fast travel points[/u][/b]
~ it's not too bad as there are fast travel points but it could be way better in terms of placement and where they take you

[b][u]- Unbalanced sound design[/u][/b]
The music isn't bad and actually fits the game pretty well, but it's nothing you'll be humming to any time soon. It is the lack of sound balance when fast traveling and attacking that puts this as a con. I put the volume up on my headphones because the base game was kind of quiet, but when you fast travel and attack it's like you're getting stabbed in your eardrums with sudden intense loud sound. 

[h1][b]TL;DR[/b][/h1]
This game is an old school action/platformer made in the vein of Super Metroid/Metroidvanias. You feel like a badass ninja with tight mechanics and feedback. If you're one of those "muh story and presentation" people when it comes to games, look elsewhere. If you want a good action sidescroller Metroid like game, play this right now; it's definitely one of the better options available.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016065178', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 360, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 360, 'last_played': 1449586781}
review:
Un ninja de la 2d avec un peu de profondeur, j'appelle ça de la 2.5d perso ^^ . C'est ce que vous aurez sur Strider.

Scenario: Un ninja des méchants, vous tapper, eux mourir... mouai ca résume bien l'idée. Bon le coté 1vs tout le reste du monde est forcément démeusuré, quand au ending... je vais pas vous spoil mais je me suis marrer tellement le héros se la pète à la ninja gaiden ^^ . Un des cotés négatifs seraient la logique du ninja qui n'est pas du tout furtif vu que c'est du beat them all ^^

Graphisme: Pour du petit jeu à 15€ il est très propre. Certaines cinématiques zoomeront un peu trop sur les perso et on pourra voir quelques aliasing mais ca reste quand même très bon à mon humble avis.

Gameplay: Très nerveux comme il le faut pour un jeu avec un ninja qui se bat contre des gardes qui eux ont des armes à feu. Je l'ai trouvé un peu mou au début au vu du manque de compétences mais plus on avance et plus ça devient complexe. Entre le switch d'éléments que vous utilisez et les différentes attaques spéciales que vous débloquez, il devient très vite technique si on veut faire un perfect sur un boss (ce que je n'ai jamais réussi pour être honnête ^^). Ma technique sur les boss consistaient juste à bourrer les combos et utiliser un maximum les attaques spéciales qui font mal et vous permet de vous mettre à couvert ou continuer à bourrer au cac^^

Donc vous l'aurez compris, je recommande ce jeu, prix pas cher surtout que je l'ai eu en solde ce qui m'a fait l'avoir à moins de 10€ voir peu être à moins de 5 mais je m'avance en disant ça. Une durée de vie de 5h pour finir le jeu tout de même en ayant fait que 60% du jeu. Je trouve que c'est un très très bon ratio qualité/prix/temps de jeu. Je vous conseille d'attendre une petite solde steam d'été/hiver... bref celle que vous voulez et vous n'en serez que plus ravis ;)

review:
yo y'all got probs if you're running this super slowly I've got 3 year old hardware that's not that great and still played it fine

it platforms pretty crazily, it's fast, and there's a lot of assassinations

pacing is a bit of a sine wave rollercoaster but you'll enjoy it. It took me about 6 or so hours (2 of those were backtracking in the endgame) to beat the game, and the only thing I really didn't like was just the lackluster ending. It's REALLY lackluster. the final tower is definitely a letdown especially when it's all "you can't go back to get items." You'd think it'd be like "oh fuck this is gonna be pretty brutal." It's really not, man. Besides that, I think it's great. You've got lots of room for failure, it's fast, Hiryu is extremely acrobatic and his abilities allow for some crazy movements, as well.

I just really don't love the endgame, 'tis all. The world's interconnected but it's hard to figure out where exactly you're missing stuff in the world, which is a bummer. Definitely try it out. I had fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104851086', 'num_games_owned': 3969, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1580374963}
review:
玩的是PS4版，Steam也寫些感想吧。

手感一流是不用說的，當年的動作天尊Capcom把Strider系列一脈相承的爽快感很好地帶到了本世代，我是很喜歡Capcom把老的平台動作遊戲製作HD重製版或者續作的，比如Bionic Commando和本作。

畫面也很好，光影、角色、敵人和背景的設計在我看來都沒什麼可挑剔的，再加上切割和打擊的音效，算得上是一種視聽享受了。

但是也有些缺點，就是Boss的設計。普通難度下，中後期的Boss西王母和倒數第二個Boss都比較難，死了很多次才打過，但是最終Boss第一次打就過關了，讓人本來很期待結果卻有些洩氣。困難難度沒有打，因為收集要素讓人有些疲倦了。

總而言之，是個爽快的好遊戲。

author: {'steamid': '76561198160846714', 'num_games_owned': 1568, 'num_reviews': 181, 'playtime_forever': 391, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 391, 'last_played': 1445019076}
review:
STRIDER™ / ストライダー飛竜® - довольно посредственный платформер с элементами файтинга в будущем. Я не любитель такого вида игр и так же не люблю аниме (не знаю причем тут анимэ,но все герои какие-то анимешные), аниме норм, если там есть секас и сиськи, в остальном эта хрень для жирных ботанов которым не дают тянки. Но вернемся к игре. В игре были дорогие карточки и я только из-за этого решил в неё поиграть, а зачем купил вообще не помню.

Сюжет

Нам нужно найти и завалить какого-то могущественного диктатора и всю игру мы идём к своей цели, продираясь сквозь толпы разнокалиберных врагов.

Плюсы

1. Довольно приятная графика.
2. Много различных боевых приемов.
3. присутствуют элементы паркура и это скрашивает унылое прохождение.

Минусы

1. Почти все персонажи какие-то анимешные и мне это не понравилось. ( Ладно бы играть за сисястую шлюху школьницу :))

Выводы

Я не любитель платформеров и игр с таким видом на главного героя + аниме не оч люблю. По моему мнению игра заслуживает оценки: 5 из 10. Покупать советую любителям таких игр или коллекционерам значков в библиотеке.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046139210', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 890, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 564, 'last_played': 1483756866}
review:
As far as I know, Strider was not a particularly commonly known franchise, which is a shame given how awesome the 2014 version is. This is speaking as someone who only has ever played the NES version, which despite being okay, wasn't the greatest game to hit the market. However, this one far exceeded any expectations I had.
You are Strider Hiryu, your job is to kill Grandmaster Meio, but obviously no game could be as simple as THAT...and for good reason because Hiryu is a total badass and it's a pleasure to play longer just so you can kick serious heiney. It's a very action oriented game since you run, jump, and just generally hack anything that moves to death with Hiryu's Cypher, which apparently is some kind of tonfa-sword combo that can be powered with various plasma types. The game can probably best be described as a Metroidvania for those of you who know what that is. Hiryu must overcome various obstacles by searching out new weapons, abilities, and such to make it all around Meio's city.
And that's where the game has me for sure. If you're the kind of person who loves adventuring all about, having to know what's around every corner, and getting a little excited when you find a new power-up that will let you be even MORE of a badass ninja than you already are, then yes, definitely a game to consider getting. I'm currently not finished with the game, but I've logged a number of hours already and the game say's I'm only about 60% of the way through.
If there is one complaint to be had, I'll say that for normal difficulty, it seems particularly easy. Though I've done quite well at finding all the HP Upgrades, Hiryu doesn't take all too much damage unless you're standing around LETTING him get shot. If anything, the worst I've faced is when Hiryu falls into a trap and disappears and respawns on solid safe ground, which is more of an irritant than a real danger. Perhaps a harder difficulty on a later playthrough will give a bit more challenge, or possibly the game itself will bare its fangs when I get closer to the end.
Overall, I'd say it's a solid game and I'm quite often finding it difficult to hit the Exit option when I really need to stop playing :D

review:
The best way I can explain this game is the crazy Ninja stuff from Ninja Gaiden & Dynasty Warriors with the Platforming elements of Super Metriod.
If you like the sound of that then, pick up STRIDER because its just that.
The enemy scaling needs some work; at the start they can kill you quickly if you're not careful but they can also die just as fast but about 4 hours in it starts to balance up but every thing now becomes a painstaking one button Hold or Tap.
also i have a feeling its just me but, if you have a GTX 770, DON'T DSR on this game, it just crashes when you die.

BUT OTHER THAN THAT...
I LOVE THIS GAME, you can easily spend a few hours before you get pissed off at dying in the same section of enemy.
It's fluid game and a beautiful game minus those STUPID FAKE SCAN LINES, but I guess it's trying to go for a flamboyant 80s look and some of the faces have NO animations? it's a bit creepy

author: {'steamid': '76561197965153857', 'num_games_owned': 826, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 604, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 604, 'last_played': 1448718593}
review:
An average metroid-vania game with a hack-n-slash focus. While the combat is fun and frantic, it requires little finesse: Most rooms will be cleared with the same combination of abilities. Player upgrades are a little disappointing, and short of the first few, they have minimal effect on the way you play the game.

Visuals are great, using the 3D side-on environment to great effect. The story and world had potential, but too many key figures follow the evil villain stereotype to be taken seriously.

If this style of game is your cup of tea, then I'd happily recommend it, but only after you first look into Shadow Complex.[7.0]

author: {'steamid': '76561197998140916', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 379, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 379, 'last_played': 1448554919}
review:
Amazing, well planned and constructed maps; very visually appealing.  My only issue is with the play controls - I was expecting a loose control scheme, but was given a reactive-type instead.

For example:
When Strider gets close to a wall in midair, he reacts by grabbing onto the wall with his ninja tools.
When Strider attacks an enemy with a shield, the game reacts by slowing the game for effect while his weapon bounces off the shield and stuns him.
When Strider is struck in midair with practially anything, he reacts by falling to the ground and won't react until you've tried to jump several times.
When Strider stands on a gravity globe, the controls react depending on which side of the globe you're on and you have to change which direction to hold on the control stick in order to keep moving.  This is especially frustrating during the final boss fight in which not only are you jumping from gravity globe to gravity globe but you're dodging seemingly random attacks that all stun on impact whether you're airborne or not.

The game is great for what it is, but don't pick it up expecting a Metroidvania game - it's more a ninja-action game, which is really quite fitting the character and series.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093648864', 'num_games_owned': 208, 'num_reviews': 122, 'playtime_forever': 1052, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 257, 'last_played': 1464436310}
review:
An action packed game which lets your cypher do the talking.  The plot is unclear and there's hardly any dialogue, but who needs them if you can just slice and dice your enemies apart?

A man of a few words but full on action.  Here we have Strider, a cybernetic ninja hero out to save the day but has nothing to say.  

The plot is kind of vague, but it seems to be that he's come to a people's democratic republic of tyranny kind of country with an assignment to kill someone.

With eye-popping graphics, intuitive controls, fast-paced gameplay, and sheer badassery, you can't go wrong with Strider.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975938066', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1413, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1400, 'last_played': 1492158119}
review:
I'll never forget the first time I saw Strider in the Arcade, I was blown away (The visuals! The sounds!! The bosses!!!) It was like a magnet for my Alladdin's Castle Tokens...Fast forward to the announcement of an NES version of the game...I was super psyched (hmm...these screenshots aren't quite what I'm expecting...). Now fast forward again to the release of the NES game (What is this...it's nothing like the Arcade?!), then suddenly (Wait a minute, this is pretty cool...), and finally (This is one of the greatest NES games ever!!!)

Several years later I became the unfortunate owner of the Turd known as "Strider 2" by US GOLD for the Amiga. I couldn't resist when I saw the box at the store (Strider 2, are you kidding me!). The excitement only lasted a few short seconds...(Looks kind of like Strider, Sounds kind of like Strider...wait...did I just morph into a robot with tank treads for feet?!?! What the hell is this garbage!). It was so bad I had repressed the memory, only to have it crawl from the stinky depths while writing this review. US GOLD were The Masters of Dissapointment...Sh@tting all over some of my favorite franchises.

Strider 2 on PS1 (alright, now we're back in business!) was pretty solid, and although didn't quite have that magic that I had found in the original Arcade or NES game, it was another good Strider game (nothing wrong with that!).

Over the last 14 years, Hiryu would occasionally appear in Capcom games as an extra or playable charachter and this gave me some hope that they hadn't forgotten about one of my favorites.There was also Moon Diver on XBLA that was very "Stider-esque" and I believe was made by some former capcom employees, and that was decent...

Then came the announcement of this game...Initially I was excited, but apprehensive (what if it's not good...) so for some reason I held off. After hearing a friend mention how much he liked the new game, I decided it was time to give it a shot. 

In short, I love this game! It's like a delicious combo platter of the Original 2 (arcade & NES) Strider games, with chunky bits of strider 2 mixed in, all served up on a tasty Metroidvania platter. The graphics are great, the Sound is great, the controls are great (xb360 controller), there's lots to see and do, plenty of abilities and secrets to find, and there are some epic boss battles.  What more could I ask for? Not much...

If you like a good MetroidVania game, you'll like this. If you like a good Metroidvania game, and you like Strider, chances are you'll love this as much as I do.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041556895', 'num_games_owned': 1609, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 442, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 442, 'last_played': 1448005557}
review:
Story: The dystopian atmosphere (think 1984 but with robot enforcers) is nice, but when the characters start talking (good and bad guys) it makes the experience a bit too cheesy.

Gameplay: Not smooth/responsive like a Megaman game. The game helps you so you can't have perfect accuracy with anything. Some areas and bosses have cheap things meant to kill you the first time facing them. Combat variety consists of unlocking a new color (red main, yellow fire, blue ice, purple boomerang) and switching between them (which isn't very smooth and only the boomerang has new animations) for the enemy types.  Map/World is connected, so lots of backtracking to get to your next destination.

Sound: Generally good for the gameplay and music. Voices are atrociously bad. Some bosses (notably the dragons) have 16 bit sound effects for some moves for whatever reasons.

Graphics: Looks very cool. No moving lips during dialogues though. That and animated/comic cutscenes weren't in the budget.

Summary: Not as good as it could have been, but not as bad either. I was expecting something deeper gameplay-wise and Strider is a modern team's attempt to create an older experience. But they make too many artificial decisions rather than let the game flow like it should. Despite that I'm still inclined to recommend it, but just as okay and with caution towards its many flaws/"design choices". It's not quite the high production game I was (and you might be) expecting.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984505368', 'num_games_owned': 1529, 'num_reviews': 226, 'playtime_forever': 331, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 273, 'last_played': 1448061756}
review:
Warning: Starts of relatively easy and a bit repetitive but ramps-up the difficulty in BIG chunks AND loves making you repeat stuff over and over and over.

As well as the big leaps in difficulty, savepoints become become less frequent so repetition grows and grows - it really does LOVE wasting your time.

Many Minibosses and Bosses have unskippable intros, unskippable chatter and are generally just exercises in learning (as you watch all the intros and chatter over and over) their various moves - it's VERY VERY frustrating.

Lastly, the controls are just weird - holding X to charge attacks whilst jumping with A isn't really a great layout and the charge system "works when it feels like it".  Platforming is also clunky at times, whether Striders grabs things or not is a bit random sometimes...

Overall I'd skip this, the developers have failed to make a progressively challenging game and instead made one which has less than brilliant controls, loves making you watch to stuff and over and generally feels like a tiresome grind.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094256578', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 639, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 639, 'last_played': 1447705550}
review:
Verdict:
Strider is fast-paced side-scrolling slasher which hits all the right notes. The combat system is fun and constantly evolving with each new upgrade. By the end of the game your character has 3 powers, throwing kunai, 4 sword types and more than enough mobility to move around feeling like a real pro cyber ninja making this game a blast from start to finish. Also a lot of fun and hard boss fights are a real plus.

Some downsides/complaints:
My experience was ruined a bit by the game's perfomance. Even with the resolution turned down the game still dropped FPS consistenly when there were a lot of enemies and clutter on screen. Also navigating the map is a struggle by its self. You never really know how to get where you want to go unless you try and fail. And the 2 powers you unlock help you move around the map to specific places but don't indicate you where so only way to know is try and see which is really annoying. Last and least is the story is basically non-existent just acts as a tool for throwing at your way a ton of ridiculous enemies so it serves it's purpose.

review:
No es difícil de jugar, los enemigos no son muy variados pero tampoco están mal, es lo suficientemente largo para no arrepentirte por su compra.

Es un buen juego de plataformas, a veces peca de demasiada repetición y otras veces te pone contras las cuerdas, la IA es simple (¿qué más quieres para este tipo de juegos?) pero a su vez cada enemigo tiene su peculiaridad y cuando se juntan varios con propiedades diferentes sueles pasarlo mal más de una vez, no hay casi puzzles y la ambientación no está mal, se mantiene a 60 FPS si tienes un ordenador que lo permita.

La variedad reside en saber utilizar las habilidades de tu "espada" para combatir a tus enemigos que dispondrán de un arsenal parecido al tuyo e incluso mucho mayor para pararte. Combate rápido y fácil de controlar, aunque es un poco difícil de perfeccionar tu técnica, cuestión de práctica. Poco valor para ser rejugable pero no está mal.

Repite los "Boss" demasiadas veces de manera que los sueles encontrar hasta de típica IA débil que se incluye en el mapeado de manera "normal", eso es un punto bastante en contra. El tema de los coleccionables te ayuda a tener un motivo por el que explorar pero tampoco es muy gratificante a menos que quieras ver el arte del juego y un poco más de información sobre el juego en general.

El concepto de los personajes está bien, el trasfondo es muy normal y el objetivo pues igual pero oye, te puedes distraer bastante.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076721797', 'num_games_owned': 913, 'num_reviews': 774, 'playtime_forever': 814, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 814, 'last_played': 1447638992}
review:
As far as metroidvanias go, this really barely is one. The game will always let you know exactly where to go, and while you do revisit "areas", you tend to only ever go to new parts of the same areas. The map's not too massive but it's big enough, the areas are diverse enough too.

The controls are really pretty good, attacking and movement are both lightning-fast, and most of the powerups make Strider more fun to control. The dash is great, the double jump is fine enough, and chaining the two can lead to some fun platforming usage, though rarely is this required. The kunai and its powerups are also a fun projectile weapon and rather powerful to boot. The four different plasma types are mostly positive; the reflect plasma makes for some interesting puzzles, the exploding plasma has the highest attack and the exploding kunai are great, the ice plasma is actually a bit annoying but is used fairly interestingly in a few puzzles, and the fourth one is just completely useless and, worst of all, slow. There's also two summons; the bird is fairly useful and strong but the panther is just... bleh. Also a shield thing I never used.

Story-wise... I didn't understand the story at all until like 60% of the way through, and it's mostly inconsequential. Music's decent, not very memorable. Graphically it looks pretty good for a 2.5D game, lots of lush backgrounds and the visuals rarely get confusing. 

As far as exploration, there's a little bit, but most of the puzzles are simple and very few of the secrets and collectibles are too hidden at all. A lot of them require backtracking, too, a door you can't open or a puzzle you need the dash to solve or whatever not, but there's not really much mandatory backtracking or aimless wandering involved.

Boss fights range from "that happened" to "one really annoying attack but otherwise simple"; mostly, not really providing any sense of challenge. Honestly the only challenges this game presented were instances with a lot of stunlocking, which is... not a good thing, at all. I'm replaying on hard and while enemies seem to do a little more damage, the amount of health upgrades you can eventually get effectively nulls this effect.

But it's a fun enough game to play. I'm not sure I'd recommend it for $15, it's not too big and not too long, nor does it have high replay value, but on sale, sure, check it out if you want something pretty fun for that metroidvania fix.

review:
Strider es un metroidvania que cumple, pero que no aporta nada nuevo al género.
El combate es rápido y fluido y favorece alternar el uso de los diferentes poderes que vamos adquiriendo. Utiliza el recurso fácil de repetir jefes, lo que se hace algo repetitivo y en general no son nada originales además de estar algo desequilibrados: algunos resultán extremadamente fáciles mientras que otros son muy difíciles de esquivar.
En cuanto a la historía, es totalmente prescindible y los personajes no tienen carisma.
Pese a que es un juego corto (de 4 a 7 horas) no veía el momento de terminarlo y darlo por finiquitado de lo poco interesante/divertido que me resultaba.
No está mal, pero no me parece lo suficientemente bueno como para recomendarlo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078119443', 'num_games_owned': 579, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 771, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 554, 'last_played': 1447174352}
review:
Very fun concept and constant gameplay changes are what you can expect from this recreation of Capcom's classic side scrolling action adventure. Enemy variety, multiple weapon effects and upgrades go very good in combination with this very fast game. Controls are great and super responsive (I played on the controller), offer excellent character and situational control and for this reason its way too easy since enemies are pretty dumb and extremely easy to defeat, no exception! This game is super forgiving, even on the hardest difficulty setting where everything except for one or maybe two boss battles was just a mindless button mashing with barely any strategy involved which resulted in total annihilation of every enemy and numbness in my thumb. Its still pretty damn fun but feels to me like a wasted potential for a very good, tactical, hardcore action game. Maybe not the the most memorable game you will play but certainly a fun one.

Pros:
- Fun, fast & fluid gameplay
- Smooth and responsive
- New move every now and then
- Beautiful graphics
- Freedom of movement

Cons:
- Very easy and shallow despite amazing character controll and multiple weapons
- Story is so unimportant that I don't even remember it now, couple of hours after i finished the game
- Would be much better if it had a good OST

author: {'steamid': '76561197992208010', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 749, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 571, 'last_played': 1446969000}
review:
"You'll wind up with your teeth all grey!"
Seriously though, great game, but um, guys, coulda put like $100 and half a day into the end sequence, y'know?

Captures the 90's feel well, without leaning on the 90's aesthetic, which is, in this industry, a welcome approach.

Great dynamic gameplay, you really feel like some kind of super-ninja flicking through the air - even on the PC, where the controls are completely messed up if you're in a no-grav/object-gravity area. Probably worth using a controller with this one.
By the time you get to the end on normal difficulty, you realise a lot of the game is just button-mashing with your special abilities to get past the harder opponents, really brute-force, but there is some elegance to it.

The exploration is the best part of the game - it rewards it, and it's pretty much how you get more powerful, rather than simply following the provided pathways. There were a few areas I couldn't figure out, but still.

It's unfortunate that the ending didn't live up to the game. I mean, the last boss is  hard (not super-hard - like, not cave-story-hard), and even a 20 second end sequence would've been enough. But no. Straight to credits.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981706607', 'num_games_owned': 4129, 'num_reviews': 139, 'playtime_forever': 647, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 647, 'last_played': 1446938248}
review: This is a 2D Side Scrolling Metroidvania-light with extensive melee combat, and a little bit of backtracking. The combat options are surprisingly deep, and the character is fairly acrobatic, leading to lots of off-the-main road explorations.  Boss battles are challenging but fair (although there was one near the end I really had trouble with), and there's enough reward for going back through the earlier levels that I added probably two hours to my game time backtracking (and still only ended with 85% completion). The story is really slight, but that isn't the point of the game. There are some issues (only one save slot, and you can't go back to explore more after finishing the game; travel between sections for backtracking takes a lot more work than it should), but overall it's a fun, challenging action adventure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088300900', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 408, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 408, 'last_played': 1446680024}
review:
[h1]Strider[/h1]

Primero que nada nunca jugué el original Strider por ende este análisis está concentrado solamente en el titulo como tal, sin nostalgia del pasado. Strider es un juego rápido, caótico y que pone tus reflejos en prueba. Es un juego que me gusto como manejo el gameplay y sus mecánicas, sin embargo no es algo que no hayas visto ya en otros juegos del género. [b]Es totalmente recomendado[/b] para todos aquellos fans de los juegos de acción en scroll lateral, así como a todos aquellos coleccionistas de ítems y habilidades como un metroidvenia. Es un juego rápido que probablemente lo acabes en unas 5 horas dependiendo tu nivel de habilidad e inclusive si coleccionas todo te tardes unas 3 Horas más aproximadamente. Ahora, este juego no es para los que no disfrutan plataformers o acción rápida con reflejos importantes para ganar.

[b]Historia y Gameplay[/b]

La historia es simple y no te acordaras de ella, pero tampoco es algo que importe, el juego surge a flote por su gameplay y estética visual. El gameplay por otro lado es bueno, rápido, puedo decir que los controles pueden llegar a ser confusos solo en las partes donde se cambia la gravedad, pero eso ya es problema de la temática dentro del juego, nada de que preocuparse. Como en todo metroidvenia, tendremos mucho para coleccionar y explorar, conforme avance la historia tendremos nuevas habilidades con las que podremos abrir nuevos caminos en otras zonas. Un pequeño problema con el que me tope es que aparte de los jefes la “carne de cañón” con la que te encontraras es muy similar en la mayoría de las zonas y eso podría cansar a algunas personas, después de todo no es un juego largo y las habilidades nuevas dan variedad, así que no sería algo con lo que molestarse.

[b]Resumen – Opinión personal[/b]

Strider definitivamente fue estrambótico, rápido y divertido, sin embargo al no ser mi tipo de juego no lo disfrute por completo y me dejo un gusto agridulce momentáneo. No creo que lo vuelva a jugar, y tampoco creo que recuerde la historia o personajes. Sin embargo eso es algo muy personal, aparte que nunca hubo nostalgia por el personaje o juego. Si eran y aun son fans del género y del gran Ninja, éntrenle sin miedo.

review: Represents one of the dumbest missed opportunities I've seen in about 25 years of gaming: Make a "metroidvania" style game, don't offer any way to fast travel back and forth across the map. As soon as I discovered this, I quit playing the game. When your gameplay design is heavily based on backtracking to open new areas with new abilities, it's a serious design omission not to include some way to quickly move around the map.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024555785', 'num_games_owned': 1375, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 684, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 409, 'last_played': 1454952410}
review:
STRIDER™ é a prova de que o Remake de um jogo pode ser melhor do que o seu original. Um jogo de ação frenética do início ao fim. Confesso que não havia comprado o jogo antes, pois achava a movimentação das pernas meio truncada nos vídeos de lançamento, onde eu já imaginava: "nossa, deve ter sido feito nas coxas, usando apenas o nome de um jogo popular antigo, com uma engine que deve ser dura de se jogar"! Naaaada, a jogabilidade é fluida e corresponde bem às ações do personagem. Jogo digno de um clássico old school!!!

Os controles são simples e vão ficando mais complexos na medida em que seu personagem vai evoluindo e adquirindo novos poderes, que além de aumentar seu arsenal nas batalhas, servem para desbloquear novas áreas do mapa. Os gráficos são lindos, com cenários muito bem feitos, com profundidade em todos os ambientes externos, que vão encher os olhos de quem curte um belo visual em games.

Todas as batalhas com Bosses são épicas, cada uma com um estilo diferente de combate, onde a estratégia conta muito para se vencer o inimigo... se bem que na maioria das vezes o que faz a diferença é a quantidade de vezes que você consegue apertar o botão de ação no menor espaço de tempo possível.A exploração do ambiente, apesar de não ser linear, é bem fluída. O mapa em tela é tão bom e simples que se perder nos ambientes é uma missão quase impossível.

Enfim, STRIDER™ se consagra em não apenas reviver um clássico dos consoles old school, como também consegue inovar nos trazendo uma experiência totalmente nova no que se diz respeito à jogabilidade e ação frenética de combate. Vale muito mais do que eu paguei nele, com certeza. Além de tudo, possui conquistas Steam, além de vários colecionáveis durante o jogo, o que é muito bom, pois prolonga a sua vida útil. Remake nota 10!

review: I'm not a big fan of classic Strider but I really dug this game. It's a neat marriage of the fast-paced slashy gameplay of the original and a Metroid-esque structure. Really good game with great, fluid and fun controls. The only real complaint I have is that the bosses kind of suck. If you try to learn their patterns they'll often blow you away with powerful attacks, but if you just go right up to them and mash buttons you'll almost always win. It's also sort of easy but not insultingly so. Those points aside it's highly recommended, it's a quick, frenetic and thoughtful platformer that doesn't wear out its welcome.
