author: {'steamid': '76561197971355045', 'num_games_owned': 975, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 927, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 864, 'last_played': 1446152171}
review:
Strider: One of Capcom's late-80's arcade games. Also, a short-ish manga series that got obscured by it's video game counterpart. Starring Strider Hiryu - one of the best-known Capcom characters despite having only 4 games of it's own in more than 25 years time. One of those was an unofficial sequel, and one is the one I'm reviewing here.

This is a story about cybernetically enhanced ninjas iniltrating a futuristic Kazhak Soviet Socialist Republic (apparently the end of the cold war and the fall of the USSR never happened in this setting) filled with bizarre opponents to beat.
Why did it manage to stick around for so long ? 
Simple: Because running, sliding and cartwheel jumping at breakneck speed, while chopping up enemies with a plasma blade it is as awesome as it's weird. (Unless you're playing the unofficial sequel, in which case it's fun but nothing that special)

But how does a quarter-munching arcade game translate to a console-oriented downloadable title ?
Pretty well actually, unless you're looking for something that throws a handful of linear levels with disconnected visuals at you.

Instead, you get a Metroid style map, and you'll be travelling to and fro to complete your arsenal, opening up new paths based on that, and finally tracking down and beating the final boss. There's also exploration on the side to find powerups and bonus collectibles. (Collectibles also include levels for the challenge mode, but as far as I've kept track those are the ones that are placed in plain sight along the main route - you need to make an effort to miss those).
In keeping with it's arcade heritage, the focus is more on the platforming action than adventuring around though, and it more than delivers on that front.

The map is mostly well designed and the movement and fighting is all as fast and as furious as it ever was, including some subtle tricks to be had - certain enemies are much easier to defeat when you figure out which weapon to use against them.
Throw in a good number of boss fights with a few nice twists, and overall you get a good action platformer.
Oh, and it looks and sounds appropriately cartoony.

It's not without it's flaws:
- The plot is rather thin, and is barely enough to help build the sense of progression, let alone getting you really involved in the setting.
- The cutscenes lose points thanks to people's faces not being animated. It stands out really bad, especially since the rest of the animation is well done and fluid.
- Outside of the boss fights, the variety in enemy types is a bit low.
- And the game is on the easy side if you know what you're doing.

But none of those are dealbreakers, and the end result is a game that's easy to recommend to fans of 2D action games.

review:
This game is vastly superior to Bionic Commando Rearmed! Is it a good Metroid game? Yes. It has a decent amount of exploration, the graphics and music are also pretty good. Almost better than Other M. 

The negatives. The game has no lip sync. Production quality in the cut scenes/story is very low. Strider's movement is analog. This game is a port from the 360. that's why they went that route. The most negative thing I have to say is this game would be far better with dpad movement. I died a few times because of analog. If you like Metroid style games, but more action, less exploration, this is the game to get. Whatever game journalist that gave this game a bad review should be Kunai'ed. It's worth a buy!

author: {'steamid': '76561198013237122', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 633, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 970, 'last_played': 1446013495}
review:
Very nice platformer with some unique ideas. Great boss fights and progression system. Could not put it down for 5h40 minutes until I finished it on Normal. Tomorrow I start new on Hard mode.
You play as a ninja and start with a basic attack then you can acquire more moves by finding collectibles and defeating bosses. There is a sort of "elemental" mechanic to the weapon where you can channel a different form of energy through the sword or kunais (throwing weapon) and that changes their attack and each enemy is vunelrable to either a special move or a certain element or a combination of the two. The game also plays around with gravity making for very nice platforming unlike anything else.
The maps are huge and you can get almost anywhere on the map. I really mean everywhere, you can walk on walls, on the ceilings, you can go through floors or through the ceilings. You get a double jump and an additional boost attack getting in the end a sort of triple jump. The boost can also be used through a sort of gates transforming it superjumps that can be chained through multiple gates. Very fun.
The graphics are nice and animations look great.
The movement is fluid and so is the combat... with the exceptions of some moments in the end levels where enemies can chain freeze you and kill you without recourse (even on normal).
All in all a great game worth the price... I bought it for 1 dollar in a Humble Bundle :) but it certainly is worth far more.

review: Now I know who that guy from Marvel Vs. Capcom is. A pretty decent Metroidvania. Smooth graphics. Awesome upgrades. NIce aesthetic. The story is so awful I wonder if it was intentional. The problems I have with the game stem mostly from the progression (it felt somewhat open worldly, but it couldn't quite commit) and there are times where I feel like some bosses, stages, enemies, and parts were put in the game purely for padding to make it longer. author: {'steamid': '76561198096209195', 'num_games_owned': 1550, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 424, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 389, 'last_played': 1457112208}
review: This game.... I love this game. On normal difficulty it's just fun to blaze through the enemies and destroy everything in your path. This is being overpowered done right. On hard there is definitely a challenge, but is just as fun. Strider is actually really really pretty. The backgrounds are layered perfectly and give a feel that you're really tearing up a dystopian city. This game always has another trick up it's sleeve, I'm five hours in and STILL don't have most of the upgrades with a lot of locations still blocked off. Yeah, the scripting isn't that great and the story doesn't really exist, but that's not the point. The villians, the gameplay, the asthetics, and the visuals all come together to make this an amazing sidescroller, one of the best in the past few years

author: {'steamid': '76561197998051734', 'num_games_owned': 727, 'num_reviews': 144, 'playtime_forever': 387, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 387, 'last_played': 1445569028}
review:
On the whole Strider is a decently fun game. Whether it's "good" or not is more up to your personal tastes and tolerances. The game is a Metroidvania style action platformer with all the standards of backtracking once you find new power-ups and such. This is where the game excels, the areas are mostly well designed and you rarely scratch your head as to what you need to progress or get a power-up you see currently out of reach. The combat is very simple and actiony, with one primary attack augmented by your current Plasma power setting, a secondary attack which is rarely useful outside of it's special button combo uses (use as down-special in the air), three unlockable energy consuming specials which are of varying degrees of use as they are highly specialized, and later a dash attack which you will then spam like a crazy person.

So where is the rub? The voice work is atrocious, the story is completely insipid and you will never care about it. The game isn't exceedingly long which can be viewed as good since when you reach final area it locks you out of hunting specials and when you beat the game you cannot go looking again for completion. But the two biggest complaints, and why I almost don't recommend this game are such: the controls for the gravity sections (including final boss) are godawful to the point of frustration, and there are no invincibility frames. Your controls on the gravity balls section "try" to compensate for constantly changing orientation but instead fuck everything up and make it work. And the lack of invincibility frames in a game like this with so many projectiles and high damage attacks means you can, AND WILL, get stunlocked to death sometimes and certain attacks will do far more damage than you'd expect (or were probably intended. Ice Breath being the biggest contender).

Now, with that big wall of whining aside for the second paragraph, if you can tolerate a little jankiness and won't get too flustered during the gravity sections, on the whole the game is still undeniably fun. Just rampaging around like an unstoppable killing machine and slicing through enemies like butter is always enjoyable. Just as long as you don't care about it having an interesting story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008305545', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 108, 'playtime_forever': 720, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 720, 'last_played': 1445430426}
review:
Ne connaissant pas du tout les jeux précédents, je suis arrivé vierge sur cet épisode qui est une suite / remake / reboot ou un nouveau mot inventé pour l'occasion. Un scénario a le mérite d'exister : Un méchant très méchant veut dominer le monde, le détruire, se créer un empire et le héros n'est pas d'accord. Je dois avouer que j'ai survolé cette partie parce que les ennemis étaient trop occupés à vouloir me zigouiller quand le PNJ parlait et que les boss veulent juste ta peau ou te recruter parce que tu es trop fort.

 Le gameplay est au poil. Le personnage réagit fort bien, les pouvoirs sont intéressants et apportent de la variété tout au long de l'aventure. La structure en metroidvania est assez simple pour ne pas dire simpliste parce que toutes les améliorations à récupérer sont indiquées sur la carte. Au final, j'ai presque tout récupéré sauf les collectibles qui débloquent des artworks et les Striders (Je demande encore à quoi sert les costumes débloqués dans le jeu).

Les ennemis sont finalement peu variés et ne changent qu'avec l'apparition de nouveaux pouvoirs qui permettront de casser leurs boucliers ou de renvoyer les projectiles. Dans la majorité du jeu, ils sont évitables et ne rapportent qu'un peu de vie en les détruisant. A quelques moments particuliers, le jeu impose de les détruire pour avancer.

 La musique est plutôt discrète et ne m'a pas particulièrement marqué. Graphiquement, ça fait le boulot pour un jeu en 2,5D. Lisible et agréable sans atteindre des sommets tant dans la variété des décors que l'aspect purement technique.

 La durée de vie est variable selon votre volonté de faire le 100% ou non. Perso, j'ai fini le jeu en moins de 6H (Temps in game pas le temps rééllement passé en jeu) en récupérant pratiquement toutes les améliorations sur le chemin. Attention, il existe des points de contrôle et des points de sauvegarde qui sont matérialisés par une espèce de grille d'aération qui redonne la totalité de la santé. Pour bien comprendre, c'est à partir des points de sauvegarde que le jeu reprendra si vous quittez le jeu et non pas, des points de contrôle.
Mécanique old school qui peut surprendre la première fois surtout quand on a bien avancé dans un niveau ou battu un boss sans avoir pensé à aller sauvegarder après la victoire.

 Un petit point sur la difficulté me semble nécessaire. Je suis loin, très loin de me considérer comme un grand joueur et certains tests m'ont fait peur quand ils parlaient d'un jeu difficile voire hardcore sur certains passages. L'ayant fini, je peux affirmer que la difficulté est très loin du hardcore sauf un passage (l'ascension dans le dernier niveau qui peut être assez ardu) et je dirais même que le jeu reste très abordable avec de la vie très présente sur le parcours. Dès que j'ai débloqué les kunaïs explosifs, ça a fini en ballade de santé contre les boss (même celui de fin). Pour ma part, je suis souvent mort une fois contre les boss pour apprendre leur pattern (très facile à déchiffrer) et comment les éviter. Le second essai a très souvent été le bon. De là a y voir de la difficulté, faut pas pousser.

Je conseille de récupérer un maximum d'améliorations (Il suffit de regarder la carte pour les trouver) et d'abuser des kunaïs explosifs quand cela est possible.
 
Pour mon ressenti perso, je me suis éclaté pendant tout le jeu. Le jeu est très dynamique, riche et malgré des allers et retours un peu lourds, se permet de ne pas lasser pendant 6H (voire plus pour le 100%). Une bonne pioche pour ma part.

Au rayon défaut un peu pénible, mais non rédhibitoire : impossibilité de passer les dialogues quand on affronte les boss. Certains sont tellement inintéressants et longs que je martelais les boutons pour espérer trouver le bon sans succès.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024246936', 'num_games_owned': 4980, 'num_reviews': 194, 'playtime_forever': 887, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 887, 'last_played': 1445297742}
review: A frenetic Metroidvania-style remake of the original arcade game, this 2014 retelling of an action classic pretty much nails it. Strider lets you know it's no B.S. from the instant you start playing, showcasing the addition of more refined controls and level design to the breakneck action of Strider 2. The result is hectic, satisfying combat, smooth controls, and a big map full of hidden goodies. Nailing those essential elemets would have sufficed, but gorgeous visuals and a fleshed-out story (complete with voice acting for all the dialogue) really ice the cake. Still, it's not so perfect a game that you can expect it to go down as a modern classic in its genre. It's hampered just slightly by the addition of too many combat mechanics that do little more than overcomplicate what should have been more straightforward hacking and slashing. And while there's a large world to explore, this game has the most convoluted map I've seen in a very long time, which makes exploration and secret hunting a massive headache. Nonetheless, Strider's a great addition to a great series, and the developer's proficiency in all areas of its design make it an overall success.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008522548', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 174, 'playtime_forever': 292, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 209, 'last_played': 1446648866}
review: I got this game for Nostalgia. Having played and enjoyed the Original on NES I wanted to try this out. I was not disapointed. the combat felt a lot like the original but revamped. They have the same music as far as I can remember from the original. This new game has great background graphics that make it seem like you are in a 3D world even though its a simple 2D platformer. If you are interested and on the fence or have played the first game I would recommend trying this out.

review:
Primeras impresiones

Hace años que no le dedico tiempo a un videojuego de este genero. Como abuelete de este mundillo, han pasado infinidad de juegos y generos por mis manos. Ultimamente estaba viviendo cierta apatia por esta aficción, me cautivaban pocos horas y los acababa abandonando. Para mi habiendo crecido con las antiguas generaciones esto ha sido un chute de energia brutal. El tiempo que le he dedicado hasta ahora se me ha pasado volando, buena jugabilidad, muscia acorde y diseño y personajes muy chulos. Ahora mis espectativas estan muy altas, demasiado diría yo y espero que se cumpla. A la espera de pasarmelo deseo sinceramente que sea muy rejugable y que me mantenga enganchado durante mucho tiempo. El diseño de las fases y que aparentemente te deja revisitar zonas antiguas, al más puro estilo metroidvania, permite que la exploración sea un eje fundamental de este titulo.  Quizas como pequeña nota negativa, me cuesta mantener el ritmo jugando y enterrame de los mensajes que aparecen en pantalla de los malos. Lo dicho ampliare este texto.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042067857', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 263, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 152, 'last_played': 1488538315}
review:
Wow, this game is fantastic. Having played the original NES Strider and the Genesis Strider, I have to say this game is an absolutely fantastic reboot. It has the open-world feel of the original NES classic but with much better level (and graphic) design, and has the quality of color and atmospheric charm of the Genesis version but with far better view instead of the absurdly close-up shots of Strider Hiryu at the benefit of graphical fidelity. Besides that the game is clean and crisp. It's a joy to play and although at first it may seem too easy (there are difficulty options), that's just a nice way to lull you into the fact that this game requires a lot of strategy. While you start with these clunky combos and button-mashing slaying of any of the Kazakh guards you see, their tactics and yours have to evolve to suit the multi-levelled terrain, the new equipment and abilities both you and the enemies get, and your general skill. The better you get, the more the game begins to feel like a brutal ballet where Strider vaults over enemies and cuts everything in his path with effortless grace. The story is far better than that of its originals since now there's not only voice acting but it's actually got a cohesive and tangible plot this time that isn't arbitrarily sending you across the world in a weirdly specific set of locations with little backstory.

Overall, this is a very fun game. I really recommend it.

review:
Where do I begin?

I have played this game for an hour now and I have been nothing but impressed with this game so far, The consoles respond rather well, I really enjoy the whole Metroidvania style that this game has although from someone who grew up in the 90's and didn't play the original strider I am unable to comment on if this is how the game was back then.

Being a huge fan of hack and slash titles I feel right at home with the fast and energetic gameplay that this game has to offer, The game has tons of unlockables such as concept art and intel to health upgrades and new gadgets/abilities for Hiruu to use. 

The sound track is pretty cool from what I have heard so far and the boss battles are pretty decent too.

Overall I really did enjoy this game and will go on to probably enjoy it for many many more hours to go.

9/10

(At the time of writing this review this game is currently available in the Capcom Humble Bundle. Please google for more information.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198025329631', 'num_games_owned': 262, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 66, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 66, 'last_played': 1444899787}
review:
You can't change the keybindings. You're stick using the arrow keys, space, A, S, D, left CTRL and right CTRL.
It also didn't seem to register my PS4 controller, which works perfectly with other games such as MGSV.

Worse yet is that the level design so far has been terrible, and the clunky controls do nothing to help. You automatically grab on to any wall you touch, which would be fine if the game was designed around it. It is not. I constantly found myself grabbing on to random ledges while I was trying to avoid enemies.

Speaking of which, there are a lot of enemies to dodge. Not that they really pose any threat, mind you, at least not on Normal difficulty. As long as you're mashing the attack button, S, you're going to be fine. Shielded enemies must be guard broken with a charged attack, though, which really breaks the flow of combat. 

The graphics are nice, though, I'll give it that.

review:
Strider is a patron saint of the 2D arcade pantheon, that I have a little shrine to in my heart. If you remember how awesome the attract mode of the original looked back in '88, then you know how awesome this game will make you feel.

Fluid physics; graceful controls. The best Sci-Fi Metroidvania since Shadow Complex. I was deeply skeptical of this game, and it proved me wrong again and again. The swordplay is like a blend of SOTN and MMX - this is an incredible achievement. Well played, Capcom. For the first time in a decade, well played. 

High points: deflecting almost anything with a plasma sword. Dashing through enemies to cause explosions. Sending explosive kunai into mechs. Listening to the excellent effects work, and noticing callbacks to twenty years of gaming. Riding a holographic plasma panther.

10/10, would buy again at full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040295426', 'num_games_owned': 625, 'num_reviews': 130, 'playtime_forever': 624, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 624, 'last_played': 1443515654}
review:
I did hear good things about this game but was a bit skeptic. In my view it looked so generic on those trailers, so I thought "great, another generic looking 2.5D game to cash in on an old franchise". I must now eat my words. Thoughts. Whatever.

I only played two strider games, this and the one on Mega Drive. I never knew there were more until I recently googled it. So my review will occasionally compare this with the 'original' (well, it was a port of the original anyway so every time I say "original" I mean the Mega Drive port) and occasionally talk about the game as its own thing.

I loved the original game. Never finished it, as it was usually the case back then. But what really stuck with me was how different everything in the game felt from every other game. The east european backgrounds, the level where you could only see silhouettes behind lightning strikes, the crazy gravity sections. The game never ceased to throw new things at me as I made my way through the levels. Today is common place for a game to have movie-like soundtrack, with those orchestral arrangements that follow no specific tempo (in movies they follow the whatever-is-happening-on-screen-tempo) but, to my memory, Strider seems to be one of the first games that did it, and I loved it.

Why am I saying all this? because I think that feeling of playing a game filled with things I have never seen before was one of the defining features of the original and is the only thing missing from this reincarnation. Strider (now we are talking about the current game) doesn't take risks. It looks great but does nothing I haven't seen before. The few things that stand out it brings from the original, like the gravity mechanics, but not everything came and nothing ground-breaking was introduced. Granted, most of those features on the original are now commonplace and new Strider is in a tough position of showing newer things. But my point is that it doesn't take any risks in any aspect.

However, while Strider sits in its own comfortable zone, it does everything extremely well. The game plays much like the original, your attack is as fast as you can mash the button without so much as slowing you down and you can climb walls and ceiling. Only a million times better than the original and with much more depth. There are so many maneuvers, different attacks, different enemies, that make battles extremely deep and incredibly satisfying. At first you just run through the enemies mashing the button, but as the game progresses you will find this strategy lacking. Shielded enemies will start appearing, flying enemies, enemies with different attack modules and so on. So each combination requires different strategies and fast thinking. By the end of the game I was jumping, dashing, changing weapon type in mid-air, activating powers, all within a second. The combat is, without question, the star of the game.

The linear progression of levels was abandoned in favor of a metroidvania structure. And it definitely works. Metroidvania, open world, or any other kind of structure that has you backtracking all the time, works very well with action gameplay. It's also a well made map to explore and improve your character stats by finding upgrades. I think it was a nice addition, but the fact the combat is so good is determinant.

One last thing. I thought the difficulty curve was ideal. I mention that because I read people complaining it's too easy. I did beat the last boss on my first try but that doesn't mean it was easy, I did it while standing up and shouting continuously at the screen until the ugly thing was dead. Very exciting stuff.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971416468', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 116, 'last_played': 1516298764}
review: Fantastic run'n'gun action! Tight controls, a very clean and focused artstyle and huge levels that allow for exploration and experimentation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025283513', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 333, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 333, 'last_played': 1443329032}
review:
The general hack-and-slash gameplay is good, its fluid for the most part and doesn't stop unless you mess up. 

Bosses on the other hand blow, 4 of them are almost the same fight. 2 more are nearly identical. Every time you die to a boss you get to watch the same cutscene(s) again before getting another shot, including the one where you're told its name and title. You can skip some of the cutscenes with ESC but not the introduction ones. Writing is bland. 

Footsoldiers are palette swaps of eachother and sometimes carry shields or guns that inflict different status effects. With the exception of shield enemies none of them pose any challenge. Shield enemies require a charged attack which also doesn't pose any problems as long as you don't face a guantlet of them. 

Heavy enemies are also palette swaps of eachother and more powerful versions just mean they get an additional attack. They're damage sponges too, not much skill required just lots of jumping. 

Players have a meter which fills by damaging enemies and avoiding getting hit. Next to impossible to fill during normal gameplay until you get the deflection power up, bullet hell guantlets force you to use it if you want to fill the meter. Unfortunately enemies in later areas have increased health and the deflection power up doesn't do nearly as much damage as the flaming one. The flaming one of course doesn't deflect bullets so the Charge meter doesn't see much use. 

Really aggravating to get hit by electricity, you can often get stunlocked. Level design is decent but not overly complex. The ease with which you travel was clearly put ahead of complicated or intricate designs. Some hazards instantly kill you (sending you back to a checkpoint) and some do not, its unclear which is which until you find out the hard way. 

Sometimes fails to load an area if you move too fast (such as by using the dash rings) allowing you to get outside the level boundaries, freqently locking you out of the level proper when it occurs. 

Looks nice but looses frame rate during certain areas such as obstacle courses or areas with lots of electricity giving you a slow motion effect.

tl;dr: Running and slashing is fun, bosses and cutscenes suck.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996057322', 'num_games_owned': 256, 'num_reviews': 135, 'playtime_forever': 925, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 925, 'last_played': 1443142343}
review:
Strider ist ein sehr lineares Metroidvania, besonders am Anfang. 

Es dauert ein wenig bis sich dieses Spiel entfaltet, vorallem am Anfang sind die meisten Kämpfe pures Knopfkloppen. 
Die Schwierigkeitsgrade unterscheiden sich kaum ... also auf Schwer erleidet man wohl mehr Schaden und richtet selber weniger an aber wirklich merken tut man davon nicht viel.

Die Musik ist so lala, weder schlecht noch super gut.

Die Grafik ist nett.

Story ist nicht wirklich vorhanden, also man ist ein Strider (Ninja eher), welcher die Welt rettet und manche Leute stellen sich halt dann in deinen Weg.

Insgesamt hatte ich trotzdem viel Spaß mit dem Spiel aber es ist auch nichts, was man unbedingt gespielt haben muss.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028714052', 'num_games_owned': 321, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 829, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 829, 'last_played': 1436997177}
review:
A slashing dose of old school fun, this is a solid entry into the Strider series. I'll admit I've always been a big fan of the series so I'm a little biased. There's nothing ground-breaking here, but it is what it is, which is fast-paced hack-n-slash fun with a decent bit of platforming thrown in. That being said, there are some flaws.

You're not going to be held captive by a breathtaking and heroic ninja story. The boss fights are underwhelming. Enemy variety isn't anything special either.

But still, you're a f*kn ninja.

Strider controls silky smooth and his abilities make minced meat out of anything in your path.  The graphics are decent, with some vibrant colors, but the environment variety is a bit lacking.

As far as replay value, I'm just not seeing it here. There are some collectibles (outfits, concept art) which are pretty standard fare and don't really warrant another play through to collect all. 

I recommend snagging this game at a nice discounted price during a sale, it'll give you at least 10-15 hours of good ninja frolicking. If you're a big fan of the series, don't hesitate to add this to your collection.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968493816', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1675, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1654, 'last_played': 1449822013}
review:
Proper Brilliant.

The guys who made this game know Strider, they know what makes Strider good, and they know this better than Capcom, who failed pretty miserably with their micro-level Strider 2.  I loved Strider in the arcades, I knew it inside and out, and could clear it with one life.  I feared the remake, but I needn't have.

This is not the original Strider, it's more Strider meets Metroidvania, and it works.  It works so hard.  The first thing I did after completing the game (and it's not a short game) is immediately start a second game on hard.

It does so many things right.  The graphics are excellent just about everywhere, and never less than really good when it stumbles.  The game occasionally opens up to really big views giving everything an immense scale, and there's a real feeling of height when you jump blindly off some platforms.  Strider's movements are perfect, from running to climbing to slashing with his sword.  Sometimes you want to screenshot your game just because it looks so fun.

Strider makes frequent nods toward its history, sometimes the player will hear a sound effect taken from the original arcade game, and some levels are eerily familiar.

Cannot recommend highly enough.  It's among the best.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120242092', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 1872, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1752, 'last_played': 1432581214}
review: This game had so much potential that it almost hurts that it didnt live up to what it couldve been. The graphics and art style are generally amazing and i really enjoy how the plasma sword and scarf effects are rendered. The story in this game is quite literally non-existant. The story can be summarized in 1 sentence and that is "Strider must kill the evil dictator" and thats it. Now dont get me wrong Im all for the assassination mission style of story, but after that 1 sentence is told to you at the beginning of the game there is no more of it afterwards. The CastleVania genre has never been one of my favorites, but this game does a good job of scattering health and weapon upgrades consistently across the map. Now here are my problems with the game: First of all its is way too short. I got an achivement for beating it in under 4 hours ON ACCIDENT. I even got most of the upgrades and all the weapon mods. The final boss is also disappointingly easy and saying the ending is rushed is an understatement. You beat the final boss then BAM credits! overall id give this game a 5/10. This doesnt mean the game is bad though, its just average. I recommend you pick it up for $5 during a sale, but it is not worth full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029583207', 'num_games_owned': 209, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 649, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 649, 'last_played': 1434906991}
review:
Strider é um jogo de Ação com uma mistura de Hack'n'Slash, onde você joga como um ninja Strider e tem como objetivo acabar com os planos do vilão. É simples assim, não tem nada de drama e de profundo na história do jogo. A vários motivos de eu não recomendar esse jogo NO PREÇO CHEIO dele, mas vou apenas falar de dois.

O 1º, você aperta um botão durante o jogo inteiro, você estará apertando o botão de ataque em 99% do tempo, nada te impede de não atacar e você não tem motivos para não fazer, já que há vários inimigos pelos mapas, até mesmo contra chefes você não para de apertar e apenas fazendo isso você zera o jogo.

O 2º, o jogo é EXTREMAMENTE curto, mesmo se você perder seu tempo explorando, coletando itens, melhorando seu personagem, evoluindo suas armas e descobrindo alguns segredos a sensação que você tem é de que o jogo veio pela metade.

Falando das partes boas do jogo, ele é bem dinâmico, você realmente se sente um ninja escalando, lançando kunais e destruindo coisas, coletar itens e poderes para evoluir seu personagem torna o jogo mais divertido também. A história é simples e não há nada de marcante nela.

Como falei, não recomendo esse jogo em seu preço cheio, se quiser experimentar o jogo espere uma promoção de 50% ou mais, eu gostei do jogo, pois ele ainda passa aquela sensação do Strider antigo que também joguei, mas esse jogo novo parece que veio pela metade.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119808461', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 591, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 591, 'last_played': 1440996049}
review:
a sexy looking, fast paced and tight action platformer that stays true to the original, whilst doing its own thing.

straight off the bat: this game looks and sounds sweet, there is almost nothign wrong with the sound and visuals (minus the explosion effects at times looking like early stage work).
the platforming is tight and responsive (as it should be) and the combat is fast, responsive and fun (as it should be since you back track a bit for collectibles and story related things).

story takes a back seat, but i didnt really ind since the action and platforming an collectible hunting where all top notch and fun.

collectibles where actually worth looking for (they arent all that hard to find in all honesty) as they reward you with concept art and 3d renders of characters (that you can read about and rotate to see the details on them).

i did however throw in the towel at the final boss since he got a little too crazy for my eyes (he telports and talks alot and spams lots of annoying energy things that are a pain since it goes against the fast pace of the rest of the game and makes you sit and wait to atack him).

def worth checking out if you love action platformers (or liked the original). worth full price :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197979579922', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 477, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 477, 'last_played': 1441575242}
review: This is the definition of filler. It is fun to a point, it is not poorly made, and it is completely forgettable. The gametime is only five hours, which is really nice, you can complete it in two or three sittings, it's over before you get bored. The best feature is that the standard attacks are matched exactly to button mashes and there's no cap, so you can hit enemies and bosses literally as fast as you can mash the button. The worst feature is the voice acting and dialogue. For instance (mild spoiler, though come on, not really), when you get to the main boss, he says something along the lines of "Good, you have defeated all my henchman, I was meaning to get rid of them anyway for their insolence." So, the man is happy that someone... killed all his employees...? And every line is delivered in what might be described as "villain-fey," a cadence that wobbles around like a drunk clown on a bull-riding machine. This needs to stop, let's have some more respect for our villains, people.

review: 第一次接触的是2代，当初在玩了ps1上的出击飞龙2代久久不能忘怀，爽快的手感，漫画式的过场，强烈的气氛，有趣的关卡等实在让人难忘！过了这么久，以为capcom早就忘了这系列游戏的存在（实际上主角飞龙一直在其他游戏客串如mvc），没想到又出了个hd版，实在让人激动，hd版并没让我失望，保留了大量前作关卡设定还对战斗系统进行了大量强化，并加入了探索地图的要素，虽说是个慢热型，但战斗和探索的爽快型让我入迷！不过在我心里的地位还是不及2代的，感觉hd不及2代硬派吧，我也更喜欢2代那种气氛过场和一直线通关的模式及从中突然出现情况。

author: {'steamid': '76561198039614734', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 783, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 783, 'last_played': 1440857512}
review:
Un excellent revival !
L'idée de faire de cette pépite de l'arcade un metroidvania n'est pas si mauvaise.
On y retrouve bien les sensations et les seuls défaut seraient la map qui assez mal designé (du coup on a vite fait de si perdre dès lors qu'on veut traverser tout le jeu pour collecter les éléments inaccecible en debut de jeu) ainsi qu'une direction artistique qui offre un peut prêt toujours les mêmes decords.

Anyway, si vous étiez de ceux qui ont été marqué par les 2 opus arcade, alors n'ayez pas peur. Le jeu vaut le détour !

author: {'steamid': '76561197985969658', 'num_games_owned': 999, 'num_reviews': 685, 'playtime_forever': 631, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 631, 'last_played': 1440618883}
review:
6.5/10. 
I was greatly disappointed by this game. A game by my favorite studio and gotten good critic and user reviews. But this game is the definition of mediocrity and blandness. Most of the game is spent running around the same looking futuristic drab landscape, where every level feels the same. You fight the same 3-4 guys the entire game (they try fooling you by changing color of the soldier’s uniform to make you think it is a different enemy…..I wasn’t fooled), minus the occasional mini-boss. There are many boss fights, which is a nice change of pace, unfortunately the game uses the unfortunate trope of repeating multiple bosses. The levels are big open levels, although they are mostly empty and boring, and involve much backtracking. Most of what you will find by searching around is boring concept art nobody every cares about. 
The other thing you will find is upgrades. In order to gain any health or energy upgrades you need to scour every single level all over the place. You start with the smallest health bar I have ever seen in a game. Don’t play the game on hard because guys shoot multiple shots are once that are impossible to dodge, as you are the least elusive acrobatic ninja ever. All you can do is do a slow jump in the air where you spread out, or just run at people. There is a slide but it is slow, you do a spin first to do it, and you can still get easily hit while doing it. In hard guys do tons of damage, the health pickups give you almost no amount, and bosses take tons of retries. The terrible checkpoints mean you will have to start in areas before the boss and you will have to watch the crappy cutscene again. There is literally no story, and the small amount of dialogue/cutscenes involve terrible voice acting and models that (no joke) don’t open or move their lips when they talk. 
Then there’s the combat. It is the most boring ever. You literally just spam x (basic attack) as fast as you can while running at guys. The same is for the bosses. You have a charge-up attack that takes too long, and an upward slash that is completely useless. You never learn combos or anything special. By the time you learn a teleportation, or using other elements in your attack, its 2/3 done with the game already. The first 2/3 is just doing the same slash move over and over with every guy as fast as you can while you run straight at them. It became so boring and monotonous that I just tried jumping past guys to get to the next area. You can also be continuously juggled and killed with certain enemy combinations, as happened to me a few times. 
The platforming can be fun and inventive sometimes. You can climb and stick to walls, which is not common in many platforms. Unfortunately, more than not, it frustrates. It is very finicky and hard to control. There is a way to move fast up a wall, but not horizontally move across the wall, meaning it’s super slow. For some reason on platforms you can’t swing around from above to under it. If you try to jump from hanging below something you must drop first, then try to jump. Many times I would try to jump off the side of a wall and it wouldn’t let me detach. Other times I would try to jump over something and it would make me grab onto the side of it. 
The worst problem I faced, above all else, was the checkpoints. On multiple occasions I would exit to a new level, and see a “checkpoint” icon in the top right. I would then quit the game, and upon coming back see that the game didn’t save my progress and I was back at a previous level. In one occurrence I had to redo an entire boss fight, and go to the next level again, because the same hadn’t saved my progress. What game in 2015 doesn’t save progress AFTER A BOSS FIGHT AND THEN A LEVEL SWITCH?”!!?! This meant that I would never want to exit the game, because I never knew what it would save and what I would have to repeat. I couldn’t even count on beating a boss or starting a new level to mean it had saved, as those normal staples were apparently not part of the game’s save function. 
The game does have decent length, and I still BARELY recommend it because there are a few times where the game shines and the platforming is and inventive, or a boss fight is enjoyable, or some of the new powers you get later on, including throwing stars, teleportation, etc, are fun. I just don’t get why they have you get them so late in the game. The backtracking definitely frustrates as well. 

There are MANY other better options in the action/platformer genre, and use this only as a last resort if you've run out of other good ones to play. Wait for a sale, as 15 dollars is definitely too much to ask.

review:
This is a remake of an old Arcade game from 1989.
It's a fast side-scrolling hack & slash platform action game that's really fun to play.
I recommend playing this with an XBOX 360 controller.
The graphics and sound are great and suit the game.
The game supports the resolution 2560:1080 but only in 16/9 - ultra wide (21/9) is not supported - so there are black bars if you play on this resolution.
I took me 12 hours to finish - so this is a rather big game with a lot of things to explore and extras to unlock.
Replayability via higher difficulty and some challenge modes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104064363', 'num_games_owned': 713, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 830, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 761, 'last_played': 1456982975}
review:
This game is INCREDIBLE!!! 

Strider got it all right. Enemies come from everywhere, and you cannot rush your way through (most) of them, since the damage you take is a big worry here (I've read that in normal mode it is not that difficult, but I'm playing it on hard).

Aside from that, Strider has a exploration side that makes the game a lot more interesting. While it is more well done in the Metroid series, the way it was done here is completely satisfying, and it does motivate you to search all around the place for upgrades and skins.

A must buy!

author: {'steamid': '76561197977736559', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 216, 'playtime_forever': 474, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 474, 'last_played': 1440093492}
review:
Przygody Stridera Hiryu pamiętam jeszcze z czasów SNES'a (Pegassusa) i trzeba przyznać, że dość długo trzeba było czekać na kolejną odsłonę jednej z najbardziej charakterystycznych i lepszych platformówek od Capcoma.

Oczywiście po takim czasie graficznie gra bardzo się zmieniła, a do tego oferuje nowe miecze (a właściwie rodzaj plazmy klasycznego miecza), umiejętności i kunai'e do rzucania które zdobywamy z czasem. Muzyka była słabą stroną serii i tak też pozostało.

Jak na klasyczną platformówkę jest to dość udana gra. Jest akcja i bardzo fajna postać, która po ciężkich treningach jest w stanie sprostać każdemu przeciwnikowi. Grając zalecam używać pada, bo jednym słowem dużo się dzieje, więc trzeba poruszać się szybko i intuicyjnie.

Polecam.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089891604', 'num_games_owned': 334, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 969, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 969, 'last_played': 1439640879}
review:
Strider Hiryu is a character that I was first introduced to by watching the DEATH BATTLE! between him and Ryu Hayabusa from Ninja Gaiden. Hiryu was a badass, and (spoiler alert) defeated Ryu. So when I saw this game that I hadn't heard about before on sale and recognized it's main character, I decided to try it out, and boy, does this game have a lot to offer besides just a ball-busting protagonist! The story is set in the dystopian future of 2048 in the Russian city of Kazakh which is ruled by the oppresive Meio, a godly being who plans to wipe out humanity so that he can re-build the world in his own vision. You play as the previously mentioned Strider Hiryu, an extremly skilled ninja who must defeat Meio and restore peace to Kazakh and prevent apocalypse. The game is a Metroidvania-style hack-and-slash action-adventure platformer (wow that's a long genre name), where you use your plasma cypher to slay enemies, and as you progress in the game, you collect upgrades to your weapons, your health and energy and even new weapons and techniques. As one would expect from a Metroidvania game, these abilities and weapons are equally as useful in defeating enemies AND overcoming obstacles. The gameplay is flawless, which is mandatory for a game with such gameplay principles, and it is unbeliavebly satisfying and fun. The graphics look really nice during gameplay. When the charactermodels are zoomed in on during cutscenes, they don't look as good, but it is of little concern. All design choices are very good and everything really possesses the grim science-fiction feel the developers went for. The music, while not very memorable, is atmospheric and fitting, and it warmed my heart to hear some wobbles among the ambient noises and musical tones. Voice-acting, story, characters etc. is good, but again, not very memorable. Even on medium difficulty, the game presented quite a challenge, but it is forgiving, which I think is important in a game like this. All in all, if you like platform games, hack-and-slash games, or Metroidvania style games and play for the gameplay more than anything else, I recommend Strider with all my heart. And I also recommend playing with a controller. I haven't tried to play without one, but the thought is frightening.
9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198075269622', 'num_games_owned': 735, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1605, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1605, 'last_played': 1448638066}
review:
从本作开始接触《出击飞龙》系列游戏，说不出什么圈内人的装逼话语。
我只能说这个游戏简直帅得燥热。
 
操作的手感自然是一流，手残人士也能很舒服地在墙上装逼。
攻击的方式对于其他同类游戏而言比较特殊：没有冷却时间且不限速度。
[i]玩过恶魔城月下夜想曲的玩家可能这样解释会比较明白：有一把神器，江湖人称[spoiler]有限真空刃（不是无限哦）[/spoiler] 。[/i] 
这也就意味着，只要你的手速够快（或者你的手柄有Turbo），BOSS什么的都跟泥一样削。
这样的攻击方式也能配合音效和拖慢实现略有风味的的打击感也真是不简单。
[i]不理解的话可以想像一下用电风扇打纸片能有多大的打击感？[/i]

游戏的音乐其实有点随意，因为（感觉）所有地方的曲目基本都是共通的...听来听去就那几曲。
并没有让人印象深刻的曲子。
而且游戏的音量稍微有点小了。

若是提到难度，我就要说了。
赶路远比BOSS难，真话。
完成了四小时通关的成就之后你会觉得人生焕然一新。

---------------------------------------------------------------------------

其实，这个游戏有一个原因让我不想给推荐。
那就是这游戏居然没有继承这一说法，也就意味着，收集全物品和全能力的意义就是在主菜单里欣赏和获得成就，并不能带到下一周目。
我花了整整十个小时在一周目总BOSS前不肯通关就为了收集完成率，结果通关后重开高难度一看全部归零。
[strike]我的爱，请全部带走。[/strike]

author: {'steamid': '76561197969372390', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 99, 'playtime_forever': 712, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 712, 'last_played': 1439537035}
review:
Strider 2014 is a Metroidvania and it's a pretty good one at that.  Fluid movements, great graphics, LOTS of bosses and plenty of hidden weapon upgrades and collectibles throughout this adventure.  There's over 10 bosses to take on, but most of them are push-overs.  While there's always plenty to do while exploring the game doesn't really pick up until the last 30% of the game.  The game is a little slow at the beginning, but that's to be expected for a Metroidvania.  By the time you reach the end the game's set at a fast pace and you're not ready to hang it up.  

The map system sucks though.  Trying to find out where you need to go to find that missing health upgrade, large hp canister or other weapon upgrades is near impossible.  If  you select a different part of the map other than where you currently are it gets cut off and you can't see it.  Another nuisance is when the bosses are talking to you (for the Story) and you're fighting the dialog is in the way of the gameplay.  You'll simply take damage due to the fact you can't see it coming.  There's not a lot of enemies either.  Yes, there are tons of bosses, but the random enemy gets recycled throughout the game and the only differences are colors.  

The game is very good though and very much worth it for anyone that likes a good Metroidvania.  Grab it on sale.  You won't be disappointed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132792574', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 319, 'playtime_forever': 1912, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1769, 'last_played': 1439484051}
review:
PUT SAVE POINTS AFTER PRE-BOSS CUTSCENES, NOT BEFORE

That's my main criticism, although that's not all I have to say. This is my first Metroidvania game (if you don't count Terraria - sort of), and I guess I was expecting a bit more. The curve of mobility upgrades could have been a bit more developed, and the combat seems to take up more of the focus. That's not really bad, but I feel like I was expecting something different. Also, back on the subject of saves, they're way too far apart here. Iteration time is NOT a hard concept. Even better, put in quicksaves, which no one ever has ever objected to.

For what it is, the game is very good. The animations are nice, I love the art style, and the combat is entertaining, and can bear being repeated several billion times as you try to defeat the boss fight right after the current room because there's no save between room and boss (seriously, this is elementary stuff). I was just expecting something different. On the bright side, however, this has made me even more excited for such games as Super Metroid or Castlevania: Symphony of the Night. I think this is a genre I can really get into.

P.S. I bought this game purely on Yahtzee's recommendation. He represents it well, and everyone should watch Zero Punctuation.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971301516', 'num_games_owned': 2042, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 941, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 939, 'last_played': 1474664190}
review:
While I did enjoy this game, it comes with a few things that to me felt like grievous issues.

Cons:
Camera - The camera is almsot always fine, but in a few boss fights it zooms in and out at horrible times and pulls away from the boss to follow Strider.  It's even worse around gravity globes you can run on, which are their own irritating issue that just becomes more annoying.

No invincibility frames - A few normal enemies and a few boss attacks have their entire gimmick around this and squeezing as much damage as possible in one volley or chain stuns.  Easily a quarter or more of a fully upgraded health from one of those, or just getting pinballed between 2-4 enemies for a few seconds while you wait for the chance to have control again.

Other smaller issues involve the final tower level being a boring difficulty spike and that wall climbing has you suddenly mantle up and over from a bit too generous of a distance.  Also there's an entire level where you run against the wind meaning you walk slow and jump short distances; meh.


The Good:
Movement is amazing.  Running, dashing, jumping, and sliding around while slashing everything in sight is solid and the best part of the game.  Worth a playthrough alone just to hop around and hit stuff really.


The Metroidvaia aspect feels tacked on with four flavors (ice, fire, reflect, magnetic/ranged) to the dash, slash, and kunais, but overall is fun while you do a little backtracking here and there and have a dramatic pose animation that plays each time you pick up an upgrade.  Also ignore the story.  Not because the story is really bad, but because it's just in the way of the fun and makes deaths to bosses involve watching another boring taunt speech.

For all of the negatives, I do still recommend this game oddly.  It's that much fun to play when the quirks aren't getting in your face.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020425915', 'num_games_owned': 157, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 2646, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1812, 'last_played': 1562518606}

Recomendadíssimo!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970472466', 'num_games_owned': 847, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 513, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 513, 'last_played': 1438635290}
review:
Trataré de escribir el análisis de Strider si siento los dedos, después de haber acabado justo el juego en este momento.
Strider es un juego que cumple su función. Arrasa con todo lo que pilles por delante, salta, haz combos, usa las "magias" y a medida que se acerca el final, todo eso se hace al mismo tiempo. 
Strider trata de ser un juego ágil, rápido y frenético (a medida que te acercas al final) en cuanto a jugabilidad, no puedes descuidarte o te acribillarán a tiros los enemigos o las torretas o las tanquetas o todo junto al mismo tiempo mientras te congelan, queman, empujan, bombardean. 
Además de todo ello, da la libertad para volver a antiguas zonas y poder desbloquear cosas que estaban antes fuera de tu alcance. Suelen ser mejoras de vida, energía, de las habilidades de plasmas o nuevos trajes.

Es un juego que recomiendo si alguna vez te han gustado los juegos tipo arcade y de arrasar con todo lo que se te ponga por delante.

Pros:
- Ágil y rápido
- Gráficos más que decentes

Contras:
- Enemigos con habilidades repetitivas


Es posible que este juego no le guste a la gente que no sean muy ágiles con los mandos y los movimientos de los personajes.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990198869', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 1184, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 990, 'last_played': 1692541019}
review:
What's good with this game?
Explore - there's tons of hidden items in this game which unlock upgrades, artwork and more.
Challenge - Its not to hard and not to easy, well balanced... accept facing Solo. I hate Solo. Who is Solo? Play the game and you will see.
Music - perfect.
Effects - comical effects that feels right.
Graphic.
Navigation - you will never feel lost in this game.
 
What's bad with this game?
Voiceacting in cutscenes - it's so bad that you will turn it off... 
Story - If you haven't played Strider before, you wouldn't understand what is going on.  

If you like Mega Man then you will like Strider.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968070055', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 404, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 404, 'last_played': 1437909848}
review:
High octane fueled game. The story makes zero sense but you just keep moving forward. The combat is pretty great. There are some cool nods to the older Strider games and I think this is a great modern version of it.

The main downside is that the difficulty ramps up quite hard throughout the game and if you don't go out of your way to collect upgrades that are hidden throughout the levels you will run against a boss that you can hardly damage and that does way too much damage to you. I basically ended up cheating since I didn't want to go back and collect all the upgrades.

So keep in mind that you are supposed to explore the levels even though the game kindof encourages you to go guns blazing through all the levels.

author: {'steamid': '76561198195843941', 'num_games_owned': 449, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 774, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 774, 'last_played': 1437692909}
review:
Com uma jogabilidade bem responsiva, Strider consegue ser um metroidvania essêncial para amantes do gênero. 
A campanha gira em torno de 4-6 horas, tendo um mapa imenso para ser explorado. E a dificuldade é razoável, nada que algumas tentativas não faça você vencer qualquer chefe. Já o enredo, inicialmente você é jogado com quase nenhum informaçao, e com o desenrolar da historia você começa a entender do por que estar ali.

Indico o jogo, principalmente se você quer algo para jogar um dia inteiro e não se preocupar mais.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987083063', 'num_games_owned': 1193, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 781, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 699, 'last_played': 1437499916}
review:
Da amante dei metroidvania, lo consiglio, perchè il gioco è valido, ma oggettivamente poteva essere fatto molto meglio.
Graficamente carino, ma le location sono spesso ripetitive e davvero a volte si fatica a capire in quale zona si è. C'è di meglio e c'è di peggio anche in 2D.
Sonoro discreto. Ci sono alcune canzoni classiche della saga, ma non so se è un problema mio, ho trovato il volume un pò basso. In generale, la qualità delle musiche è di medio livello.
La giocabilità soffre di alti e bassi. I combattimenti e il gameplay in generale, sono molto divertenti e soddisfacenti, ma a volte il pg non risponde bene ai comandi, e si ha una sensazione generale di poca precisione...che in un gioco in cui ci sono varie fasi platform, non è un difetto da poco.
Come longevità siamo leggermente al di sotto della media del genere. 8 ore per finirlo quasi al 100% a livello medio, senza grosse difficoltà, a parte 2-3 boss.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059647673', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 1014, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1014, 'last_played': 1437418561}
review:
Excelente jogo! Honraram a memória do antigo Strider.

[b]Gameplay[/b]: plataforma com ação em [u]alta velocidade[/u], mas ao mesmo tempo permite que se possa explorar todo o cenário em busca dos itens de upgrade. Resumindo, se for cauteloso, perderá muito sangue; se for para cima, terá melhores chances, especialmente porque com o avançar do jogo, o número de ataques diferentes aumenta muito!

[b]Pontos positivos[/b]:
[list]
[*] O controle responde muito bem e os golpes se emendam, quase como um combo (se for jogar no controle, recomendo usar três dedos para manejar os botões A, B, X e Y e se possível, trocar as funções do Y com a do RB).
[*] Ataques bastante variados, indo de [spoiler]reflexão de balas inimigas ao congelamento (ou explosão) dos adversários passando por projéteis teleguiados, explosivos ou que ricocheteiam, [/spoiler], entre outros (sem citar os especiais).
[*] O sonho para todos os amantes de plataforma: [spoiler]pulo duplo + um pequeno teleporte = pulo triplo![/spoiler]
[*] Os chefões possuem padrões repetitivos de movimento (como nos jogos antigos), o que os deixam até fáceis, mas afastam a frustração, mantendo o clima de velocidade e diversão.
[*] Os itens escondidos são fáceis de achar e os ganhos proporcionados realmente fazem diferença.
[*] Visual muito legal, especialmente o dos cenários.
[*] O som não irrita.
[*] Dá pra terminar em menos de 10 h, se for direto. Se parar para explorar tudo, umas 16 h ou menos. Em outras palavras, diversão sem mofar na biblioteca de jogos do Steam.
[/list]

[b]Pontos negativos[/b]:
[list]
[*] deveria haver uma maneira mais rápida de se locomover para os estágios já finalizados.
[*] falta uma indicação no mapa de para qual estágio determinado corredor irá levar.
[/list]

Esse jogo vale a pena. Diversão garantida para jogadores do tipo killer, explorer e, um pouco, achiever, já que as conquistas são meio que óbvias.

review:
Perso j'en attendais pas grand chose, mais au final cette version 2014 de Strider fut plutôt agréable. On se retrouve donc avec un jeu d'action légèrement inspiré de Metroid, les combats sont nerveux et on avance de façon progressive avec un personnage de plus en plus badass.

Entre le scénario principal, la course aux collectables divers et variés, la durée de vie est assez bonne pour ce genre de jeu (compter 10h maxi pour tout faire), par contre j'ai trouvé la difficulté générale assez faible (du moins sauf si jouer en hard car là ça devient plus complexe).

author: {'steamid': '76561197977835630', 'num_games_owned': 514, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 495, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 495, 'last_played': 1437262128}
review:
This incarnation of Strider is a Metroidvania-style game with it's focus on hack n' slash platforming. The music is decent, the action is solid, and the controls are sharp (an absolute requirement for this sort of title). The voice acting is so-so but that isn't what you're really here for, is it? 

Sorta wish they'd have kept the original cipher sounds, but ultimately I don't mind the update. 

Total gameplay time is around 6 hours. There's an achievement for finishing in less than 4. 
A controller is definitely recommended for this title. 

For: Strider series fans, people that like slicing things to bits, anybody who thinks cyber-ninjas are the future, action and platforming fans.
Not for: The easily frustrated, people who hate backtracking for pickups, people who hate 2d platforming.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055553431', 'num_games_owned': 7573, 'num_reviews': 209, 'playtime_forever': 747, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 747, 'last_played': 1436980734}
review:
[h1] Remake fast and furious del cabinato ’89, con una pennellata di backtracking, incorniciato con uno stile grafico futuristico contaminato da elementi dal medioevo asiatico. [/h1]

Storia: impersoniamo un ninja in quel di Kazakh City, la cui struttura politica pare rimembrare un satellite U.R.S.S. ma di matrice distopica; la città è tiranneggiata dal Grandmaster Meio, di cui ovviamente ci dovremo occupare. Non ci viene raccontato molto, sappiamo dell’oppressione e di esperimenti meta-scientifici, perpetrati da mistiche figure protette da mercenari a sangue freddo…per non farsi mancare nulla anche qui ritroviamo delle sorti di zombie, che personalmente avrei evitato d’inserire soffermandomi più sulla caratterizzazione sci-fi.

Gameplay: veloce adrenalinico sin dalle prime fasi, rese complicate da una un barra della salute risicata: dovete muovervi velocemente -sfruttando anche la verticalità degli scenari grazie al rampino- verso gli avversari, a testa alta, deviando o eludendo proiettili e attacchi melee. Le abilità sono ben diversificate nella forma, anche se il numero non impressiona: l’attacco a breve distanza è affidato allo Cypher, una speciale spada; dalla distanza intervengono i Kunai, delle sorte di dardi. Ma per entrambe le tipologie esistono 4 varianti (congelamento, rimbalzo, esplosive e magnetiche) a seconda del potere imbracciato; evidenziato stilisticamente da una sciarpa, stilizzata al neon e muta colore, accoccolata al collo di Hyriu. Esistono anche 3 abilità speciali (d’attacco e difesa), anch’esse stilisticamente ricercate, il cui uso devastante è limitato da una seconda barra, d’energia, similmente suddivisa in tacche.
Di notevole efficacia la “catapulta al plasma”, una sorta di brevissimo “teletrasporto” in tutte le direzioni, che se effettuata dopo il doppio salto consente di innalzare ulteriormente l’altezza raggiungibile.
Le tacche delle 2 barre, poteri e abilità speciali sono centellinate nel corso dell’avventura e non tutti questi elementi li otterrete nella loro massima espressione, a meno che non vi dedichiate all’esplorazione. Ecco che entra in gioco il backtracking –alcune zone saranno accessibili solo se appreso un particolare potenziamento- coadiuvato dal respawn selvaggio: attenuato dal recupero parziale della salute abbattendo i nemici. Personalmente non vado matto per il respawn, ma va sottolineato come nella fase avanzata sarete molto più forti, quindi potrete semplicemente scappare, senza attaccare battaglia con i fastidiosi sottoposti. Vi consiglio di posticipare dunque l’esplorazione fino al momento precedente l’inizio dell’atto finale.
Per i completisti, poi, ci sono: costumi, bozzetti, e sfide da recuperare per una immedesimazione maggiore; tuttavia questi elementi risultano evidenziati sulla mappa, una volta scoperto ogni anfratto.

I.A: la difficoltà è alta anche se inferiore al predecessore. I pattern d’attacco avversari sono semplici per la maggior parte dei molti boss a disposizione, anche se alcuni personaggi brillano di luce propria. Se fosse stata riposta la stessa cura per la caratterizzazione dei combattimenti anche per i restanti avversari, ci saremmo trovati davanti ad un’eccellenza. 
Se con i normali nemici e mini boss (mach poco raccomandabili) il titolo assume le vesti di un hack ’n’ slash; la situazione con alcuni veri Boss muta drasticamente: bisogna studiare l’ambiente circostante, sfruttando ripari; carpire le debolezze dell’avversario, scegliere il momento giusto per attaccare e muoversi molto…in queste circostanze l’approccio alla rambo porterà solo a morte certa

Comparto grafico: gli stage sono ben diversificati tra loro, meno al loro interno. La paletta cromatica vira bruscamente fra interni ed esterni, regalando a volte un colpo d’occhio impressionante, intervallato però da stanze decisamente asettiche. Dove le pennellate al neon non si estendono arriva una prospettiva in secondo piano, in grado di allargare gli spazi e donare vitalità e spazialità, corredata da effetti in cel shading. Si passa così dai sobborghi grigi ai caldi terrazzi e guglie della zona più ricca fino a recinzioni al plasma, fortezze terrestri e spaziali e…scoprite il resto da voi, non voglio rovinarvi la sorpresa :)

Comparto tecnico: gli elementi scriptati per pulviscolo ed esplosioni sono di buona fattura; ottimi gli effetti riflessi, con marmi lucidi nella pavimentazione di zone lussuose. Le texture sono buone in-game meno nelle cut-scenes dove il numero dei poligoni e la definizione dei contorni viene meno. Eccellente l’uso della telecamera dinamica che non è mai fastidiosa pur prendendosi delle libertà per donare un effetto cinematografico all’azione. I controlli sono precisi e la fluidità è massima, con frame granitici.

Comparto audio: doppiaggio discreto, le battute non brillano per arguzia. Effettistica più che sufficiente. Si sente la mancanza di una colonna sonora più incisiva; tipica di questo genere di produzioni.

Commento finale: Strider è un Action in 2.5D dal ritmo veloce con un’anima arcade, immediato nelle meccaniche, ma da non prendere sotto gamba. L’impegno per modernizzare un classico è di solito una sfida ardua, ma Double Helix ha centrato l’obiettivo; magari fossero così tutti questi progetti. Il team, però ci lascia sul mercato Pc, accettando di lavorare alla console di Amazon. Auguri per le prossime opere.

review:
Sanics the name, speeds my game. This game has lots of speeds.

10/10


Actual Review:

So i bought Strider when it was on sale, not exactly knowing what i would get myself into as i haven't played the first one on SNES and it seemed good looking enough to buy it.

Basically, what you get is a fast-paced Metroidvania game with somewhat advanced graphics, a simple plot and cool artstyle with everything set in the near future.
As always in Metroidvania games, you start off pretty weak and overall without much tools, the further you progress, the more you get. What's interesting is the fact that you need to adapt to different enemies on the fly, use dashing, kunais and your special ability to get rid of enemies or just do super cool stuff in general and most of that in one fight, kind of my style especially that you can attack as fast as you can push dat button (which can result, more often than not, in boss fights not even lasting 10 seconds)

That's pretty much everything i have to say here as it's a solid game and i liked it very much, definitely worth the bucks (of course it feels kinda short if you rush through in under 4 hours for the achievement but still) and i recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198127629068', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 3054, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2995, 'last_played': 1440271295}
review:
Eu realmente adorei este jogo! 

Para quem viveu nos anos 80 e sofreu jogando Strider para Mega Drive, a CAPCOM fez um ótimo trabalho de repaginação do jogo: novos upgrades e ataques e aquele visual futurista que continua enchendo os olhos!

As fases são muito bonitas, gráficos estilosos e várias cutscenes e diálogos, que aparecem à medida em que você vai avançando e muitos deles não estragam a continuidade do jogo.

O áudio não é uma maravilha, mas quem se importa com isso quando está se divertindo? A jogabilidade está ótima, a movimentação e o jogo é bem fluído. Continua sendo um jogo de plataforma (2D) com cenários e objetos 3D. Os cenários têm planos de fundo com mais locais, acessíveis por meio de viagens através de uma águia ou de um tigre voadores - que são encontrados em locais específicos e sinalizados no mapa.

O jogo é rápido, não é difícil demais (ainda bem, né?); os controles são bem ajustados e os upgrades os tornam ainda melhores. Com os upgrades, você conseguirá encontrar novas áreas dentro dos cenários.

Vale a pena se esforçar para aumentar a barra de vida e de energia dos especiais, já que eles dão uma ajuda gigante para terminar o jogo logo - que também não é longo e nem curto demais, especialmente se você se interessa de explorar os cantos e procurar completar os objetos colecionáveis.

Os itens que você vai encontrando podem trazer: novos personagens Strider (praticamente só muda a cor de seu personagem); dados sobre personagens e a história do jogo, rascunhos de arte conceitual que foi empregada no jogo. E tem dois modos extras de jogo desbloqueados por encontrá-los escondidos nos mapas: corrida por melhor tempo e derrotar inimigos contra o relógio.

Os personagens, assim como os cenários e objetos, têm um estilo futurista, lembrando características de arquitetura russa e chinesa. Não há opções de idiomas - achei um dos pequenos contras. 

RECOMENDO, especialmente se estiver barato! Eu gostei tanto que terminei o jogo quatro vezes em seguida, consegui 100% dos colecionáveis e platinei... Fui injusto com os outros jogos que ainda nem joguei, né? Bom mas esse é tão legal que eles ficam pra outra hora.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064976519', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 988, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 988, 'last_played': 1436228971}
review:
Strider es un juego bastante bueno, mucho mejor de lo que esperaba. Llegué a pensar en un momento que se trataba del típico juego “B” barato y mal hecho para aprovechar el nombre de la franquica dada la recepción que tuvo, pero me alegra que no fuera el caso.

Strider no es perfecto ni tampoco intenta serlo, no busca ser el típico juego para babear en los trailers de youtube ni vivir de memes por sus grandes cinemáticas o filosofías baratas, no busca nada de eso, pero ninguno de sus problemas daña la experiencia del juego solo merman la calidad final de lo que pudo haber sido si le hubiesen puesto algo más de amor y cariño al juego.

Hay dos grandes problemas en este juego: el primero es su mapa cuya organización es bastante confusa, llegando a molestar una vez que empiezas a retroceder para abrir nuevas zonas (backtraking), cuesta mucho distinguir hacia donde ir para llegar a determinado lugar porque simplemente el mapa es raro e innecesariamente enredado (y digo innecesariamente porque los escenarios son bastante básicos para recorrer pero todo cambia al mirar el mapa).

Y el segundo gran problema es que reciclan muchos enemigos. Double Helix se preocupa mucho no volver repetitivo y tedioso al juego y lo consiguen, pero no totalmente. Lo que el diseño del juego consigue los enemigos reciclados no. Muchos soldados iguales (con distinto grado de dificultad pero iguales a fin de cuentas), muchos minibosses iguales que salen en diferentes lados y algunos jefes se repiten de modo muy absurdo. Por ejemplo: hay unas chicas ninjas que toca enfrentarlas una a una, y luego a las dos juntas, luego sale la tercera y luego las tres juntas… Aunque también hay que destacar otras excelentes peleas con jefes únicos. Insisto, el juego no es para nada repetitivo pero molesta un poco ver el excelente ritmo y velocidad que lleva el juego para encontrarse cada cierto rato con casi los mismos conocidos.

Poco más que eso lo puedo criticar al juego, ese hecho de que Strider pudo haber sido una maravilla, con mejores efectos, más variedad de enemigos y algo más de presupuesto. Pudo haber sido un Bayonneta en 2D pero se queda en un Ninja Gaiden + Super Metroid sin llegar al nivel de excelencia de ninguno de estos dos casos. El juego es rápido desde el primer segundo en que empiezas a moverte y no dejas la acción hasta que termina, como fanático de Marvel Vs Capcom me encanta el hecho de que el personaje se sienta casi igual que en el juego de lucha.

Lo recomiendo 100% y no tengo idea del porqué tiene tan poca “publicidad” este juego, seguro salió en un tiempo donde las "experiencias cinematográficas" y los scripts guiados eran lo que se consideraba “gameplay” y no la libertad total que brinda este juego.

review:
あのストライダーが帰ってきた！

従来のストライダーシリーズを知ってる人に分かるネタが盛り込まれているのもポイント。

author: {'steamid': '76561198061063257', 'num_games_owned': 831, 'num_reviews': 344, 'playtime_forever': 309, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 309, 'last_played': 1436087023}
review:
昔、アーケードで人気を博した
ストライダー飛竜シリーズの新作。
カプコンとは書いていますが外注で
悪名高いLOST PLANET3の開発スタッフが関わっています。

～　初期のアクション性　～
・攻撃(八方向)
・ジャンプ
・壁張り付き
・スライディング

最初はblade kittenのアクションを
減らした程度の動きしか出来ませんが、
ストーリーを進めれば、二段ジャンプやクナイ攻撃、溜め攻撃など
様々なアクションが追加されていきます。


プレイをした感想ですが…個人的には
褒められる点を探す方が難しい作品でした。
今作からメトロイドの様な探索要素も追加されたのですが
探索の為にMapを広くしたせいで
移動に時間がかかってスピード感が無くなり、
過去に評価されたアクション性も
探索要素の弊害で大味になってしまい
合体事故を起こした感じになっています。

その他にも
・似た様な風景が多い
・イライラ棒の様なギミックが多い
・BGMが地味
・SEに迫力がない
・カメラワークが悪い
・敵の種類が少ない
・ボスの攻撃パターンが少ない
・雑魚敵が硬いorギミック以外で倒す意味があまりない

ゴリ押し前提のゲームデザインで
基本ボタン連打で敵の攻撃を被弾しながら
突進で進むか、ジャンプで無視しながら進むのが早いです。
そこら中に溢れるほどの
回復アイテムが落ちているので立ち回る必要がありません。

無双系の爽快感重視アクション？
それを意識してデザインしているのかと思えば
敵は一人一人が硬く、また
溜め攻撃や火属性でないと倒せない雑魚が混ざっていたり
触れたら戻されるギミックがあったり
爽快感を阻害する要素が満載です。

カメラが勝手に寄って
敵が見えなくなる事もあります。
敵はお構いなしに飛び道具を撃ってきます。↓
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=475248761

無双系爽快アクションでもないし
攻撃を見切って戦う立ち回りアクションでも無し。
探索アイテムもゲージの量をUp系ばかりで
ワクワク感が今ひとつ。
何を作りたかったのか、制作者の心が見えない作品です。

そこら中にやたら回復アイテムが設置してあるのは
制作者もテストプレイをして
微妙だというのに気付いたんじゃないでしょうか。
修正するには納期に間に合わないから
クリアだけ出来る様にしておいた感を個人的に感じます。

ニンジャで遊びたい人以外にはお勧めできません。
