author: {'steamid': '76561198067834171', 'num_games_owned': 1306, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 765, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 710, 'last_played': 1435442666}
review:
Strider – ремейк одноименного платформера 1989г. от фирмы Capcom (разработчик и издатель огромнейшего количества популярных игр для множества игровых платформ). 

Без всякого вступления вас кидает в игру, вы попадаете в Казах-сити (о как!), ваша задача - добраться до могущественного диктатора и покончить с ним. Дальше про сюжет можете забыть :)

Игра получилась отменная - динамичные бои и пробежки по уровням, боссы, каждый со своими "фишками", набор различных способностей главного героя, которые вы будет открывать по мере прохождения; с уклоном в метроидванию: весь мир-город поделен на отдельные районы-уровни, между которыми можно свободно перемещаться на любом этапе прохождения (за исключением первой и последней локаций).

В игре простая, но вполне привлекательная графика и необычный мир. По-видимому, японцы сознательно делали тоталитарную пародию на своих главных "друзей": Советский Союз и Китай. Чего стоят только названия противников: пешка, витязь, булава, страж и плакаты на русском языке. Но не стоит принимать это всерьез, все весело и непринужденно, и не должно задеть чувств даже самый истовых патриотов.

[b]Вывод:[/b] Хорошая игра от именитого разработчика. Цена в стим (399р на момент написания отзыва) выглядит несколько завышенной, дождитесь скидки и можете смело брать.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018307765', 'num_games_owned': 1649, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 678, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 678, 'last_played': 1435463230}
review:
Admittedly, it's really difficult to get me to get into a side-scrolling game. It's just something I've experienced so much, from puzzle games to fighting games to action games... Eventually, it starts to get stale. That's what I find so incredibly refreshing about this game. My impression shifted from 'this is way too simple' to 'this is crazy awesome' really, really fast.

In terms of story and setting, I knew hardly anything about Strider, but this game throws you right into the fray in a heartbeat. There was so much to appreciate about this game at first. The art direction is gorgeous, for one, and the gameplay is bizarrely smooth. Each button tap of your weapon is a sword attack. Every single one. If you spam the 'X' button, you attack that many times --it's really one to one. Jumping felt a little wonky at first, but I quickly adapted to it, and once I did, I was warped into a crazy fluid combat experience.

Admittedly, I was worried that 'jumping and sword slashing' would be all to the combat, but the game quickly provided me with a series of upgrades and attacks that really refreshed my palette. By mid-game, the combat was borderline addicting, and I could hardly put my controller down. Jumping back and forth, dodging attacks, reflecting bullets, switching elemental strengths and plunging in for a strike --it was all incredibly satisfying. 

To its detriment, though, this game is -really- difficult, particularly in some segments. I mean, I usually play games on hard rather than normal, because I think developers sometimes dumb games down for the masses, but even normal was a big challenge (Particularly a certain elevator that had me rage quit a few times.) Also, checkpoints. Don't think that just because you respawned before a boss fight means that if you turn off your game, your progress is saved. A couple of times, I had to restart half a level because I quit the game before another checkpoint without even realizing.

That aside, though? It's a pretty good deal for a game that swept me away otherwise. You'll get maybe 6 hours if you blow through it, and 10 if you go secret-hunting. Get it for under $10, you'll not regret it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023049455', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 320, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 320, 'last_played': 1435431528}
review:
[h1]Intro[/h1]
I love platformers like the Megaman series and ninja games where every move counts, challenging and rewarding at the same time. I love finding secrets and unlocking new moves, that's precisely why I wanted this game. 

Strider was fun to some extent especially the boss fights and the platforming system. You can climb on walls and even on ceilings. There is a reward system of course which presents you with new upgrades that adds you your weapon collection adding to the fun. However, the game lacks in many aspects and I will try to cover these in this review of the game. 

[h1]Shallow Fighting System[/h1]
The whole game system encourages the player to rush through the enemies and end them as fast as possible which is expected of a ninja and should be good if implemented right, but the problem here is that enemies come in large quantities and spam you with bullets that stumbles the player. You may be able to play the game slowly and kill enemies without losing health but it will take forever, plus regular enemies are tough to beat and I don't mean tough to fight, the game makes them harder to crack when hit. Throughout the game, the only effective moves you'll be using is your normal sword strike or the charge strike. 

[h1]Repetitive[/h1]
The game is extremely repetitive, it reuses a lot of enemies and (you guessed it) it also uses the same bosses all to extend the length of the game. I have been playing this game for five hours and I'm still fighting the same soldiers that I met at the first level. I'm not even sure, they might have changed the color of their eyes but I'm pretty sure that they are the same except, now they are more in quantity and with various weapons to use. Adding cruelty to injury, sometimes they even use a shield to prevent you from passing which is really annoying to deal with. They also spawn back when you reenter the room.

[h1]The Problem With Level Design[/h1]
The level design, the levels are well done and the platforming is fun. The placement of enemies is also clever and hard to pass without thinking of how to approach them. There are doors which require special keys to open and pass through and there are also secrets with rewards. 

But the problem is the foreground and the background are sometimes confusing. Especially when you play this game for the first time, you'll have trouble finding doors and vents without looking at your minimap. I find myself, most of the time, constantly looking at the minimap to make sure I didn't miss anything. Also, there is lack of variety in designing the levels. In a normal platformer, you expect a climate change, a day time a night time. These things are important to me and I think they keep things fresh for the player. The game changes environments but not much, it is all about fighting in a modern city, a factory or underground which all look like the same place to me.

[h1]Many Worthless Rewards[/h1]
The reward System, every now and then, the game rewards the player with new powers to use. My problem with this is that most of these rewards are mere keys to new areas. Most of them are useless in a fight and you'll be more inclined to use your sword in fights instead of wasting your energy on those moves. An example of a useless reward is the [i]kuni[/i], a ninja projectile used to throw at enemies and instantly kill them (supposedly). But instead, if you use it on enemies in this game it's like throwing stones at an armored soldier. Plus, it only can be thrown halfway through the screen and then disappears. The only useful thing about this item is that some locks are only activated by using it.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
At the end, Strider is a fun game and a good platformer. It offers great boss fights and will keep you active throughout the game. The game however is repetitive and sometimes doesn't reward the player properly. You might be playing this game for a while but be prepared to spam the same button over and over to defeat all your enemies. If I have to give it a score I would give it 5/10. I hope those issues are addressed in their next game, otherwise, I'm not buying it.

review: Fantastic distillation of the mechanics and aesthetic that made the original Strider games such cult classics. The controls have been tightened and the Metroidvania combat and exploration refined to give you the game you wish you had played back in 1989. This is nostalgia bait - the good kind. Fast, furious, challenging, and very, very badass. A very satisfying old-school romp with modern sensibilities. A definitely pick-up during a sale or when you're hankering to flip out and kill mecha-dragons and cyborg ninja-angels.

author: {'steamid': '76561198191803939', 'num_games_owned': 38, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1583, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1069, 'last_played': 1485057096}
review:
It's a fun Metroidvania style game. So if you're a fan of the genre, you'll probably enjoy this.

But there are some details though that keep this game from being one of the best in the genre.

My biggest complaint is the map. It doesn't say to where a certain passage leads to. So you end up going in circles or being slingshot into another section by accident. Having to make your way back to where you were. You're left having to look up for a map online. Which kinda defeats the purpose of playing a Metroidvania game.

The voice acting is kinda bad. I sometimes prefer to play Japanese games with Japanese audio and I would've liked if this game had this option. But the acting is not bad enough to ruin the experience.

The enemies kinda get repetitive. Except for a few, you see the same generic enemy throughout the game. The only difference being what colour the enemy is and what colour his shield is…

But all this doesn't stop how fun it is to slice through all the enemies. The boss fights are pretty solid and the Metroidvania element is a welcomed addition to the series.

This game will be plenty of fun for anyone who grew up playing console games in the 90s.

review:
The game is a great 2.5D metroidvania type game. It's pretty similar to Shadow Complex, except its main weapon is a sword and the main character has a climbing hook they can use to climb underneath things and up walls. With amazing art design and great music, the game revives the Strider IP with a bang and suceeds in making him into a real icon in Capcom's collection (although they don't seem to care very much about icons lately).

The only negatives are that the game is beset by some glitches. The fullscreen mode for example is bugged to the point of being broken and causes random crashes, so it is recommended to play in Fullscreen Windowed instead. In addition the game will freeze if the controller is turned on after the game starts.

The game's lack of many fast travel points can also be somewhat annoying when you are searching for upgrades or pickups.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986442118', 'num_games_owned': 483, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 95, 'last_played': 1652464358}
review:
Absolutely essential for every Strider fan.

I can't believe I waited until the last Steam Sale to buy this game.  The last time I had played "Strider" was on the Sega Genesis. It was good fun back then and I remember my times with the game fondly.  - This new Strider game absolutely nails it. It is exactly what I would have hope for from a modern remake of the game. 

- Graphics / artstyle absolutely beautiful in motion. Especially the particle effects and reflections
- Quick responsive controls 
- Wonderful soundtrack with plenty of cues that send you right back to your Sega Genesis era.

The combat and platforming are fun. Nothing groundbreaking but completely in line with what you'd expect from Strider. 
On top of that the devs have innovated just enough to make the game feel fresh.  Awesome, awesome game. I suddenly find my self wanting more games like this. Damn I suddenly wish someone would remake the Star Wars games from the SNES.  *sigh*

author: {'steamid': '76561198025182579', 'num_games_owned': 2465, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 2521, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 80, 'last_played': 1510889755}
review:
O primeiro (e único) Strider que joguei foi o do Master System, que em resumo era uma bosta de port do arcade, difícil pra caramba e em câmera lenta. Mesmo assim eu gostava demais.
Jogar essa versão a 60FPS em alta velocidade foi uma evolução incrível. O jogo tem uma jogabilidade fluida semelhante ao Megaman ( mas jogando com o Zero, já que você usa uma espada caralhuda), as lutas são gratificantes você realmente se sente um ninja fodão. Junte a isso o colecionismo dos Castlevania e o sistema de Mapas/Alavancas do Metroid.
O jogo é bem desafiador, difícil na medida certa e não pega na sua mão com trocentos tutoriais. Ok, alguns Checkpoints te jogam lá na puta que pariu, mas termina se tornando um incentivo para você melhorar! Joguei no controle de Xbox 360 e recomendo um desses, no teclado com certeza ia ter dificuldade pra dar espadadas na diagonal.
Resumindo um plataforma delicioso 9/10, que com certeza renderá horas de diversão!

author: {'steamid': '76561197971348987', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 750, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 750, 'last_played': 1434562611}
review:
The developers behind this 2014 remake/reboot of the Capcom arcade classic really got the balance right. They paid respect to the gameplay qualities that made the original fun, while carefully modernizing it with new elements which really elevate experience.

The gameplay starts off *very* simple, letting you learn the basics, and then slowly adds new moves, attacks and special powers as the game progresses. The difference between the complexity of the combat in the beginning and in the end is REALLY dramatic. That's a double edged sword, because on one hand it helps keep things fresh and  interesting, but I can see how it could make someone toss the game aside after 20 minutes because he/she felt the gameplay lacked depth.

The control scheme is really excellent using an xbox 360 controller, but in the midst of heavy action I sometimes experienced some problems getting the dpad to select the desired plasma type. Probably just my overworked, uncoordinated old fingers, but it did annoy somewhat.

The graphics are pretty much perfect. They nailed the whole sci-fi ninja theme, and the 2.5d rendering dynamically zooms in/out depending on the area you're in, so that it feels confined and in-your-face when fighting in narrow corridors, and vast and open when you're outside in big areas.

The sound effects are also excellent, but I found the voice acting (there isn't much) and music just a tad above mediocre.

The game lasted me around 10 hours on "normal". 90% of it was an absolute joy, but the last 10% was sadly tainted with frustration due to a combination of high difficulty, my low skill level and some stupid game design decisions:

- Checkpoints aren't save games! You have to reach a "save pod" to save your progress to disk. It blows my mind that someone felt the need to punish the user for having to turn off the computer!

- Some checkpoints are placed too far before boss fights (of which most are great btw), making you replay a dull, unchallenging part of the map over and over. 

- No "retry from checkpoint" option.

- Unskippable cutscenes before boss fights (well, you CAN after watching the first 15 seconds or so, but when boiling with rage after dying 15 times this feels like half an hour).

At it's best, Strider 2014 brought me stellar gameplay moments, and while I do reckon this is in my top 3 action platformer games, there's no denying that the above complaints poisoned my overall enthusiasm somewhat.

82%

author: {'steamid': '76561198034207934', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 534, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 523, 'last_played': 1497657435}
review:
Story and Characters: 9/10
I mean killing the Winds sisters? Instant win. Hired to kill the Grandmaster Meio? Even better. A classic retelling of the core Strider story complete with the classic assassination feeling along with the judgement of self-righteousness. The villains do not disappear after beating them once and pose a threat every step of the way, even during easy mode.

Art and Sound: 9/10 
The 2D animation does not try to focus on nostalgia which I really prefer rather than relying on old nostalgic feelings for a game. This makes me feel like a new reboot that actually works which is incredibly rare (I'm looking at you Nintendo). It is aesthetically pleasing. The classic Hiryu "HAHHH" attack sound is missing which I will take a point off just for that (pls add it in the future!)

Gameplay: 8/10 
Some of the directional attacking is a bit clunky. Although overall the games easy to learn keys are nice on the hands. The directional jumps can also interfere with some tricky terrain passes where you have to calculate the amount of time and reflex you have to make a jump etc. So far I enjoy the upgrades to your Cypher which really makes this higher than it should be (you are welcome Capcom)

Replayability: 7/10
Can get a bit repetitive but worth exploring the other difficulty options while having fully upgraded your Cypher. Although for $15 dollars this is definitely replayable to a point where you will see immersing yourself into it for hours on end.

Final Thoughts Overall: 8/10
Strider Hiryu is a classic game rebooted not to fit into the "nostalgia" resurgence of this past decade but tells a core retelling of his story, one that vividly explains the struggle of the Strider character. Buy this. You will not be disappointed. Thank you Double Helix and Capcom for bringing us this masterpiece.

review:
The legend is back! From the classic 1989 Capcom arcade and NES console game comes a new story set in the future. This is an amazing action-packed sidescroller game. If you're craving the lost feeling of a classic Capcom sidescroller such as the discontinued MegaMan series or anything of the like, STRIDER™ does an excellent job filling in that void.

My personal experience with the game thus far: I've taken on the persona of a badass ninja from a badass ninja clan, and fought against the Pooh sisters. Strider sure knows how to have a good time with the ladies....Awww yeah!

Note: There was a bug in the game where I was invisible and could not move in any direction while trying to climb puff the magic dragon. I thought it was just Strider being all stealth ninja, but if you wait for a while, Strider will eventually latch to the dragon and you can continue playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028615861', 'num_games_owned': 1136, 'num_reviews': 650, 'playtime_forever': 524, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 504, 'last_played': 1433367551}
review:
Strider es un juego entretenido y que cumple bien con los cánones del subgénero Metroidvania: mapa que explorar con bastantes secretos que obtener, habilidades que se van desbloqueando y nos dan acceso a sitios nuevos, scroll 2d, combate y plataformas mezclados, etc. No hay mucho más que decir sobre el juego, la verdad, ya que resulta poco sorprendente y poco novedoso, limitándose en buena medida a cumplir con lo que se espera de él y poco más, ni siquiera llegando a contar una historia de ninguna clase.

Gráficamente el juego es un poco pobre, en parte supongo que porque es un port directo de consola (con cosas como, por ejemplo, no permitir configurar los controles en el teclado...). Pero eso no quita que el personaje se mueve rápido pero, en general, las animaciones de todo el mundo son repetitivas, los bosses poco originales y la mezcla de cyberpunk con una especie de mitología oriental manga no acaba de convencerme nada. La música cumple sin grandes aspavientos, los efectos de sonido lo mismo.

El resultado es un juego que, para su subgénero está bien, pero que realmente no aporta nada que no se haya visto ya en muchos títulos anteriores. Un 6.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985517026', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1186, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1084, 'last_played': 1433096614}
review:
Dans ce jeu éponyme vous controlez un personnage mélange de ninja et samuraï, dans un univers cyber-futuriste en 2D.

Strider est un savant mélange entre action et plateforme, très inspiré du genre "metroidvania". Les niveaux sont liés les uns et autres au sein de la grande carte d'une ville, et petit à petit l'on acquiert des pouvoirs permettant de débloquer notre progression vers les divers boss et la fin du jeu.

On saluera l'identité graphique respectée et remise au goût du jour, ainsi que les mécaniques de gameplay et la bande son (l'utilisation d'un gamepad est fortement conseillée).
On reprochera une absence de challenge en dehors du plus haut mode de difficulté, et des chutes de FPS dans certains environnements.

A recommander aux amateurs du genre, en promotion de préférence :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197994904389', 'num_games_owned': 483, 'num_reviews': 136, 'playtime_forever': 1304, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1304, 'last_played': 1433449914}
review:
While not stunningly great, Strider is pretty solid experience from start to finish. While buying I was worried that this game may not deliver its promises. Luckily for me, most of those dark predictions were proven untrue. 

The biggest problem of this game is that it could use a tad bigger budget. Some areas like voice acting, textures and level variety could use some more polish and work. This is most noticeable while navigating the main menu which in contrast to action packed game, is pretty dull. Not very Capcom-like. There are just some aspects of this game that contrast to the great ideas and design decisions in gameplay department. I also lamented the lack of interesting story that could frame the adventure in broader context. In this situation only the gameplay pushes us to finish the game. This complements mechanics, but plot-less game still feels a bit empty. 

That said, Strider delivers... This is a button-mash-through-your-enemies gameplay at its finest. Press attack button as fast as you can and see how those Techno Commies are sliced into pieces. Yes, I said Techno Commies. There are also some robotic dragons, panthers, eagles, mad scientists, weird martial-arts sisters and bounty hunters as bosses and all other cool characteristic Capcom-esque stuff. Action is explosive and it rarely slows down. I like it. Otherwise, this is a solid made metroidvania game which spoils you with upgrades every time you explore a bit. Feels rewarding. 

In conclusion, while production values and the plot disappoint in places, the gameplay drives this game nicely to its home destination. Recommended to all fans of action platformer genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038137532', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 455, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 455, 'last_played': 1432660313}
review: I have to say one of the best things about this game is that at the start you have so little at your disposal, and at the end you have a ton. Like, it can actually be hard to keep track of the exact tool to use for some situations, but I guess that's one of the reasons I had so much fun with this game. This game HIGHLY rewards exploration with its metroidvania-esque map layout and also makes the player learn and think on the fly with its highly entertaining boss battles. If you are a fan of metroidvania titles, like cyborg ninjas, or just want a fun game that brings to life aspects of classic gaming that made us all love games so much, then please pick this up!

author: {'steamid': '76561198002315662', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 2271, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1342, 'last_played': 1489204906}
review:
Pros
-Fun Boss Battles
-Great Skill Design
-Ran great on my rig
-Smooth controls
-Not to long or short time wise
-crisp modern graphics(not really a graphics guy but this game looks great while running smoothly)

Note: I've read reviews where the writer complains about how drab world. I agree it's drab but no because of art direction. Strider really needed better world building behind it to be masterpiece.  

Cons
-Weak story/world building


Strider was great fun. The pace of the game makes you feel like an expert warrior. The action is just at the right speed where I have enough time to react while not being a cake walk either.  Another aspect I loved about Strider was the way skills progressed in the game. Each tool had its distinct strength and wasn't overshadowed by new additions to Strider's arsenal. 

The enemy variety just was right in that non-boss combat did not feel monotonous meaning each enemy required its unique approach for the most part. The boss battles were really the highlight of this game for me. Some boss patterns were easy and others were hard but none of the fights felt gimmicky. I couldn't just stay in one spot and win the battle. Dodging and moving in to attack were the general patterns but each boss fight requires its own approach in executing those actions. 

The only aspect that I felt Strider lacked was story. I never gained strong sense of connection with Strider. Nobody in the story cared for Strider leaving me with nothing to identify with. I felt like a random guy who did all these awesome things in a world where the Why was never explained. Maybe these feeling are a result of me having never played a Strider game before? I mean it's alright if you don't give the main character a lot of depth because it's a game but if you take that course your world needs to have the depth to support the story your trying to tell.  

The story was decent though and game play was more than enough to make up for the story's failings. This game is really great and you shouldn't pass it up if you enjoy action games. At least for me, Strider sets the standard for the modern Metroidvania title.

review:
Third and final update:
Completed the game after turning the game into windowed mode (fullscreen off option), disabling the Steam overlay, etc. I have NO idea if that actually worked or if I just got lucky with not getting a crash, so I will leave the negative review up. Suffice to say the final boss fight is kind of the least satisfying of all bosses in the game. A bit of a let down. Also pretty short: About 7 hours. Granted I did not 100% the game, but I also see no reason to...got most of the upgrades, rest is art unlocks and stuff. And I had to repeat a lot of stuff due to crashes. Anyway, would be an ok to good game if it didn't crash randomly.

Alright, had to change the review again.

Good stuff:

Cool graphics, amazing boss fights and pretty decent combat once you get more stuff. Also Metroidvania stuff.

Now to the bad stuff. The game crashes. Constantly. For no apparent reason. Just because it wants to fuck your progress. See, the game features checkpoints AND save points. Unfortunately if your game crashes (or you leave the game for whatever reason) ANY checkpoints you reached since the last SAVE POINT are GOOOOOONE!!!!!!!!!!!!! This is an insta "thumbs down", since many people seem to have this problem. Just random crashes. And it's not just in Windows 10 apparently.

I was REALLY looking forward to actually finishing the game, but this makes it impossible, since someone REALLY smart decided the last level shall not have any save points and that section is extremely lengthy. I got to the elevator part and assume after that comes the boss fight, but I can't be bothered to just try and hope the game won't crash. Sometimes it runs for an hour, sometimes it crashes 5 times in just as many minutes. Unpredictable.  
  
Also, the enemies are extremely cheesy later on, because they can almost stun lock you infinitely. You have no iframes in this game, which means, once you're shot down, bombed, shocked, hit with a melee attack or FROZEN ffs, you just lose more and more health without being able to fight back. Of course you should not get into such a situation in the first place, but since you're always outnumbered, it just happens. But being repeatedly frozen and shot is just not a fun experience. I was able to deal with all that until the last section of the game where they just throw 2 massive robots at you that shoot homing missiles that also freeze you...I mean, seriously? And as if that wouldn't be enough let's throw constantly respawning flying bots that send homing bombs your way. So between getting frozen, knocked away and knocked down, you can just hope that you didn't take much damage from the enemies before and hopefully just survive that. It's beatable, sure, but it's anything but fun to take control of the player away on such a ridiculous level.  
  
It's a shame, because the game in general is really cool, stylisch and slick, and I could even force myself through that last section if it wouldn't crash all the time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006768995', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 1049, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1049, 'last_played': 1431343402}
review:
Strider ist ein Jump & Run mit einem Fokus auf sehr schnelle Kämpfe sowie etwas längere Bossfights.

Dies gesagt müsste ich nicht mehr schreiben, denn mehr enthält das Spiel auch nicht. Die Geschichte ist schon vergessen. Rätsel oder ähnliche Einlagen sind gar nicht vorhanden.
Sie müssen es auch nicht. Strider ist etwas für Personen mit einem Hang zur schnellen Arcade-Action. 

Als Strider Ryu in Russland, ich meine in Kasachstan, oder so ähnlich ankommt, muss er sich zum Oberboss hochkämpfen. Um das zu bewerkstelligen sind vorerst einige Fähigkeiten zu erlernen bzw. Waffenarten zu erwerbem (Metroid lässt grüßen).
Diese gemeistert kann man sich dann daran machen, den Oberbösewicht in die Schranken zu weisen.

Das Gameplay
...wirkt auf den ersten Blick simpel. So schnell wie möglich den B-Knopf drücken und zwischendurch mit "A" durch die Gegend springen, damit nicht getroffen wird. 
Leider funktioniert das nur bei den einfachen Gegnern. Andere benötigen mehr Strategie und einen schnellen Wechsel zu einen der 4 zur Verfügung stehenden "Waffenarten". Diese wählt man über das Steuerkreuz aus. Am Anfang ist dies noch etwas hakelig, aber irgendwann hat man es raus.
Für die Profis ist es eine besondere Herausforderung sich nicht treffen zu lassen um in einen Modus zu kommen, den ich mal den "Rage"-Modus nenne: Ryu teilt mehr Schaden aus und alles schimmert rötlich.
Neben den Waffenarten gibt es noch Kunais, sowie Spezialfähigkeiten, die sehr hilfreich sind, um besonders viel Schaden zu verursachen, dafür aber auch Energie kosten (Mana sozusagen).

Im ganzen Spiel gibt es einiges zu entdecken, besonders was alternative "Kleidung" (nur Farbänderungen) angeht, sowie ein paar Hintergrundinformationen etc.

Grafisch ist das Spiel angenehm anzuschauen, besonders was so manchmal im Hintergrund alles passiert.

Das Spiel ist nicht unfair, man muss wirklich nur wissen, wie man an die einzelnen Gegnertypen herangeht und wen man zuerst töten sollte, ansonsten kann man sich auf mehrere Respawns (die eigenen) freuen.

Die Bosskämpfe sind natürlich der Höhepunkt. Schwach inszeniert, aber super atmosphärisch und es fühlt sich wie ein Bosskampf auch an.
Ich empfehle für Fortgeschrittene Spieler auch gleich den höchsten Schwierigkeitsgrad.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979518537', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 592, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 563, 'last_played': 1429141933}
review:
Metrolvenia, tipo de juego donde se trata de derrocar a una dictador/religioso  donde los jefes de pantallas son esteriotipados, rusos y chinos (extraño). El juego es entretenido y se necesitan armas especiales para poder desbloquear partes de los mapas. Es un juego de plataforma/brawler en 2d que uno se entrentiene. 
Yo lo juegué con control y se maneja de forma simple, aunque para las diferentes habilidades hay que estar presionando más de un botón. Y para el caso de los sables, es un poco incómodo, porque hay que presionarlo y esperar hasta que la bufanda cambie de color y en algunas de las veces no funciona bien. 
Yo lo recomiendo un juego interesta. Yo le doy un 8/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198142069651', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 734, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 698, 'last_played': 1563080132}
review:
É evidente que os clássicos Nunca devem ser dispensados ou subjugados, mas esta nova aventura de Strider ao menos para mim é a MELHOR! A versão mais bem feita e mais empolgante de todas. Belos efeitos gráficos, belas animações, ambientação maravilhosa, músicas e efeitos sonoros muito bonitos e competentes, além de ser viciante em sua escalada metroidvania. Tudo isso sem contar os controles mais que responsivos, enfim, um jogo Completo e Indispensável!!! Um jogo a altura de um grande clássico e a altura de um grande personagem, que tem em si, toda a relevância do gênero plataforma trazido desde os anos 80.
Se você quer um jogo de plataforma super divertido e que lhe renda umas boas horas de jogo, Strider É a pedida!!!
Ponto pro pessoal da Capcom, mais uma vez! É Nota 10/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084105977', 'num_games_owned': 370, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 647, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 572, 'last_played': 1614970286}
review:
[b] Предисловие [/b]
Эххх, смотрю на свои старые обзоры, на их громоздкость, и прям восхищаюсь! И было же столько времени и желания у человека!.. Или просто не было умения писать коротко и по делу... Кхм, окей! 
Спустя приличное время с последней игры в Strider (семь лет, охренеть!!!) я решил посмотреть на данную игру снова, более, так сказать, набитым глазом. Поэтому и обзор свой также обновлю.

[h1] ВАУ-ВАУ, ЭТО ЖЕ ИГРА ПРО НИНДЗЮ! [/h1]

Примерно с такими словами я впервые встретился с Strider в Стиме. Еще с серии [i] Ninja Gaiden [/i] на NES я неровно дышу к динамичным сайд-скроллерам, с бегом по стенам, катаной в основном вооружении и остальным присущим. 
Strider, собственно, об этом всем и есть! Единственное, что, вместо линейного прохождения уровней, он завернут в тесно связанный с 2-D играми жанр Метроидвания. 
Игра предоставит нам большой город, разбитый на локации, каждая из которых изрежена десятками коридоров и комнат, попрячет всяческие улучшения и коллектабалсы. И в целом это все - дело неплохоооое...
[b] НО! [/b]
Возможно, это уже личное предвзятое отношение. Похожее у меня было и с [u] прекрасной без сомнения игрой [/u] [i] the Messenger [/i]. Когда играешь в динамичный экшен про ниндзю - ты хочешь... блин... играть в динамичный экшен про ниндзю! 
То есть... у тебя есть уровень, у тебя есть цель уровня, и ты бежишь к ней через толпу противников, изящно с ними разделываясь, взбегая вверх по стенам, раскидывая кунаи! И это все круто, потому что соответствует заявленному игрой! 
Но потом ты получаешь новый апгрейд, или просто видишь еще одну дверцу, не по пути твоего целевого прохождения, и заглянуть тебе туда вроде и не хочется, а вроде и улучшить персонажа было бы неплохо... 
В общем: эксплоринг в такого рода играх - это не сколько интересное, сколько утомляющее занятие. К тому же рушащее динамику!

[i] Стоит заметить, что в the Messenger проблема эксплоринга не так сильно бьет по динамике, поскольку второстепенные локации, как правило, короткие, но труднопроходимые. [/i]

В Strider же все до отупения просто! Тебе нужно будет либо вернуться назад с новым улучшением, либо же осмотреть все "темные пятна" в комнате. При этом каких-то серьезных препятствий на пути ты, как правило, не встретишь! Ну скууууууучно же! Это простительно какой-нибудь [i] Symphony of the Night [/i], поскольку там вся игра в подобном умеренном ритме протекает! Но никак не игре про ниндзя-машину, пролетающую почти насквозь врагов!

Напротив метроидванской системе, [u] все, что касается экшн-составляющей - выполнено отлично! [/u]
Персонаж управляется супер-отзывчиво (порой даже слишком уж "супер", но это беда с моей чувствительностью стиков)! Частота взмахов мечом зависит только от скорости Ваших пальцев - что вообще в последнее время стало для меня личным жирным плюсом в играх! Также махать мечом позволено аж в восьми направлениях! Другой вопрос, что по игре это очень редко пригождается, но только ради эффектности - почему бы и нет?!

В целом, если у Strider есть что-то в духе NG+, когда тебя не будут гложить ненайденные улучшения - игра просто расцветет и поглотит мое внимание на еще несколько вечеров! 
Но, насколько мне известно, его там нет... =\

Как и [u] нет нормального позиционирования платформ на уровнях [/u], кстати! Смотря чисто на игровой экран, порой очень трудно различить объекты на заднем фоне (или даже на [b] переднем [/b]!) от объектов на основном! Поэтому часть игры, связанная с платформингом и паркуууууууууууууууууууууром, будет фокусировать Ваше внимание не на огромном (ну или на каком мониторе вы там играете) экране, а на левом верхнем уголке!
Кто не догадался - [b] на мини-карте [/b]!

Из личных придирок хотелось бы отчитать разработчиков за дурацкие хитбоксы на некоторых "больших" противниках, и объектах! Не то, чтобы горела жопа от них, но приятного мало, когда тебя бьет НЕ ПОЙМИ ЧТО!
А также за отсутствие подката на отдельной кнопке! Почему малоиспользуемый удар "вверх" (который можно исполнить иначе) удостоился своей отдельной кнопки на геймпаде, а более полезный и используемый подкат нужно выполнять комбинацией "вниз+прыжок"? Эта комбинация, конечно, логична, но на стике ее выполнить гораздо труднее, чем на занятом D-pad!

[h1] ИТОГ [/h1]
Интересная концепция, отличные механики, и в большинсвте приятный визуал в принципе позволяет мне порекомендовать эту игру... что я, собственно, и сделаю! Однако, для своей протяженности, Strider ощущается пустоватым. Изучение локаций вызывает только скуку, а по основной игре действительно привносящих новое и меняющих тактику механик не так много! Большинство улучшений - это "ключи" для открытия новых локаций.
Но, повторюсь - Strider - вполне неплохая игра! И, учитывая малое количество действительно годных проектов в подобного рода жанре, эту игру стоит попробовать. Местная боевая система должна порадовать всех поклонников!

Ну и очень хотелось бы увидеть сиквел этой игры, или перезапуск, ну или что-нибудь, что привнесет в уже годный концепт больше разнообразия и загладит неприятные шероховатости оригинала.

review:
Buen juego de plataformas, un homenaje a los juegos de principio de los 90.
Tiene una buena duracion para lo que ofrece, el diseño es sobresaliente a destacar la vistosidad de los colores y habilidades.
La parte negativa es el mapeado, no existe una forma de acudir rapìdamente a dos puntos y nos hace volver a recorrer parte del mapa para buscar los desbloqueables y por ello se hace un poco tedioso.

Si te gusta los juegos de plataformas y recuerdas con cariño el Strider de antaño este juego merece una oportunidad.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034306697', 'num_games_owned': 1401, 'num_reviews': 614, 'playtime_forever': 853, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 853, 'last_played': 1429925493}
review:
[b]A short yet fast 2D action-platformer with metroidvania-like exploration where you'll be required to backtrack a bit and open up new places in the world with the new things you get as you play the game.[/b] The game takes a lot from the previous Strider games including the enemies/bosses and power-ups/upgrades included in it along with its own new features.

Difficulties range from Easy, Normal, and Hard. The only difference with these is the damage differences; the higher the difficulty the more hits you need to dish out and the fewer hits you can take, though I'm finding Normal to still be a bit easy and Hard actually causing me to die quite a lot which kind of forces me to actually pay attention to how I should be avoiding taking damage while still hacking and slashing. 
The hacking and slashing is as fast as you press the attack button which can be very tiring. You can attack at almost anytime you do anything and the direction as to where you slash can also be manipulated to be pointed almost anywhere around you as you please. 

I didn't find the exploration part to be very rewarding since a lot of the optional things you go back for can only be attained somewhat late in the game and there's no sort of New Game + to keep at least some of the upgrades. Plus there's a lot of strenuous backtracking to get these optional items.
I found it to be a lot of fun though to sort of speed run through the game and mostly follow the indication of where I should run to next. Because it's a 2D platformer a controller is best suited.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036432957', 'num_games_owned': 822, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 733, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 461, 'last_played': 1474715343}
review:
This is a reimagining of the old Strider games, and it has the same basic concept - cyborg ninja fights the evil forces of Cold War-esque dictator Grandmaster Meio by slashing baddies with his cypher and running/flipping/climbing on walls with sickles and a robot panther and falcon. That's a pretty loaded sentence and if you thought "wow, that sounds awesome!" then this is the game for you. The graphics are very gorgeous and gameplay is generally fast and furious if your computer can handle it; I had to turn down the resolution quite a bit and there was still lots of slowdown, though it was certainly cinematic at times with Strider dodging bullets in slow-mo like an uber boss.

Structurally the game differs from past Striders (except for the NES game) by taking on a Metroidvania format - you run around sections of a big map collecting abilities and fighting bosses in order to unlock access to new areas. Nothing wrong with that, I love Metroidvanias - but Strider 2014 does feel padded at times even though it's not a really long game. Certain sections drag and the map feels overly big and occasionally confusing thanks to different "planes" that don't really make much sense. I never felt the need to run around and explore every nook and cranny or snag every ability, which is really a first for me in a Metroidvania game. 

Aside from some dullness that will likely keep me from replaying this anytime soon, Strider 2014 is worth it if the idea of communist-fighting ninjas appeals to you or if you're a fan of the older games. At its best, it's full of nostalgia with old bosses like the Pooh Sisters and the robot gorilla all present and accounted for. Also the NES Strider theme plays in the background sometimes and really got me pumped more than once, so I guess that was worth the price of admission.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977394942', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 1081, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 594, 'last_played': 1594172163}
review:
9.5/10 

This game is GREAT!  As someone who beat the genesis strider 1 and strider returns, NES Strider, Playstation Strider 2 (Japanese version), and who has been slaying people on MVC1, 2, and 3 ultimate, this is a wonderful game.  It's like the creators looked at the game Moon Diver which was supposed to be the successor to the Strider franchise, and learned from all the mistakes that were made in that title.  Even without ANY powerups, from the get go, Strider feels just as sleek and fine tuned in his handling and controls as he did on any of his previous incarnations including MVC.  Add in all the cool power ups, the button combinations that are needed to traverse levels, and the multitude of secrets waiting for the gamer with an eye for exploration, and you have a wonderful romp in a revamped Strider universe that  pays many nods to the previous games.

There are only a few things for which I fault this game.  Firstly, the music is awesome, especially the nod to the NES Egypt Rail Carrier track.  The track is slower and there are trains in the background capturing some of the feel of the original NES content. However, it drops the ball in that there is no level that takes place on a high speed train.  This was an effect that was supremely brought to life on the NES.  With the current technology, it would have been awesome to see how an idea such as this could have been illustrated and also the game mechanics that would have been involved.  Secondly, we are given different color palattes for Strider as mementos from fallen Striders.  This is a cop-out as it would have been much better to actually RESCUE said Striders and have them join Strider's team either as a type of limited subweapon or as an AI controlled ally or as a completely different character that can be swapped out at any save station.  
With that said, if there were other playable characters, the idea of Co-op would easily be implementable.  And, considering that Co-op was already a part of Moon Diver, there is really no excuse for there to be a lack of couch Co-op for Strider.

Still, that only amounts to a 0.5 point deduction on an awesome game.

review:
[h1]Strider[/h1]
[i]a metroidvania action platformer[/i]

Strider is a metroidvania in a way that you collect items and upgrades that is (sometimes) necessary to make progress and just helps you overall throughout the game. You start with just your primary weapon (the cypher) which lets you cut through enemies. And  will unlock more abilities like a Charges slash and kunai to shoot at enemies. The more you explore for collectibles, the more beneficial it will be for you. 

Depending on how you play the game, it can be long or short.
If you want to collect all the collectibles, (which i recommend) you'll easily reach between 10-15 hours of gameplay.
If not, then you can beat the game in under 5 hours if you go pretty quick.

This game is one of my favorates and hope it can be for you too.
definitely recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052604899', 'num_games_owned': 801, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 36, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 33, 'last_played': 1442167934}

author: {'steamid': '76561198017727524', 'num_games_owned': 376, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 495, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 495, 'last_played': 1425763064}
review:
Кроме того, что это стандартная метроидвания, стоит знать две вещи: во-первых, это порт – частота кадров скачет от десяти до восьмидесяти, во-вторых, несмотря на то, что [b]STRIDER[/b] длится всего четыре часа, уже к середине видны попытки разработчиков растянуть игру – замедляющие темп противники со щитами идут через одного, а следом за ними появляются позорные комнаты с телепортирующимися врагами. 
Потенциально хорошая динамика на каждом шагу проседает под необходимостью что-то переключить или где-то медленно проползти. Собирать секреты и улучшения становится неинтересно.
Ещё здесь геймдизайн прямиком из девяностых, но не знаю, хорошо это или плохо. Советую дождаться распродажи.

6/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198051777251', 'num_games_owned': 302, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1410, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1410, 'last_played': 1424625510}
review: С одной стороны игра очень простая и без каких-либо фишек, да и ей эти фишки не нужны. Я её купил только из-за ностальгических воспоминаний об одноименной игре для NES. Это классическая аркада, пройти которую не составит особого труда, я бы даже сказал что она слишком простая. Но самое главное в ней, по моему мнению, это визуальная составляющая. Она выглядит очень просто, декорации однообразные, но какие же они приятные. Это же настоящее искусство сделать из одинаковых кубиков по-настоящему любопытные архитектуры. Дух такого стильного минимализма витает на протяжении всех уровней игры, и совершенно не надоедает. Нисколько не жалею денег на нее потраченных.

review:
This game is pretty awesome. I played the old games back on the NES and the Genesis and this version is a high octane space ninja in a metroid style game where you have to earn unlocks and upgrades to progress to different areas and get other items.

Hope they make another.

review:
Overall: Strong exploration/action game.  Simple, effective.  The Pros are broad and the Cons are narrow for a reason.

Pros: Beautiful, lovely world design (very Einhander-esque) with a strong score and tight controls.  

Cons: For as pretty as it is, I was a little bored after awhile; I never learned who the character was or why he was doing what he was doing.  The entire game is In Media Res which gets old after a half-dozen hours of Fighting the Good Fight.  The automated annoucements that provide strong atmosphere at first get incredibly repetitive after a short time.

Rating: **** / *****

author: {'steamid': '76561197982764094', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1338, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1178, 'last_played': 1424609236}
review:
初見ノーマルを8時間ほどでクリア。達成率は約7割。
価格以上にやりがいのある良質なアクションゲームです。
良い点は他の方が書いてくれているので、不満点を幾つか。

1.サイファーが弱い。
敵が硬いというか単純にサイファーの威力が低いです。
最初のザコ敵すら数回ヒットさせないと倒せないレベル。
中盤以降強化されることで使い勝手は上がりますが、根本的な威力不足は改善されず・・・

2.ボス戦での飛び道具の強さ
1.に付随しますが、基本ボス戦はサイファーで斬りつけるよりも飛び道具のクナイを使ったほうが楽です。
下手に近寄るよりもクナイをちまちま撃ってるほうが効率的なため、ボス戦は単調になりがちです。

3.収集アイテムを拾った時に自動的にセーブされない。
このゲームにはマップ中に散らばっている収集アイテムをコンプさせていく要素があるのですが、拾った時点ではセーブされないため
セーブされる前に死んでしまうともう一回取り直さないといけないという手間のかかる仕様になっています。
このせいで取り忘れなどが多々発生してしまうのです。

4.周回プレイが出来ない。
広いマップを探索し強化アイテムを集めて飛竜を強くしても、その強さを堪能できるのはゲームをクリアするまでです。
強いままニューゲームが出来るかと思いスタートを選択すると、そこにいるのは最初の弱い飛竜という無情な仕様・・・
次作がある場合は是非周回プレイを導入してもらいたいです。

なお、プレイはキーボードでも可能ですが、基本的には箱コンの使用をおすすめします。

author: {'steamid': '76561197991163504', 'num_games_owned': 755, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 4292, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1398, 'last_played': 1705240254}
review:
Strider, a reboot of the old arcade and NES/SNES franchise, is a sidescrolling, metroid-vania action platformer with great visuals, awesome music and pretty awesome yet precise combat. 
The art style is simple yet great due to the use of colour contrasts and comicbook-esque effects. The music, as much as I researched, is a reimagining of old music bits from the SNES and arcade games.
The combat feels very good and there are many things to discover, learn and slice through. There are also many upgrades for your weapons and skills. The boss battles are also quite amusing yet very hard and frustrating at time.
All in all Strider is a wonderful and awesome experience and is defenitely worth your time and money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009870133', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 565, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 554, 'last_played': 1675051307}
review:
Do you like Metroid?

Do you like Mega Man X?

I do, and this game being the marriage of the two works out very well. Strider plays like a smoother, quicker modern version of how Zero played in Mega Man X4 and X5. The best thing about this game is that very feel; your character can slash enemies 1:1 with how fast you can mash the attack button and it's very satisfying to plow through enemies at a full sprint.

The game is somewhat of a free form metroidvania, but only somewhat. Your objectives are given to you marked on a map and you only need to backtrack through one area in order to fight a particular boss. You can find secrets and upgrades by exploring more once you've powered up, but all of the crucial stuff you'll find just by letting the game hold your hand. The fact that the city is technically open to exploration is nice though, and it doesn't slow the pace of the game if you don't let it. Surely going back to grab stuff often serves as a nice break between difficult boss fights.

So the gameplay is really solid all around and that's what's important- however you may find that things are lacking in art direction and story. There are a handful of environments to traverse as the city is separated into districts, but each one is blander than the last. Visually, the game doesn't have much personality especially when you consider that the character's mouths don't move during voice acted cutscenes. I'm not a visual designer, but what I think what this game needed was a darker, more dystopian tone rather than the spitshined anime one we got.

The story can't be called a disaster because it isn't really there, but what is there feels dissapointing in light of the fact that they actually bothered to animate a few cutscenes and record dialogue. Especially after defeating the final boss, you might find that the complete lack of meaningful exposition or resolution brings down the experience.

Overall, an 8/10 with one point deducted for the each of the two paragraphs above. The gamplay style is timeless and I disagree with the majority of people who found this game frustrating. At about 7 hours for my first normal playthrough, it may be most worth it to buy during a 50% sale but it is generally worth it anyway. It's a fun time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987838265', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1064, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 983, 'last_played': 1419102089}
review:
メトロイド型の探索アクションゲーム。
7時間程度でクリアできる程度のボリュームで、実績自体もやりこみがそれほど必要がないので気軽に遊べる。
元TeamNINJAの開発スタッフが関わっているということで、忍者的な美学は共通している部分がある。
問題としては「ザコ敵からダメージを受けながら突き進む」というのが前提なので、ノーダメージで遊ぶ美学を持っているという人には抵抗感がある。

アイテムを収集する時に2箇所、ちょっとした応用操作が必要な所がある。
そこはyoutubeなどで取り方が紹介されているので、詰まった時には参照してもらうと吉。

author: {'steamid': '76561197974984968', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 477, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 477, 'last_played': 1422664488}
review:
제작사인 더블 헬릭스가 스트라이더 비룡을 메트로베니아 스타일로 되살린건 매우 잘한 선택이라 생각한다. 오리지널은 명작이지만 요즘 세상에 완전 단방향 일직선 아케이드 스타일 게임은 왠만한 경우를 빼고는 너무 성의가 없어 보이니까. 그리고 더블 헬릭스가 가지고 있는 사소한 악명에도 불구하고 비룡은 정말 멋지게 돌아왔다. 

앞서 메트로배니아라고 했는데 사실 이 게임에는 장비와 아이템을 모아 맵을 개척하는 메트로이드식의 게임플레이는 있지만, 돈이나 경험치를 모아 뭘사거나, 레벨업을 하는건 없으니 엄밀히 말해 메트로베니아는 아니고 아주 잘만든 메트로이드식 액션 게임이다. 아마 제작진도 고민을 했을지 모르는데, 솔직히 이미 특A급 스트라이더인 비룡이 돈과 경험치를 모으기 위해 지리하게 맵을 왕복하며 찌질한 적들을 끝없이 갈아되는 모습은 올드팬의 입장으로서는 보고 견디기 힘든 노릇일거다. 대신 제작진은 속도감과 화려한 전투에 더 무게를 실은듯한데, 덕분에 맵탐색하랴 사방에서 총을 쏴대는 적들을 이리저리 휙휙 날아디니며 처리하랴 매우 바쁘다. 정말 액션 게임으로서의 원작에 가까운 느낌을 가진 현대적인 게임으로 재탄생한거다. 개인적으로 메트로베니아 태그가 붙어 있어서 구매했더니 사실 돈을 모아 장비나 아이템을 사고, 경험치를 모아 레벨업을 하는 시스템 같은게 전무한 경우 그냥 비추를 날리는편이지만, 이 게임은 스트라이더 비룡이고 비룡에게는 원래부터 그런 장난감 따위는 필요가 없다.

그렇게 액션 게임쪽에 무게감이 더 실리는 본작이지만 난이도가 턱없이 어렵거나 그렇지는 않다. 오리지널 스트라이더 비룡을 즐긴 유저라면 노말 난이도는 그냥 논스톱으로 클리어할 수 있을테고, 액션 게임이나 메트로베니아 장르를 즐기는 유저라면 보스전에서 어쩌면 한두번 재시도할지 모르지만 대충 하다보면 클리어할 수 있을정도로 적당하게 만들어져 있다. 만약 초보자라면 공략을 보고 맵을 탐색하여 체력과 옵션 에너지를 늘리는 업그레이드를 박박 긁어모으면 된다. 막말로 오리지널에서는 적에게 몸이 닿는거만으로도 피가 깍였고, 안죽고 아이템을 박박 긁어모아야 5번 정도(워낙 어릴때 했었기 때문에 기억은 잘안나지만) 공격을 견디는 유리몸이었던 비룡이었다. 

맵탐색의 난이도도 그렇게 어렵지 않다. 다음 목적지가 맵에 표시되기 때문에 그냥 그쪽으로 따라가기만 하면 된다. 물론 업그레이드를 모으려면 경로를 이탈해 옆길로 빠져야하는데, 매우 친절하게도 그런 업그레이드도 맵에 표시된다. 유저는 그저 어떻게하면 저길 들어갈 수 있을까 궁리만 하면 된다. 답없는 맵탐색이 메트로베니아의 미덕이라고 하는 사람도 있겠지만, 할건 많은데 시간은 없는 사람들에겐 이쪽이 좋다. 

또한 BGM에는 오리지널의 멜로디가 녹아있고, 동풍 3자매, 공중전함, 바운티 헌터 솔로등 올드팬들을 즐겁게 하는 요소도 가득하다. 어쩌면 노스탈지아를 자극하는 추억팔이라 할지도 모르지만, 현대의 기술로 되살아난 3자매, 솔로와의 화려한 보스전은 꽤나 재밌으며, 오리지널에 비해 추가된 요소들도 들어있으니 그저 추억팔이로 그치는건 아니다. 

물론 단점도 있다. 게임 내용이 좀 짧은 느낌이 드는데, 대략 노말로 업그레이드를 찾아 다니는 시간을 포함해 6~7시간정도 플레이하면 끝이 난다. 메트로베니아로서는 좀 짧은 감이 있는데 아마 맵에 다음 목적지가 표시되는 시스템 덕분에 길을 잃고 정처없이 방랑하는 장르 특유의 시간낭비가 없어서 그런걸지도 모르지만, 오로지 싱글 플레이밖에 없는 게임인데 10시간도 즐기지 못한다면 가격을 생각해볼때 조금 아쉽다. 쓸데없는 플레이 타임 잡아늘리기가 없다고 생각할 수도 있지만 리플레이성이 풍부한 게임은 아니니 판단은 각자 알아서. 

그리고 사소한 단점인데 컷신에서 캐릭터들의 립싱크를 지원하지 않는다. 클로즈업 화면에서 캐릭터가 뭐라 떠들건 그냥 입은 고정이다. 정확한 립싱크가 힘들 경우 그냥 뻐끔거리게라도 만들텐데 이 게임에는 그것도 없다. 더블 헬릭스가 헐리우드 영화 배틀쉽을 소재로한 FPS게임을 내놓았을때도(배급은 액티비젼) 똑같은 짓을 했는데, 그땐 병사들에게 모조리 마스크를 씌워서 아예 입이 안보이도록 만드는 꼼수를 사용해서 비난을 받았다. 그런면에서 기본적으로 마스크로 보이는 뭔가를 착용하고 나오는 비룡의 디자인에 제작진은 안정감과 편안함을 느꼈을지도 모르겠다. 
 
스트라이더 비룡 1편은 오락실에서 즐겼고, 2편은 플레이스테이션으로 즐겼고, 3편은 PC로 즐기고. 뭔가 갈수록 남들 시선이 없는 개인적인 공간으로 틀어박히는 느낌이고, 이런 미지근한건 스트라이더 비룡이 아니다! 라고 말할지도 모르지만, 이런식으로라도 이 씨리즈를 다시 즐길 수 있다는 그걸로 만족한다. 그리고 게임 자체가 재밌는데 아무렴 어떤가.








PS: 이 게임에는 러시아어, 중국어, 영어등 각자 자기 나라 말로 떠드는 인간들이 상호간에 멋대로 의사소통이 되는 간지나는 상황은 들어있지 않다. 아 이 얼마나 안타까운가.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132471523', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 461, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 168, 'last_played': 1565508324}
review:
As of: 01/18/15

Great homage to the original title.

Gameplay is fast and fluid. Strider's controls are intuitive and fun to use as you rip your way through enemies as the unstoppable force you are.

My only complaint so far is that the characters do not move their mouths or have almost any sort of facial expression when they talk - unsure if this was done intentionally - however, it does dampen the experience slightly.

No matter, as the cut scenes are quick to pass and you're back into the action.

I rate it 9/10. Should you buy at full price or wait for it to go on sale? I say you could wait for a sale - but it's definitely worth full price if you decide you can't wait.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995249326', 'num_games_owned': 1448, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 451, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 451, 'last_played': 1421455763}
review:
Strider was a very fun and enjoyable action side scroller. Filled with beautiful lighting and fast paced fights, it reminded me of the old days of NES and SNES titles like Metroid and Megaman, along with the (of course) previous installments in the Strider franchise. (Which I have not yet gotten a chance to try personally.) I encourage the use of a controller with this game, but those on the keyboard should be able to manage.

Liked:
-Fun
-Fast
-Fluid
-Metroidvania
-Level design (in general*)

Disliked:
-Stun locks
-Poorly designed invisible walls*
-Unengaging story
-Questionable voice acting
-Anti-climatic ending
-Saving at the end of the game stops you from going back and collecting everything. Is an option not to save however. (Awesome reward for beating the final boss... /sarcasm)

Overall Score: 6/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198019170400', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 862, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 850, 'last_played': 1438533792}
review:
Wer bei dem Spiel eine tolle Story erwartet, der wird bei Strider sehr enttäuscht. Was einzig bei dem Spiel zählt ist das Metroid-artige Gameplay, was für mich der entscheidene Punkt ist warum ich dieses Spiel empfehle. Die Gegner unterscheiden sich nicht wirklich deutlich voneinander, aber es macht einfach Spaß durch die Gegend zu rennen und alles nieder zu mähen was Strider im Weg steht. 

Dieses Game ist auch eins der wenigen, die mich dazu motiviert haben alle Achievements zu ergattern(was auch nicht sonderlich schwer war). Wer arcadelastige Spiele mag, die auf Metroid-Basis beruhen(viel erkunden, Upgrades suchen, eine Große Welt unterteilt in verschiedene Abschnitte(also keine einzelnen Level/Stages), der ist mit diesem Spiel gut bedient.

Ich empehle dazu unbedingt ein Gamepad zu benutzen, sonst tun einem vom Schnetzeln die Finger weh! :)
Ich habe es erst mit einem PS3 Controller probiert, was echt gut lief. Aus Neugierde, weil es ein arcadelastiges Game ist, habe ich es mit einem Arcadestick probiert. Das Gefühl war richtig genial bis ich auf die erste Hürde gestoßen bin: Waffenwechsel... geht nur mit Steuerkreuz, muss dafür extra den Stick umschalten was bei dem schnellen Spiel sehr aufwendig ist.

--------
tl;dr
--------

Gut
- Gameplay
- Exploring
- Upgrades suchen
- Schnetzeln!
- Movement(erst Gewöhnungssache, doch dann sehr angenehm)

Schlecht
- Story
- Gegnervielfalt
- Schwierigkeit(zu leicht, bei allen Upgrades zumindest)
- Hin und wieder ein paar Bugs, aber kann man verkraften
- Steuerung in den Option nicht veränderbar, aber dafür haben wir ja xpadder. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197972610914', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 684, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 684, 'last_played': 1419783321}
review:
Great game that makes you feel like a bad-ass cyber ninja from the future.   If you enjoyed the fun days of sidescrolling platformers where your character gets progressively more awesome as you down bosses and get upgrades then you will love this.  
For Strider fans this is a must have and for fans of being awesome this is also a must have.  

If you hate being awesome or you like to be lame then I can't recommend this to you. Go knit a non plasma scarf.

For the sale price you sure get your moneys worth and it will burn up an afternoon or 2 if you are a completionist.

review:
Pretty much like the older games.
Probably not as hard, but I dunno never played any of the original titles. 

Pick this up if you liked Muramasa for the PSVita or the Wii. They have many similarities in gamplay.
Quick side-scrolling action and unlockables and new things are added into the gameplay to keep things fresh. 

Although, I do wish there should have been a way to do jumping up and down slashes more consistently. Maybe it was my controller but I ended up doing things I didn't want to do, but I got used to it. Definately hope this spawns more games where it can be polished more.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993151025', 'num_games_owned': 511, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 743, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 640, 'last_played': 1578102054}
review:
This game is very well done, and a decent price.  Very much faithful to the Arcade originals. I hope they will come out with some DLC, although the game can easily be replayed a few times without it getting dull.

Boss fights are very rewarding, easy at first, but get progressivly harder as you go deeper into the game.  The game action starts out simple with only a few options and as new skills are unlocked, the variety and complexity of moves you have at your disposal will make you feel only as a truely badass future-ninja could.

Highly recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020111067', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 647, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 409, 'last_played': 1450656974}
review: Contrary to popular belief Capcom does in fact have IPs besides Street Fighter and Resident Evil,  This is one of them.  It harkens back to Strider's Action Arcade roots but uses the Metroidvania game design to expand on it.  Solid Platforming, Tight Controls, very Atmospheric and humorous Saturday Morning Cartoon-esque dialogue.  It has two minor problems in that with too many projectiles and enemies on the screen at once the game may chug and the FPS may drop. the other problem is that some areas rely on copy-pasting rooms to increase the longevity.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082887581', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 9916, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 615, 'playtime_at_review': 2531, 'last_played': 1710581145}
review:
just got this game. would like to properly play it w/a usb gamepad but apparently 2 multi-billion $ corporations want me to take a programming lesson in hacking usb controller support before i can play this game that has almost been out for a year now.  this may be a fine process for some, but this is half-assed support that I'm sure the PS4 & Xbone versions don't have to put up with.  There's gonna have to be a lot more order if they intend the OS & Machines will have any hope in the market compared to consoles.  Things like this make it hard for me to continue recommending friends to pc gaming.  I will eventually play this game when I want to go thru the inconvenience of (apparently non-official or sanctioned from Steam or Capcom) guides.  At a glance of the guide,  it seems I've had more ease setting up emulators than the steps the guide seems to indicate.  The game apparently doesn't recognize (at least for me) 2 separate usb controllers (Sabrent 12 btn usb pad & playstation pad w/adaptor) that work with Street Fighter IV just fine.  The title screen alone looks cheaply done & not impressive as seeing the first Strider game many years ago.  I hope the game is more entertaining than this initial impression I have.

update 1/30/15: the game crashes randomly upon booting many times for no apparent reason;   looked online for fix & basically found nothing solid.  used xbox360ce to emulate 360 / xinput pads since this is the only type of pad the developers apparently bothered to allow.  this app alone causes the game to crash as well and the app hasn't been updated in a while afaict.  I only really get the app to work by luck it seems due to it being a factor of the game crashes.  i refuse to drink the "buy a 360 pad" kool-aid for any game esp if my pads work 100% for every other game if i can avoid it.  The game is good but not w/o its complaints.  First, it's buggy--random sound effects occur when they are not supposed to (ie level change sound while just running around); i had to reset the game many times while exploring & climbing b/c he'd get stuck in walls but wasn't that big of a deal to me; maps would show an item as not collected (therefore preventing full 100% achievements for a section from being obtained) even though it was obvious it had been; set to play on hardest setting (b/c found the game too easy on lesser difficulties) but didn't get hardest setting achievement--not a big deal but just a little annoying.  The game also doesn't provide quite the impact of the original (the ape boss was too easy & not very large or imposing--he was kinda easy in the original too but more imposing.  There wasn't much variety in the landscapes (was hoping for a dinosaur stage & weird end boss it had from original; no amazon/jungle stage.  There is no save file, if u want to start from beginning, all your previous progress is lost and once u beat the game, you can't use anything u acquired--this is just lazy on their part.  The only thing that remains is the challenge levels which is better than nothing but still not a sign of thoroughness.  Seems like the game was cut in development probably b/c DH knew they were gonna be purchased by Amazon so they just put some polish on console versions first, then whatever time was left--if any--for the pc version.  The game just feels like they rushed it & didn't give it its due.  A concept like Strider is very cool & should be given the full treatment.  Would love to see future versions include blocking or a combo system like ninja gaiden's but uniquelly Strider.  Perhaps the 3d treatement mixed w/some 2d stages if done cohesively.  Also starting the game off w/o the cypher for a level or two if storyline is more epic / movie caliber.  I prefer the original robotic panther but the eagle in this version may be better.  Also preferred the orbs which were more dynamic in movement in the original.  Would've liked to see more & bigger closeups of Strider & his enemies but understand the panoramic & scale of the environments may have been lessened to a degree.  The last tower stage & meio fights; the shiny effects; the sound effects & the music; the different costumes were also cool.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075553660', 'num_games_owned': 325, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 649, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 531, 'last_played': 1494392165}
review: Three words can sum this game up: Fast, Fun, & Satisfying. I found this game by playing the demo for it at NY Comic-Con and fell in love with it immediatley. You take the place of the legendary Strider Hiryu in this fast paced side scrolling hack'n'slash game. The game really nails down the feeling of being an unstopable assassin by having you be significantly faster than your enemies and destroying waves of well placed enemies. If you rack up enough hits on your opponents you can then unleash Hiryu's full power in short 5sec rage allowing you to make short work of who ever dares cross your blade. Like any game though, there are a few shortcomings. For example there is next to no story explaining the game. The game literally starts off with Hiryu diving into action, and doesn't even take the time to explain to you the controls. The only story that is present is through a handful of cutscenes (that have the characters speak without changing facial expressions or moving their mouths) that allow you to piece together a rudimental plot. Infact the game doesn't even tell you the main character's name unless you read the end credits. Overall the game is good clean fun with a fair challenge. If you consider yourself a hardcore gamer I recommend this to you, and if its on sale BUY IT! If you are adept at it you can probably play it and beat it during a long flight, and provide yourself with hours of entertainment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039870205', 'num_games_owned': 387, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 2502, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1784, 'last_played': 1527953427}
review:
Три-ноль в пользу CAPCOM. Последние три игры в которые я играл (DMC, RememberMe, Strider) вселили в меня надежду что игровая индустрия не сдохла окончательно.

Касательно игры Strider - на мой взгляд это первый отличный эксплорэйшон со времён выхода Metroid на GBA. Вообще Strider мне представился как Metroid в сеттинге MegamanX. Этакий боевой эксплорэйшон. Если в Metroid упор делается на хоррор составляющую, то здесь упор делается на экшн. Страйдер - это игра про ниндзю. Бегаем по большой локации выполняем задания и собираем апгрэйды. Что очень здорово сделано в этой игре так это локации. Они атмосферные и проработаны досконально. То есть здесь вы никогда не встретите копипасту. Всё проработано индивидуально.

Игровой процесс достаточно разнообразен (Лазание по стенам и потолку, тройные прыжки, кунаи, мечи и бла-бла-бла). Правда начало у игры весьма вялое. В Metroid начало игры брало интригой и хоррором. В Страйдере же игрок ещё ничего особо не умеет и единственное чем можно заниматься в самом начале - наслаждаться видами локаций. Потому что интриги особой и нету. Пожалуй, это единственный минус игры.

В целом, после Страйдера возникает ощущение, что он прилетел к нам из прошлого, из времён денди и сеги, только завёрнут в очень красивую оболочку. И это на мой взгляд круто, т.к. я считаю, что на денди и сеги делали очень крутые игры. Графики тогда не было и брали за живое очень хорошим дизайном уровней. В данной игре дизайн уровней на высоте. На протяжении всей игры хоть игрок и делает по сути одно и то же, но каждый момент игры остаётся уникальным.

Очень хорошая игра. Рекомендую, если вы любите не только крошить в капусту врагов, но и поисследовать большой мир.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978705200', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 250, 'playtime_forever': 375, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 375, 'last_played': 1419790351}
review:
Back in 1989, Strider was released in the arcades. It's basically how International Relations would go if the participants were  futuristic ninja assassins, robots, and god-like evil entities. The game turned out to be a success, paving the way for a couple of sequels, fighting game cameos, and so on. 

However, along the way something was lost. Kouichi Yotsui aka "Isuke" was the visionary behind the original Strider. After leaving Capcom he designed a similar arcade game by the name of Osman / Cannon Dancer, and most recently Moon Dancer (XBLA/PSN). He left behind a blueprint for all subsequent Strider games, and Capcom hasn't done much to deviate from it.

Strider (Arcade/Genesis/various ports) stars Strider Hiryu. He battles the evil grandmaster Meio, faces off against a trio of female assassins, slays the bounty hunter Solo, and cuts through a cyborg/mutant/??? army. He climbs walls & ceilings, and finds power-ups

Strider 2 (Arcade/PSX) stars Strider Hiryu. He battles the evil grandmaster Meio, faces off against a trio of female assassins, slays the bounty hunter Solo, and cuts through a cyborg/mutant/??? army. He climbs walls & ceilings, and finds power-ups.

Strider 2014 (Current-gen platforms) stars Strider Hiryu. He battles the evil grandmaster Meio, faces off against a trio of female assassins, slays the bounty hunter Solo, and cuts through a cyborg/mutant/??? army. He climbs walls & ceilings, and finds power-ups.

Note that I'm being exceedingly unfair in these descriptions. There are numerous differences between the three games, ranging from mechanics to level-designs to bosses. The story never changes though, and each itineration feels safer than the last. 

Unlike the previous games, Strider 2014 is an action-adventure game. Progress is tied to exploration, and Strider comes across abilities that help him reach new areas. Also unlike the previous games, Strider's cypher (sword-thingie) has multiple modes. For example, he can deflect bullets, or cause explosions, and even freeze enemies. Most of the time players will stick to the one mode that fits their play-style, only switching to others when it's absolutely necessary (color-coded shield enemies....ugh).

The most common enemy in this game is the overly-standard grunt with a gun. It seems that Strider brought a cypher to a gun-fight, but his maneuverability allows him to close gaps in a hurry. Battles tend to be exceedingly one-sided, with Strider easily cutting through everyone. Larger foes make rare appearances, and you can't have an action-adventure-platformer without flying enemies. Still, this game doesn't have any style. The military's lack of imagination is painfully apparent, when every room is filled with GWGs, big mechs, turrets, FEs, and zombies. Early on there's a fight with an elite who uses a double-bladed staff, he doesn't show up again until the end of the game. Nobody ever gets the bright idea to try anything original. Strider is killing everyone and finding kickass abilities, and the military can't come up with anything more than more guys with guns? More guns with guys? Guns guns and guns that gun? Give me a break. At least the bosses try to be different, and for the most part they're pretty good. 

When not slicing through foes more generic than the last, Strider is exploring each area for upgrades, costumes, and art unlocks. Acquiring some of these treasures requires the usage of different abilities, and it's nothing that hasn't been done before. At least getting around is fluid, and the mid-air dash is very handy. The environments never seem to graduate from cold & sterile though. I guess this is to be expected in Neo-Russia, and I can't imagine that Strider would suddenly run through an Amazon forest, but it leads to every area being too similar to one another. 

The mechanics of this game are solid enough, but nothing stands out. There was a level of finesse to the first game, and you really had to be on-point with your movements and jumps. Here, it doesn't seem all that necessary. In a way it's nice, because the original Strider has a punishing level of difficulty. However, I tend to get lulled into a state of complacency. The damage I take is largely irrelevant due to large number of health-replenishing capsules, and whatever traps I run into take a mere sliver of life. Granted, I played on the normal difficulty, and I died a few times, but the idea of replaying on the hard difficulty, just doesn't sound appealing. 

Enemies in this game also tend to be sword-sponges. By that I mean they take a lot of hits until their vitals give way and they're split into pieces. There is a charged attack for dealing with everyone quickly, but the kunai tend to be more effective after a few upgrades. Also, while the first game had "blink and you'll miss it" amounts of violence when Strider killed someone, it still looked really cool. Here? It just isn't the same. Since practically no blood is spilled, the combat isn't as satisfying. It's fun weaving in-between the bullets, but the pay-off isn't there. 

All that said, Strider 2014 isn't a bad game. My review might make it sound that way, but I believe it functions properly enough. The controls are suitable, the bosses are solid, i's are dotted and t's are crossed where it matters. It is a perfectly safe product for consumption. I just don't think it's exciting. The original Strider was rare, almost alien in quality, and every moment feels weird and interesting. Strider 2 is more standardized, but still works as an enjoyable arcade game. Strider 2014 checks all of the boxes for what can be considered an ok or even a good game, but it's so safe and bland I'll probably forget I even played through it a month from now. Moon Dancer? It's a piece of crap, but at least it played around with new ideas. 

In short, this is a decent game but I don't recommend it.

review:
Strider é um grande cássico da era de ouro dos jogos Side-Scrolling, a época dos 8 e 16 bits.
Muita gente tem ótimas lembranças desse jogo, então nada mais justo do que atualizar o jogo para gráficos mais avançados.
Esse novo jogo consegue manter a essência do jogo original, e ao mesmo tempo é muito mais dinâmico e caprichado, mantendo a jogabilidade 2D com gráficos 3D.
Jogo excelente e extremamente viciante, altamente recomendado tanto para os fãs do original quanto para quem ainda não conhece esse grande clássico Cyberpunk.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032486799', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 1434, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 352, 'last_played': 1504365603}
review:
Okay I saw this game and expected some high-quality remake like Bionic Commando Rearmed and Duck Tales Remastered. You know, they're great classic games, uplifted with polished graphics and sound, but honestly the whole point is to get that dose of retro nostalgia. If you didn't care, you might as well download the rom image and play the old version on an emulator for free, right? For a long time that's what I assumed Strider would be like.

OH WOW WAS I WRONG.

It's so much better than that. This game isn't about nostalgia at all, it was made out of a genuine love of old platformer games and strives to bring something fresh and exciting into that genre. It's like what kids back then thought future videogames would be like, a supercharged progression of what they already have, and now it's come true.

Also, I'm convinced it's THE best "metroidvania" since Super Metroid. I never thought I'd say that.

review:
It's a Metroidvania.  You're a ninja.

No, seriously, that's all I have to say to try to sell you.  The combat is sleek, the gameplay in general is smooth.  Most of the powerups are in plain view, while some of the collectables are really hard to find.  Basically, Strider goes out of the way to not break the game's flow.  Falling in a pit or hitting a laser moves you back to the last solid surface with a small amount of life loss.  Even full-on death happens shows a quick "mission failed" screen, and moves you back to the last checkpoint, which are pretty frequent.

The story was really weak, but it's not a story-centric game.
