author: {'steamid': '76561198072182182', 'num_games_owned': 2862, 'num_reviews': 352, 'playtime_forever': 736, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 736, 'last_played': 1417571688}
review:
Balanced proudly on the back of a galloping jaguar of pure energy, cybernetic ninja Strider Hiryu has returned at long last!  With holographic scarf streaming in his wake, he blazes through the laser-sculpted city of Kazakh, his objective:  to end the life of demigod despot Emperor Meio, and release mankind from his soul-crushing grip!  Strider Hiryu has always been a majestic character, but it is only in [i]this[/i] game that he finally seems himself, sprinting, sliding, blasting and slashing with an elegance and speed his original creators could only have dreamed of, and his older games could only suggest.  Raucous applause to Double Helix for bringing out the best in this iconic hero!  

Now let's have a sequel that takes its primary inspiration from the fascinating but fatally flawed NES iteration!  We can have Hiryu and friends hanging out in a giant unicorn-shaped space station, teleporting at will to a variety of evil-infested locations around the globe -- and this time Double Helix can make good on the promise of that 8-bit tragedy!

author: {'steamid': '76561197987401232', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2166, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1348, 'last_played': 1521204407}
review:
Gran juego. Estilo arcade 2D que recuerda a los grandes juegos de plataformas clásicos, con modos extra y elementos coleccionables por todo el mapa.
Se puede escalar casi cualquier superficie y la capacidad para explorar es grande, me encanta.
Hay varios enemigos, pero me hubiera gustado un poco más de variedad (por ejemplo, hay varios tipos distintos de soldados, pero siguen siendo eso, soldados; más enemigos de diferente morfología de los que ya hay molaría).
Los jefes son originales y divertidos de combatir.
Lo he disfrutado mucho, lo recomiendo!! (Y)

author: {'steamid': '76561198079711087', 'num_games_owned': 130, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 1123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 572, 'last_played': 1705640516}
review:
I just beat it after playing it on and off for about a couple weeks. This is, hands down, one of my favorite games of the month, the year, and hell, it beat Dark Souls as my most enjoyed game I bought from Steam. I'm just gonna copypaste my opinion I told to a friend the moment I beat it:

I had a ton of fun with Strider. It's almost one of my most favorite games of all time, but I don't know what makes it not quite up there with favorites like Metroid Prime and Super Mario World. It's got some of the tightest design I've seen in years and the action is fast paced and fun. Looking around all over the map provided hours of entertainment in itself, and the story leading you a linear trek before that was hilariously bad. The game almost praises me as well, with some enemies sounding like they said 'Mayo is god'. There's a lot of freedom even when the game is at its most linear, you can climb anything if you put your mind to it, Metroid-style enemy freezing allows you to use them as platforms and the warp dash maneuver is one of the coolest powerups I've ever seen. I guess my only complaint is the weapon switching can fuck you over if you're using a 360 controller and it's abysmal D-pad and you can't turn the hint system off. I've been plenty challenged and I've only beat it in Easy Mode. There's still a lot to learn too, as I've seen a speedrun of it that took advantage of clipping glitches and half way through there were so many glitches stacked up I couldn't comprehend what was going on. Sadly, I don't see any chance of Strider returning anytime soon, as the marketing for the game is basically non-existant, and even then, Metroidvanias of this quality are very rare and precious. It's still my GOTY.

So yeah, buy this fucking game if you love 2D action titles of any kind. It doesn't fuck around with needless story and exposition, you don't need to care about anything except that you're a ninja who kills cyborg Russians. It's part maniac hack 'n slash and a metroidvania if you spend more time into it, and if any of this raised your eyebrows, you wasted too much time not playing Strider.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969413947', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 458, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 458, 'last_played': 1418021715}
review:
Short review: Skip this game. It is remarkably mediocre.

Long Review:

Strider is boringly forgettable as a platformer, as a Metroidvania, and as an action combat game. There is really nothing compelling about it, and its strongest point is that the experience is nice and short (~5 hours on normal difficulty). My major complaints,

- The map: This is the worst map I've seen in a Metroidvania, and I've played a lot of them. It has two major problems that are compounded by the lack of useful fast-travel mechanics. The map is basically linear, sprawling from right to left, and the environments are barely distinguishable (basically, sheet metal factory is all you'll see throughout). Because of this, there are few shortcuts to unlock and I never had a moment that made me say "wait what, this connects to THIS!" I never really had any idea where I was unless I was constantly checking the world map. You do unlock a couple of powers that let you jump between points, but these warp points are so disjointed (with little indication of where you'll actually end up) that they don't provide a satisfying or quick way to get from one point to another, even at end-game. It just kills any desire to explore or backtrack. It also seems like the designers realized this, because they actually mark all of the important power-ups on your map (only cosmetic and alternate game mode unlocks are truly hidden).

- Enemies: this goes hand-in-hand with the uniform environments, but the enemy variety is just not there. There are basically 5-6 enemies that are palette-swapped throughout the game (human soldier, flying drone, ape robot, spider robot, turret, acid-spitting bugs). Even though the game does give you a nice set of powers to mess around with, the combat feels very one-note because you just seem to be fighting the same battles over and over again. This does not go for the boss fights though, which are pretty fun.

review:
A challenging and faithful 2.5D port of the original SNES title complete with updated physics and textures - STRIDER reinvigorates the franchise in all of the right ways without reinventing the wheel.

This game is fast paced and jam-packed with challenging platforming combined with hack and slash ninja combat.
Exploring is immensely rewarded - finding points to upgrade Strider Hiryu and unlocking secrets.

BOSS FIGHTS, BOSS FIGHTS GALORE.
At the end of every level, even sometimes in the middle, you will face against fierce warriors and sometimes learn new abilities to aid in battle.

7.5/10 Recommended for fans of platformers or SNES classics.

review:
Strider กับการหยิบเกมเก่ามาทำใหม่ที่ต้องบอกเลยว่ามันยอดเยี่ยมจริงๆ ระบบเกมเพลย์การต่อสู้ที่ลื่นไหล อาวุธหลากหลายตามแต่สถานการณ์ ตัวเกมมีความยากในระดับท้าทายพอสมควร เชื่อได้ว่าถูกใจคอเกมยุคเก่าอย่างแน่นอน จะบอกว่า Strider ต้นฉบับทำไว้ดีขนาดไหน ฉบับทำใหม่นี้ทำได้ดียิ่งกว่า ,ถามว่าเกมนี้มันสนุกยังไง มันก็คงเป็นอารมณ์เหมือนเราเล่นเกมมุมมอง side-scrolling แล้วตะลุยด่าน แต่เราจะได้เห็นอะไรที่มีมิติมากขึ้นในเกมนี้ ฉากกึ่ง open-world สามารถวนกลับไปมาได้เพื่อเกมไอเท็มเสริมความสามารถตัวละคร ศัตรูบางตัวที่ต้องเลือกดาบเฉพาะในการฆ่า ที่สำคัญ ทีเด็ดของเกมนี้อยู่ที่ boss fight ซึ่งการออกแบบแต่ละตัวถือว่าทำได้น่าสนใจและโดดเด่น ทำให้ตอนสู้มีความรู้สึกตื่นเต้นในการจับจังหวะหลบ เหมือนเป็นความสนุกที่สุดของเกมก็ว่าได้

สำหรับข้อติติงอาจจะเป็นเนื้อเรื่องที่ดูยืดเยื้อไปหน่อย ตัวเกมใช้เวลาในการเล่นเยอะในระดับที่ผมพอใจ ด้วยเวลาประมาณ 8 - 12 ชั่วโมง ก็น่าจะสามารถเล่นเกมนี้จนจบได้ แต่ด้วยการที่เกมมันมีระยะเวลาการเล่นยาวเท่ากับเกมในระดับ Big Title ดันสวนทางกับเนื้อเรื่องที่ทำออกมาได้ขาดความน่าสนใจ เราจะได้เห็นบทพูดเพ้อเจ้อแบบตัวร้ายคลาสสิคแต่ไม่ได้มีเนื้อหาอะไรให้เราได้รู้สึกตื่นเต้น แถมเวลามีบทสนทนาขึ้นมาระหว่างเล่นมันก็จะไปบังตัว interface ของเราแบบน่ารำคานเอามากๆ

author: {'steamid': '76561197981793213', 'num_games_owned': 1078, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 1992, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1951, 'last_played': 1417643381}
review:
Strider is a remake of a 1989 arcade classic starring Strider Hiryu, a ninja with a quick swinging sword capable of slashing a group of troopers in an instant. He is incredibly acrobatic. It felt weird to me that there was no mouse needed to play Strider, just a keyboard. The keyboard is tolerable, although I was wondering if a gamepad is more appropriate for the PC version of this game considering all the different moves you will learn as you progress through the game making Strider a more powerful protagonist.

The story is very simple as it takes place in Kazakh in the Soviet era. Once you understand the setting you will slice various enemies while you rely on your map to reach your next objective. The gameplay is very fast paced and this is a good attribute for this game. The action is also impressive and gets more impressive as you progress. You will learn new moves such as the double jump. The double jump will be crucial to jumping over obstacles such as electrical fields and moving buzz saws. Other moves include the kunai, which is a plasma weapon used to shoot enemies and becomes crucial during boss fights.

There is plenty climbing up walls and ceilings and Strider has sickle that can be called a climbsickle. This is a very useful tool for navigating the different levels in an action platformer that is basically about moving horizontally and up and down. There are many collectibles in this game, some for upgrading Strider, others for cosmetic effect. The collectibles Strider can be in well hidden areas, so Strider must use his double jumps and catapults to good use in order to find these collectibles. The most important collectibles are health and energy upgrades that increase Strider’s max health and energy.

The enemies consist of troopers of different variations, some very basic, others carry shields that require more advanced moves to eliminate them. The enemies do become repetitive since they look the same and can respawn as you backtrack to some levels. The boss fights can be downright annoying, especially if you don’t learn each boss’ patterns. Every boss has a pattern of fighting, so you will have to go through several tries of button mashing to finally defeat a boss.  One boss fight includes 3 sexy females after fighting two of them in previous encounters.  Another includes a boss who uses water to attack you and you must learn how the pattern of water based attacks is used. Defense is very important in each boss fight. Too much offense and too little defense will get you killed without a doubt. The defense requires a number of keys to be pressed in order to avoid a boss’ attacks. These boss fights made me think that a gamepad might be better suited to fighting these bosses than the keyboard.

The graphics are never bland and are always bright. Every level of Kazakh City is vibrant. Levels include an abandoned train station, a research facility, a military prison, and other diverse locales. Strider can eventually travel using an eagle perch, which looks beautiful when using it as a travel point. There’s also a panther statue that can be used to travel from one destination to another.
Overall, I think Strider is a decent game that is a reminder of the arcade era of the 1980s. It can be frustrating to mash buttons in order to defeat tough bosses. I felt a sense of accomplishment when defeating these bosses, but I didn’t feel like I would like to fight them again for fun or replayability. The replay value I find in this game is the collectibles that are scattered throughout each level. It can be enjoyable if you’re looking for 1980s arcade fun and fast paced action platforming, but you should be aware of the frustration of pressing different buttons so quickly, so many times with the keyboard.

review:
Just beat this game on Normal difficulty after about 7 hours playtime (according to the in-game timer), and it was mostly enjoyable. It starts off a little overwhelming with a small healthbar and enemy bullets that seem almost impossible to fully dodge, but by the end of the game you're jumping & air dashing all over the place chucking exploding kunai and freezing any fool that gets close enough to you.

Overall it's a solid if somewhat linear action-exploration game (Metroidvania). It's always a good sign when I still want to play more after beating it, and this game gives me that very feeling.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006439503', 'num_games_owned': 218, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 515, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 512, 'last_played': 1419859756}
review:
Je recommande ce jeu pour son ambiance et sa façon de nous projeter dans une histoire excellente ! La durée de vie est très longue pour un jeu de ce style et la difficulté monte normalement en fonction du jeu. Le gameplay est juste excellent de par son aspect Metroid qui va vraiment très bien avec le jeu.
Néanmoins, je tiens à faire part de 2-3 détails qui m'a un peu déçu :

Premièrement, certaines manettes ne fonctionnent correctement pas avec le jeu. Par exemple ma Logitech Duale Action n'est pas reconnue par le jeu, j'ai dû passer par Joy2 Key et remapper les touches telles que Strider la définit car oui, il n'est pas possible de remapper les touches clavier.
Ensuite, si par malheur vous appuyez sur la touche Windows ou que vous changer de fenêtre avec Alt-Tab ou quelque chose comme ça, le jeu ne répond plus, obligé du redémarrer et de reprendre à la dernière sauvegarde.
Enfin, le manque crucial de sauvegarde à la fin. J'ai dû recommencer un nombre incalculable de fois parce que la fenêtre avait changé de vue ou que je devais correctement configurer Joy2 Key pour plus que ça se reproduise. Et les devs savent à quel point la fin est rudement longue !

Ces trois points-là sont vraiment dommage pour ce magnifique épisode de Strider qu'a voulu adapter un style Metroid qui lui va a ravi !

author: {'steamid': '76561198016944265', 'num_games_owned': 115, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 646, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 577, 'last_played': 1443679239}
review:
¡El ninja futurista regresa!
he de confesar que al principio no tenia fe en este juego y el principal motivo
eran sus desarrolladores "Double Helix" de los cuales habia escuchado una
muy dudosa reputación, pero al final me he llevado una agradable sorpresa
el juego es muy bueno, no puedo establecer que tan bueno como el primero 
o el segundo de la serie, ademas de que este es un reboot, pero sin duda
alguna te  hara sentir esa nostalgia de aquellos juegos viejos,los graficos 
son simplemente adecuados para el juego, eso si las escenas cinematicas
se sienten un poco vacias ya que los personajes no mueven ni un diminuto
musculo de su boca...

la dificultad del juego no es tan elevada pero si te hara perder en muchas ocasiones
pero querras volver a intentarlo una y otra vez, las areas son grandes y con muchos
lugares ocultos para descubrir objetos, lo unico malo que me hubiera encantado 
seria la opción de empezar ya con todo lo que habias conseguido.
bueno para finalizar, recomiendo ampliamente este juego para los seguidores de
Strider Hiryu ó a los que les gusta los juegos de sidescroll al más puro estilo de la
vieja escuela.

review: Well, I finished it, but I'm not sure that I really enjoyed it. I kept getting stuck to walls, the weapons don't feel all that punchy and powerful, and bloody hell, the enemies have no qualms about stunlocking you, especially once they have the freeze guns. A lack of savepoints in the final ascent is also aggravating. Fortunately the last boss itself isn't too punishing. But, now that I'm done, I don't really care, and frankly I nearly gave up before I was done. Recommended if you reallllly want a Metroidvania Strider in your life, but there are better options.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031901172', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 874, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 861, 'last_played': 1407970779}
review:
Upon its release, [B]Strider[/B] promised gameplay faithful to the original series and attacks as responsive as your button presses. Poor marketing if you ask me. They leave out the magic of the Charge Strike Meter, which fills up every time you hit an enemy without getting hit yourself. Charge Mode is best described as "Fry with 100 cups of coffee" mode and for my money, blows away its Sleeping Dogs equivalent in the dust. It transforms the gameplay [u]entirely[/u], turning your Strider from a vulnerable hoppy-avoidy ninja who has to manage his button presses into the ultimate human chainsaw able to finish off monstrous killer robots before they can fire off their next shot. You lose all of that power the moment you get hit, so there's actual tension in those hellish games of chicken.

It might seem wrong to enjoy a Strider game on the strength of playing a death-crazed berzerker rather than a nimble evasive ninja, but it's fun in its own right and that's what counts; right? Dare I call it an intelligent button-masher? Because you work to enter Charge Mode, you work to stay in Charge Mode and you work to take advantage of the 5 seconds of Charge Mode, I say yes. That's right: [b]Strider[/b] is worth your money for the 5 seconds of Charge Mode it provides. The exploration aspect? You live in a bleak cacotopia where every enemy is a one dimensional evil baddy. Finding stuff is a chore, not a reward. The attacks most associated with Strider, to wit the Slide and the Down Strike, feel tacked on by the necessity of this being a Strider franchise. In practice, these attacks are mostly used for area unlocking rather than combat. I might've bought this game on the strength of its franchise but now I've discovered a much greater, far more exciting game that would exist outside of it...

Other weapon mechanics are a mixed bag.Your Kunai and Options are powered by an energy bar which refills over time, encouraging you to use your specials at any time without taking undue importance from your Cypher attacks. Your Cypher Upgrades on the other hand seem oddly mismanaged. Your first upgrade is the Reflect Cypher and it's the coolest by far, turning you into some sort of Jedi and allowing you to reflect bolts with your sword [i]if you time it just right,[/i] opening up synergy with the Charge Mode mechanic for its slowdown effect. Too bad enemies stop using reflectable bolts midway through the game. The second upgrade is the Burst Cypher and completely trivializes all other upgrades by simply making your enemy explode. It is, in fact, the best upgrade. Third upgrade is the Ultra-Cold Cypher, for turning enemies into ice platforms and better explore the game whle the fourth upgrade fires ranged boomerangs from your sword, somewhat defeating the whole "you have a sword, your enemies have guns" motif inherent to ninja-related games. It's the last upgrade though, and as such feels enough like an end-game mechanic that you forgive it for being dead simple.

Although not as exciting as the combat, the platforming can be enjoyable on its own thanks to the Plasma Catapult, your 8-way short-ranged teleport dash device. The challenge comes from planning your trajectory, working the flexible nature of your jumps along with the linear nature of the Plasma Catapult to form elaborate mid-air travel paths. The Plasma Catapult also gains from the Cypher Upgrades to form some cool but essentially useless gimmicks. For example, the Magnetic Plasma Catapult turns the targets you pass through into living magnets for enemy fire! Too bad it's tied to the ranged Magnetic Upgrade, making it more convenient to just shoot them from a distance. In fact, every combat gimmick tied to the Plasma Catapult is nullified by the fact that the Plasma Catapult [i]phases through your enemies[/i], bypassing the very notion of combat!

On the topic of Challenge Mode, one important notice for the developers: you need a way to show the player his top score and rank in a stage BEFORE they clicks the mission, so the player knows which stage they aced and which stage still needs work. Otherwise, since Story Mode is rather short and offers rather little replay options, alternative modes of play become greatly appreciated. Thankfully, Challenge Mode missions are built around the best aspects of the game: races across the city, and combat!

I gripe, but I had fun. The developers, [b]Double Helix Games[/b], have thrown a great deal of ideas at the wall and many of them stuck. You want a sequel and you want an editor, someone who will focus the game on the more thoughtful mechanics and axe all the overpowered shit. No seriously, the first Option you unlock, the bird, turns each and every boss fight into easy mode. EVEN THE END BOSS FINAL FORM!

REVIEW EDITED FOR LENGTH.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993363806', 'num_games_owned': 1054, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 813, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 340, 'last_played': 1415945396}
review:
Mark of the Ninja makes you feel like a ninja by having you sneak around, cool and calculated. Strider makes you feel like a ninja by throwing you into huge firefights armed with only a sword and reflexes. You also have an inexplicable glowy laser scarf. GLOWY NEON COLORS EVERYWHERE. So pretty.

The default difficulty level is kind of high; I recommend playing on easy. You can attack as fast as you can mash the attack button, and higher difficulties just up the HP of enemies.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044431911', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 71, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 71, 'last_played': 1414631193}
review:
So many good ideas executed very poorly. I have not played the original Strider, so keep that in mind when reading this review. Also this is my first impressions after playing it for about a little over an hour.

Controls could have been better, but they are tight for the most part. Strider's animations are very good and overall graphics (especially shader effects) are pretty sweet. Sound effects and music are lacking though. There are times where you are very aware that a sound effect is missing or that the music is trying to pump you up but falls flat. Title screens and transitions seem to lack polish as well.

Not enough variety in enemies. It also does this thing where bosses (middle bosses?) become normal enemies (further reducing the enemy variety). Normal enemies are mostly one-shot, which I really like in this kind of game. And the harder enemies require a little more, but not enough to slow down the pace.

It tries to be a metrovania game, but I don't feel it. There is not that much back tracking and the fast pace makes it even less obvious that there's backtracking. Upgrades come at relatively good timings and keeps the gameplay fresh. Love the fact that it's an arcade style side-scroller, which means no levels, experience, talent trees, etc, etc.

Overall I would say that this game seems to lack polish. It's not a bad game by any means, but probably will not be playing it again. Simple, fast-paced sidescroller with limited exploration. For it's original price ($15 at the time) I would say it's barely worth it. Any more and I wouldn't recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999914689', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 1493, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1397, 'last_played': 1492572543}
review: The gameplay is solid and fast paced. It is not too busy, just busy enough. Nor is it too fast paced just fast enough. An excellent blend of balance for a wide range of gamers. It can get rather challenging but never so much so that it is beyond enjoying. A few tries to get through a hard part and you should be good. The art style is clean yet fulfilling. The sound track suites the game well. The sound effects fit right in. The animations are smooth and fluid while looking bad ass but not commically so. Acquired abilities are all useful and cool. Time to completion was very satifying leaving the player wanting more but not feeling like more was needed for this game. Replayable, not so much for alterations, but because it is so enjoyable to play through.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087045715', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 4439, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1054, 'last_played': 1474645299}
review:
ノーマル、ハード一回ずつクリア。60／100点。

■良かったところ
・爽快感がありMVCのモーションを色々なアクションで見ることが出来る。原作、MVC両方が好きなら動かすだけでそこそこ楽しめる。他のレビューでもあるがウロボロス（オプションC）やXF（スーパーモード）のようなものもあり、ひたすら前進しながらプレイ出来る。ロックマンZEROなどが好きな人には特におすすめ出来る。

・良い意味で難易度が低め、一発即死で難易度を水増ししていないのは英断だと思う。アクション好きなら最初からハードのほうが良いくらいのレベル。ストライダー飛竜としての難易度を期待していると肩透かしを喰らうだろう。

・値段が（そこそこ）安い、コスパ的には悪くない

・ルートガイドが分かりやすく探索型だが迷う要素もなく、ストレスを感じにくい。良くも悪くも一本道。


■悪かったところ
・操作性が悪い上に、ゲーム側でボタン配置の変更が出来ない。最も致命的な欠点。おすすめしないにするか迷うくらいのものだった。アクションゲームでボタン配置の変更不可ってそれだけでクソゲー要因になりうると個人的には思っている。PS2コントローラーの右スティックが何故か認識せず、わざわざ箱○コントローラーを買ってまでプレイしたがこちらのボタン配置も変更不可であまり良い配置とも言えない、JoyToKeyと非公式ドライバを使ってやっとアクションで満足いく配置＆感度になるという感じ。

・成長要素がいらない。探索型なので仕方がないとも言えるがせっかくアクションが楽しいのに制限されてるものが多く、特に二段ジャンプとリフレクトサイファーの有無は爽快感に直結しているためこれだけでも最初から持たせて欲しかった。スタイリッシュなアクションを最初から楽しめないとアクションが苦手なプレイヤーのモチベーションが保てないと思うし、アクション好きのプレイヤーからすると最初はやることが少なくて単調に感じるだろう。

・探索要素の入れ方がヘタクソ。良い部分でも述べたが良くも悪くも一本道で障害物発見→新たな能力を入手→突破が主な流れになり、探索型ゲームの楽しみである先回りして能力、アクションを入手するなどの自由度がない。ボスを倒す順番も完全固定で隠しボスなども存在せず、探索要素はひたすら飛竜のアップグレードと中身の薄いおまけ要素の収集でしかない。

・ゲームスピードがもっさりしている。個人的には２ぐらいのスピード感が欲しかった。今の1.5倍くらいの速度が丁度良いと思う。

・キャラのモデリングが悪い。好みの問題だが飛竜が完全に外人顔でイラストとゲームの違いが気になった、もっとかっこよくしてほしかった。飛竜だけでも日本語音声が欲しかったところ。東風三姉妹も変にゴツイ感じが・・・

・おまけ要素がショボい。ファーストランナー、サバイバルとあるがどのステージもSランクを取ったらもうプレイしなくていいやぐらいの出来。せっかくボス戦が面白いのだからボスラッシュぐらいは用意して欲しかった。


次回作（があったら）購入すると思うので是非悪かった点を改善してもらいたい。

author: {'steamid': '76561197994865590', 'num_games_owned': 1016, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 1664, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1270, 'last_played': 1414700113}

review: Solid Metrovania style game that does the original version proud. There can be a few times where the game may seem unfair but if you rethink your approach and use the provided skillsets those challenges can become much easier. The only thing I wish I could change would be the dialogue between characters as it's a bit tiring and melodramatic. If you want a good game to kill an afternoon with than I would easily recommend Strider.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074305074', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 781, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 400, 'last_played': 1701703997}
review:
かの名作アクション、ストライダー飛竜が復活！
とはいうものの、かつてのステージクリア型のアクションではなく、いわゆるメトロイド系の探索型アクションゲームに。
難易度はさほど高くなく、多少努力すれば、きっとクリアできるレベル。探索型とはいえ、難しすぎるような謎解きもなく、ミニマップもつねに表示されてるので、道に迷う事も・・・まぁわりとあります、このあたりは探索アクションのお約束でもあり醍醐味でもあるので。

アーケード版と比べると、グラフィックはきれいになってはいるものの、現在の目で見ると少々地味で迫力はいまひとつ、探索型になって、全ステージがつながった形になってるせいか、旧作のように、シベリアから空中戦艦に乗り込み、そして次のステージがアマゾンなんてみたいなトンデモ構成はなく、少々変化に乏しいかも。

全体的にみてステージの構成上、旧作のような豪快なアクションは減り、敵の配置も意地が悪いところもあり、敵の耐久力もけっこう高いので、敵の攻撃を受けながら弱めのサイファーでちくちくやってる感じで爽快感に欠けるものがあるのが残念。

グラフィック、音楽、効果音ともに地味で、全体的に派手さと爽快感に欠けるため、旧作のような豪快かつ爽快なモノを期待すると、コレジャナイ感を感じてしまうかも。

わりと欠点もあるものの、探索アクションとしては充分に楽しく、迷いながらも、ついつい時間を忘れてうろうろしつつアイテム探しをしたりが楽しめたので、あまり旧作にこだわらず、純粋に探索アクションゲームとしては充分オススメできると思います。

author: {'steamid': '76561197973556481', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 502, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 502, 'last_played': 1393422381}
review:
A good metroidvania, which is hard to come by these days. Although far from perfect.

The game itself was a bit too linear for my tastes. Not much reason to backtrack to previous areas and the areas themselves all felt a little...samey.

Other than that it's a very solid game and controls very well. Definitely worth the price of admission if you're looking for some metroidvania fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993601098', 'num_games_owned': 1200, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 490, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 479, 'last_played': 1411956896}
review:
A Metroidvania-style platformer. While it may be [b]just a little less[/b] excellent than [i]Guacamelee![/i] in terms of mechanics, it certainly builds a better world and the voice-overs are appreciated, even if the plot is very thin.

Combat is fun. You can swing your sword as fast as you press the button. Kunais and powerful special attacks are also available. The latter are quite effective in the plethora of the awesome bossfights. My only gripe were the occasional stunlocks.

Strider Hiryu is very mobile and can traverse almost any terrain. Using his hooks, he can climb walls infinitely and he also dashes and double-jumps. All of it feels great. The only obstacles are enemies, locked doors and electrical fences.

In terms of difficulty (I played Normal): It started off way too easy, gave me a good challenge throughout until the antepenultimate boss*, where the difficulty spiked greatly. But from there it only gets easier.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009420039', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 1577, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 954, 'last_played': 1646940713}
review:
I've always been a fan of Strider since the NES days.  I wished the old arcade game would have been for console the non Capcom one called Osman.
This game brings all your strider games together, compacting them in a seemlessly non conflicting way. I love action side scrollers.Ninja Hiryu better than Naruto, and Ninja Gaiden. I remember the NES version being Darker though.Definately buy this. I wish it would have came with the manga. Hopefully they make a New Strider game for next gen.

This game is just a joy to play. With all the DLC games to unlock new abiilities or areas. Strider shows what old gaming was about unlockables and becoming a badass. Exploration without buying a new map. At first you'll think this game is easy but then it starts getting more puzzles and stronger weirder bosses. But its not overbearingly dficult. With the right powers equiped and specials. Strider the Ninja that is awesome.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044360880', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1161, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 756, 'last_played': 1500656316}
review:
This game feels amazing. Theres a small learning curve yet there is a lot of room for players to improve and master Strider's moves so they look natural and effortless. The voice overs I find funny but don't take anything away because theres an option to mute the characters and just read the subtitles. (try japanese voices might sound right).
The freedom to visit aread I've cleared was fun but it also left me confused as to what to do next. There is a type of beacon that shows where to go next, so I don't see it as a fault in the game. The biggest downside about this game is that the controls can't be changed in the options menu. No, you'll need to go into the game folder and change them manually. Since the community is pretty cool, instructions can be found on how to change all those to however you like.
It's a fun game to master, definitely.

review: rock solid castlemetroidvania interpretation of STRIDER, looks great, plays great, the voice acting is the correct amount of CAPCOM, sublime design, just good overall. My only complaint is that the game isn't nearly wacky enough. Why is the giant snake a lab experiment and not the combined might of the Kazakhstani parliament? Where is the dinosaur world? Why do I not get to fight a shirtless man in a burning building? This isn't really a a complaint but I don't care, please fix this for a sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010243046', 'num_games_owned': 1049, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 457, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 457, 'last_played': 1404607651}
review: STRIDER™ / ストライダー飛竜® is a pretty cool game about a pretty cool dude that happens to be a ninja man. You run fast and slice and dice! You play as a STRIDER™ who has been in past games such as Strider and Marvel Vs. Capcom 2: New Age of People! author: {'steamid': '76561198072045458', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 721, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 721, 'last_played': 1410955967}
review:
ノーマルクリア。　箱コン使用。　８割強探索して７時間ちょい。

名作ストライダー飛竜のアクションにドラキュラ月下の様な探索をプラス。
プレイ前は「こんなの飛竜じゃない」的な意見もありどうかなと思いましたが楽しめました。


■良い
・アーケードと変わらぬ多彩なアクション。
・アップグレードによる体術とサイファーの強化
・エリアによっては移動にパズルのような一捻り必要な要素もあり。
・ボス戦はかなりゴリ押しで倒せるのでアクション苦手でもパターンを見れば倒せる。
・アップグレード後オプションを絡めて猛攻かけると気持ちいい(^q^)

■不満点
・敵がちょっと固い。アーケードばりの無双感がない。
・レベルデザインが今ひとつ。もう少し色んな仕掛けが欲しい。
・ひとによっては探索がダルい。でも探索しないと後半辛い。
・チャレンジ系はメタルギアみたいなやり込み系がほしい。
・最終面に行くと引き返せず探索できなくなる。


お値段相応の面白さでした。最初の飛竜から遊んでいますが及第点だと思います。

review: This is exactly what a reboot should be.  A good action-platformer franchise taken into the new generation with fantastic, fluid graphics, a constant rush, and all the Metroidvania aspects you'd like to see!  Really, even if you're only familiar with Strider from the 'Vs.' series, you'll see all the stuff you remember him throwing out in this, and it's all done so well!  This is very highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086284705', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 394, 'last_played': 1404874200}
review:
Not recommended. 

The game itself is pretty boring.
The variety of enemies is pretty small (later enemies are just recolored versions of their weakier early counterparts)
Tries to emulate a Metroid/Castlevania feel, but fails miserably.
The story is really week and does not even have an intro cutscene or something to explain what is going on.

You will spend most of you time following the arrow that tells you where you have to go, all the time, while tapping the attack button, ocassionally swtching blades to match enemy targets (this mechaninc is introduced very late in the game and is annoying as fuck)

Don't worry  though, the game only lasts for about 5 or 6 hours, even if it's your first time playing it.

For replayability, it relays HEAVILY on collectibles...which are totally useless.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994494614', 'num_games_owned': 239, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 617, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 617, 'last_played': 1393167343}
review:
Poucas coisas são tão valiosas e recompensadoras para um jogador de videogame quanto a capacidade de se sentir poderoso com um controle nas mãos.
E a produtora Double Helix soube, como poucas no mercado, transportar essa sensação de poder para os controles de Strider, a nova aventura do clássico personagem da Capcom, oriundo dos arcades, NES e Mega Drive.
 
Alguns podem até não saber, mas bem antes de surgir como personagem em jogos de luta, Strider Hiryu era protagonista de grande sucesso em games de plataforma e ação, e poucos são os consoles da década de 90 que não receberam ao menos uma versão de seus jogos.

Strider era ágil, estiloso e acrobático, bem diferente dos típicos personagens pesados dos jogos da época. E essas características, como em um bom vinho, apenas melhoraram com os anos.

A nova versão de Strider serve como um reboot do original, e une elementos da versão arcade, com gráficos caprichados, movimentação suave e ação acelerada, e da versão NES, que possui um desenvolvimento menos linear, com um sistema de mapas, popularmente conhecido como "metroidvania", onde é preciso procurar itens e equipamentos para avançar pelos cenários. E nesse caso, o resultado é bem maior que a soma de suas partes.

Ao invés de buscarem uma reinterpretação simples, com jogabilidade 3D, a intenção aqui foi respeitar com a maior fidelidade possível, a essência dos jogos originais, mantendo a mesma pegada das antigas nos controles, mas trazendo uma série de benefícios de jogos mais modernos.

Hiryu, o protagonista que veste pijamas azuis e um cachecol vermelho de plasma é, além de um especialista em acessórios de moda, um Strider, um guerreiro de elite, treinado à exaustão para atingir a perfeição técnica. Striders existem para cumprir missões e a tarefa de Hiryu é simples: destruir o tirano Grandmaster Meio, que domina o mundo com mão de ferro.

A trama segue a premissa básica do jogo original, com alguns diálogos dublados de forma burocrática, sem grande emoção. O jogo até tenta criar uma certa empatia com alguns vilões, mas no geral, os diálogos são esquecíveis e até desnecessários. Strider Hiryu precisa derrotar o vilão e é só isso que você precisa saber.

Para cumprir essa missão, Hiryu contará com sua boa e fiel cypher, uma espada curta que gera uma lâmina de plasma ao ser brandida, e uma série de power ups, que vão desde novas habilidades, como pulos duplos e rasteiras, passando por diferentes "sabores" de cyphers, com atributos de fogo e gelo, por exemplo, até a capacidade de invocar companheiros robóticos que servem para funções diversas durante o jogo. Um robô de duas pernas, uma pantera e uma águia, chamados criativamente de Option A, B e C respectivamente.

A progressão pelos cenários é direta e veloz. Controlar Hiryu é simples e com alguma prática será possível fazer manobras muito estilosas e precisas, correndo, saltando, agarrando-se em paredes e até no telo. Existem poucos lugares por onde o strider não pode passar, contando que você tenha o upgrade correto, é claro. 

Os cenários são muito amplos e, talvez por isso, algumas vezes pareçam um pouco vazios e sem vida, mas raramente deixam de ser interessantes de se transpor. As barreiras físicas que limitam a navegação são bem implantadas e você nunca se deparará com uma parede invisível, por exemplo. E praticamente todo o mapa é interconectado, criando um enorme mundo que pode ser explorado de várias formas, e com muitas recompensas para o jogador mais curioso, como melhorias de saúde, roupas alternativas e diversas artes da produção escondidas em várias áreas secretas.

Ao ouvir a musiquinha inicial, logo após o vôo de asa delta que abre o game, fãs das antigas se sentirão em casa. A trilha sonora reune várias das faixas mais famosas da franquia, todas remasterizadas em alta qualidade e remixadas para a nova versão. Os efeitos sonoros seguem na mesma linha de qualidade e fidelidade ao original, misturando os sons característicos da cypher cortando o ar a tiros e explosões e toda a cacofonia típica de uma cidade-estado dominada por um tirano. E isso agora inclui mensagens governamentais promovendo sorteio de comida para todos os cidadãos que denunciarem os vizinhos traidores.

Strider prova que ao valorizar o produto original e não mostrando medo de desafiar o jogador, é possível criar experiências com games tão fantásticas quanto a nossa nostalgia permite. Além disso, essa nova versão mostra que em alguns casos, alguns clássicos podem e merecem ser revisitados e melhorados.

Strider não é um jogo para novatos, mas promete recompensas formidáveis para os que aceitarem o desafio. Com muitas áreas secretas e power ups para turbinar as já incríveis habilidades do nostálgico ninja azul, aqueles que resolverem brandir sua cypher e vestir o cachecol vermelho irão encarar um belo desafio pela frente, com ajuda de uma jogabilidade precisa e aquele sentimento "oldschool" de uma época em que os jogos não tinham medo de misturar dificuldade e diversão.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004743425', 'num_games_owned': 393, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 815, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 461, 'last_played': 1681526908}
review:
Like Metroidvania games? Want to feel like a total badass? Don't mind a bit more backtracking than similar games and a few recycled bosses? Buy it! For a $15 base price, it's fantastic.

A few notes:
- Use a controller.
- I found the difficulty just right, but I can see it being far too tough for those inexperienced with platformers and Metroidvania games.
- I don't know anything about the Strider series, but the story/characters/dialog were pretty awful. Buy this game for the gameplay.
- It doesn't hold your hand with tutorials/tips. Be prepared to be a little confused (in a good way).

author: {'steamid': '76561197970398622', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 348, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 348, 'last_played': 1406859419}
review:
What I liked most about this game was the focus on old school game fundamentals. The game takes the formula from the old Strider games and only expands the map size a bit. There’s hardly any dialogue or cutscenes at all. It’s no-nonsense ninja sidescroller action. I can’t remember the last time I played something that felt this stripped down and focused. Even the logos when you start the game go past faster than other games. This is the game for everyone who’s ever complained about modern game trends, and that they “just want to play the game”. It does this without wallowing in nostalgia. This isn’t a retro sidescroller, this is better than them.

I had a good feeling about Strider after I saw a clip of it, but even so I was pleasantly surprised by how good it is. It does basic things right, such as putting the coolest stuff at the end, and the second coolest stuff right before that, and so on. The controls are as responsive as the Itagaki Ninja Gaiden games, and details like the sound design augment how good it feels just to move around and do things. I only have minor quibbles with it like how mouths don’t animate in cutscenes, and that you can’t skip some of them when you retry bosses. On the whole it’s one of the best sidescrollers I’ve ever played. Sections of the game had me thinking of Turrican 2, which is always a good thing. I loved it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051322981', 'num_games_owned': 3807, 'num_reviews': 130, 'playtime_forever': 500, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 500, 'last_played': 1406787949}
review:
2014-07-31 爆机以后追加一下评论：
首先，游戏后期还是有一些需要动动脑子的地方，一味蛮打还是不行的（虽说总体还是简单的）。
武器的选择比较罗嗦，不过简单难度可以无视，反正跳过去绕开就好了
4种主要武器还是有用，最开始的剑的反弹子弹到后来的燃烧、冰冻、远程回旋都是很有用的，飞镖的存在感太低了，威力不行出手慢，就是稍微远一点，发挥余地不大。特殊攻击中的凤凰啊、豹子啊用得上的地方也很少，聊胜于无罢了。
游戏后期依然有很多向前作致敬的地方，甚至连最终BOSS战的第一形态也是，太怀念了。
总体来说，游戏不错，值这个票价。就是爆机以后无法选择继续探索这点太遭了。
===============================
我从小就非常喜欢的一款游戏 ，所以有新作立刻就购入了。看到有人说没有打击感，其实这个系列为了表现剑光犀利就是这么个设定，其实打击感不差啊，砍在重型机械和盾牌上反馈是很地道的CAPCOM手感 ，普通小兵一刀切自然就那样了。系列是以流畅华丽的动作穿越各种地带和华丽的演出为主题，所以本作依然继承了传统，这点无庸置疑。游戏从以前单纯的忍者ACT变成了类似FC版初代（和街机版不同是个ARPG）的类似《月下夜想曲》的风格了，需要通过关卡的推进学到各种能力，然后用新的能力可以探索新的区域这个主题。但是 略微不足的是，游戏的场景相对历代来说是变化最小的，基本就是在硬邦邦的钢铁都市进行穿梭，感觉太冰凉了。初代的场景变化很大，其实很棒，这个算一个退步。

游戏从一开始就不停的向前作致敬：刚开始的飞翼突袭、巨大机械蛇、飞行赏金猎人、引力球等等等等，让怀旧的玩家异常满足。另外手感非常棒，后期技能齐全后，如果你是高手，你可以展现出非常华丽、高效率的攻击，会十分赏心悦目。当然，普通玩家只要能打过《洛克人X》任何一作相信都会毫无问题的爆机。目前来看难度远远低于墨西哥面具英雄，那游戏太变态了，恐怕路上的一个小谜题需要的操作手法就比这游戏中最难的都要难。

总之，很久以来都没有什么正统的此类忍者形ACT了，强烈推荐喜欢本作或者传统FC版《忍者龙剑传》的玩家入手，很值的哦！

author: {'steamid': '76561198041738178', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 686, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 686, 'last_played': 1406296162}
review: STRIDER™ / ストライダー飛竜® - это вполне удачный ремейк оригинальной одноименной игры 1989 года от разработчиков-самураев из всемирно известной корпорации CAPCOM. С обновленной графикой, современными эффектами и улучшенной боевой системой этот проект не потерял шарма и духа старых консольных игр. И что самое главное, игра по-прежнему довольно сложная: некоторые боссы, коих здесь наберется с десяток, неслабо могут расшатать нервную систему неподготовленного игрока. Этому, кстати, способствует не только сложность, но и корявое управление на PC – особенно в уровнях, где отсутствует гравитация. А уровни в игре очень красивые: взять хотя бы заснеженный город Kazakh-city с кремлевскими мотивами в архитектуре и русскоязычными вывесками, которые, на удивление, не изобилуют тоннами грамматических ошибок. Главный герой-ниндзя Strider Hiryu тоже сделан безукоризненно. Стильный и узнаваемый персонаж. По версии ряда журналов один из самых узнаваемых персонажей, вышедших из CAPCOM. Поэтому, если ты, анон, уже устал от современных, обыденных игр, то этот экшен-платформер поможет хорошо провести несколько вечеров за исследованием запутанных уровней, яркими боями с мобами и динамичными, сложными битвами с боссами. Эта игра – один из немногочисленных примером удачных возвращений старых консольных хитов. Рекомендую!

author: {'steamid': '76561198118681355', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 558, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 514, 'last_played': 1406143654}
review:
A while back there was a Death Battle episode on Youtube featuring Ryu Hayabusa from Ninja Gaiden vs Strider Hiryu from Strider. Being a fan of Ninja Gaiden and having never really played a Strider game, I was surprised (spoiler) when Strider won. "HERESY!" I screamed as I flipped my table. "How could this be?". Then I played this game. "...oh".

I wish I could end the review there but unfortunately the game isn't perfect. Throughout your playthrough, you may find floating items which appearantly unlock alternate costumes. (1) I have no idea where to equip them and I've looked in every menu option I could find. (2) There is a point of no return just before the end boss so if you continue, beat the game and save, the game doesn't allow you to replay stages to get items you missed. And (3) There is no NG+ (New Game Plus). 

So not only can I not find the costumes I unlocked (It's not in the "Extras" menu), but I appearantly can't use them in a NG+ mode (which is the point of unlocked costumes in the first place) and I can't revisit the game I just spent hours beating to get the ones I missed...

Dispite this rather stupid design decision, the game is great. Highly recommended.

Edit: Found it. During gameplay go to the map screen then hit left or right bumper buttons on your controller (not sure about keyboards). Still can't equip them in a new game though so you can only use them as youfind them. Then they reset if you beat the game and save... wow.  -_-

author: {'steamid': '76561198063587281', 'num_games_owned': 515, 'num_reviews': 225, 'playtime_forever': 563, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 563, 'last_played': 1406074752}
review:
All sons of old Gods...DIE!!

The return / reboot of Strider!

This reboot borrows heavily from both the NES and Arcade versions of the game, fusing all the great aspects of both but also changing the layout of the entire game drastically for a brand new experience. Grandmaster Meio is the main villain so no worries for arcade purists. This is a true reboot and does not segway in to Strider 2 on the PSX or have any connection to any other Strider games previously released. The lore has been changed from Strider Hien's backstory to prove this.

The soundtrack is pretty decent, the newer songs aren't so great, they're more like ambient noises, however the old school remixed tracks are amazingly well done. The remixed tunes span across nearly every re-imaging of the game from the coin-op version, the turbo CD, NES and even a track from Strider 2. ;)

The gameplay is fast and frantic and once all of your abilities are unlocked you feel as if you can handle any situation and truly feel like an A-Class Strider. It can become a bit cumbersome while climbing around on ceilings but wall climbing is pretty solid. 

Boss battles are fairly frequent and require some heavy memorization and skill if you plan to make it through on the Hard setting. Plenty of stuff to do and numerous reasons to re-play the game, speed running, 100% completion and of course becoming an A-Class Strider by conquering hard mode. 

Definitely worth the price for any Strider fan, new or old.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043784900', 'num_games_owned': 1443, 'num_reviews': 254, 'playtime_forever': 757, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 757, 'last_played': 1456728334}
review:
If someone told me five years ago the developers of Silent Hill: Homecoming and of various movie licensed games from G.I. Joe: Rise of Cobra to Battleship: The First Person Shooter would make not only the new Killer Instinct but also a reimagining of Strider, then I would have assumed we were talking about some forgotten twin sharing the same Double Helix. Credit should also be given to Capcom’s Osaka Studio who provided oversight during the creation of Strider’s surprising return.

This is one of those rare instances where a development studio burdened with making licensed products for so long is given the opportunity to create something more original, and whether it was mainly due to the direction of the project heads or the pent-up creativity after so much shlock, the result is an adequately designed Metroidvania of the classic NES/arcade cyber-ninja that unlike its contemporaries makes the player feel powerful from the start rather than making the player feel inept.

[h1]Taking Strides Forward By Staying the Course[/h1]

Out of all the Capcom franchises in its backlog of history, Strider is probably the least interesting in terms of its gameplay as well as overall design. Originally on arcade machines, the game was a side-scroller that while enjoyable for its aesthetics, for its simplified yet refined combat, and for its difficulty curve to mask its purpose to eat your quarters, the game itself is archaic to modern standards. Even the console or various computer ports deviated from the original by making a generic side-scroller with some light adventure mechanics by finding clues to progress the story. Aside from a manga made to flesh out the lore of Strider, the IP remained dead until 2013.

So how does DH’s take on Strider deviate or even return-to-form at all? Other than the aesthetics and brand name, there is nothing in common with the previous games. Strider (2014) has taken the barebone design of the original and made a simplified Metroidvania game with eight-directional controls that will remind one of the quality from the Castlevania trilogy to Castlevania 4 given a 2.5D style as well as an inspired Metal Gear Rising: Revengance health system. The added controls as well as visual polish creates such a satisfying result to play that there is almost a sense of liberation in terms of how you control the character flawlessly around enemies and master the destruction you can create like the cyber-assassin Hiryu was always meant to be.

While it does stay true to the ideas of Metroidvanias, Strider (2014) mainly sticks to the basics of progression with secrets to discover to improve your character in somewhat open-ended linear maps with multiple weapon to unlock new paths or means of countering enemies. There are no sequence-breaking routes or anything distinct about Strider in terms of its combat or its platforming mechanics. The only notable thing about its gameplay is a feeling of improvement, something inherent in the genre, that begins at a high point of fluid mobility and high combat prowess that only makes the character feel more powerful the farther the game continues to add more to Hiryu’s arsenal.

All of these aspects do not make the game bad nor does its lacking originality undermine it as many modern Metroidvanias like Guacamelee rely on its combat mechanics; they may stay true to its non-linear exploration like Axiom Verge; they utilize the spectacle of Metroidvanias to make a game as enjoyable for newcomers as well as die-hards looking for a new itch like Ori & the Blind Forest. Strider (2014) is content to stay the course by revamping the original design while managing to keep the same cathartic entertainment of the originals from their simplicity. 

[h1]One Stride Forward, Two Steps Back[/h1]

Having praised the game as it is, there are some oversights that are warranted from the limitations of its design by creating a Metroidvania devoid of any real depth. As previously mentioned, the lack of sequence-breaking undermines players’ ability to explore these maps for alternative paths, which helps establish a more non-linear experience through either exploits and tests of player skill. This is something that establishes the real hallmark of the genre, and one that is often ignored by modern developers for better or worse. Strider (2014) doesn’t even attempt to allow players to pass up any ability, relying on self-imposed challenges not to use abilities that will make fights easier towards the end. However, the far more egregious issue with the game is the lack of depth to incentivize more replayability with the game beyond the difficulty settings. 

Perhaps the one idea the game teases the player with the prospect but never seizes the opportunity to add more to the experience is having multiple Striders, which establishes many fallen Striders with their own backstories that only reward you with color palette swaps. Similar to how Shovel Knight offers the Plague Knight and Specter Knight modes for longevity, these multiple striders could have reworked the existing level design as well as offer new ways to play the game. While it’s never completely fair for arm-chair critics to think of ways to make a game better outside its development process, the lack of any DLC to capitalize on this idea is a shame when developers from Ori & the Blind Forest made a new version to improve its non-linear design post-launch. Had the developers chosen to implement these types of modes instead of the color schemes, the game would have more longevity behind its name as well as more opportunities for creative approaches to the level-design and combat mechanics. 

[h1]Here-You, Sure-It-Can Stride-Her![/h1]

Strider (2014), as a standalone title, is a classic throwback for a new age with as much ambition for its future as well as its appeal of its legacy for such a lesser known IP. You simply cannot go wrong with this game as it’s a diamond in the rough with as much polish behind it for the modern age. 

It’s somewhat ironic that Capcom would please fans for an IP with so few titles like DuckTales: Remastered and this game for Strider’s 25th anniversary while still leaving Mega Man fans blue-balled for so long until they finally created the MM Legacy Collections as well as ruining Bionic Commando—I will never forget that series. However, games like Strider (2014) makes me hopeful for the future of Capcom as they continue to create games that harken back to the originals such as the case with Resident Evil 7, even though their ambitions for success to redeem their franchises’ names will not always be as profitable as they hoped.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025843884', 'num_games_owned': 859, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 334, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 334, 'last_played': 1404666539}
review:
This is how you do reboots. 

Strider Hiryu returns, along with his arsenal of animal friends (now plasma entities as opposed to robots) and his trusty sword. 
Everything from previous Strider games can be found here, though this game feels alot more fleshed out in comparison to the arcade titles.  

Hiryu's moveset's been given an upgrade, with some of his Marvel vs Capcom moves making an appearance. His heavy launcher from UMVC3 is here, for instance.  Enemies can be juggled, certain projectiles can be parried and alot of the "outside the box" stuff from modern action games are also implemented. I really appreciated being able to pull off some combos utilizing the launcher attack and the directional light attacks in the air. Along with special moves such as a ground slam ability you obtain, there's some depth to the combat system. 

Strider's an assassin, he's not a tank. As the player, you'll be dodging attacks and avoiding bullets as opposed to blocking them. Hiryu's really mobile, so it's no problem. The lack of a block button might be off putting to those more comfortable with modern games, but I really liked figuring out patterns and dodging gunfire.

Boss battles are frequent and all of them feel satisfying to defeat. 

The only real issue I found with this game is that the PC port does not seem to be optimized pretty well. I have a decent machine and was experiencing some slow down in certain areas, and constant screen tearing. Especailly during cinematics. 


I would definitely give this a shot if you are a fan of Strider's previous games or just action platformers in general. It's a fantastic reboot, which often times feels like that'd be an oxymoron, but it works very well in Strider's case.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048498273', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 1093, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 970, 'last_played': 1405837800}
review:
Wow. 

GRIN's Bionic Commando Rearmed is probably my favorite action game of all time, striking the perfect balance of classic 8-bit old school design and modern gameplay conventions into a blended whole that surpasses all prior (and sadly, subsequent) versions of the franchise. Amazingly, Double Helix's recent version of Strider does the exact same thing for the Cyber-Ninja that seemingly had a larger following in the fighting game scene than in his own titles.

Now, Strider's not BCR exactly. Some choices seem a smidge ill-fitting at first. Like the Metroidvania "single grand level" concept seems odd when you have such a mobile character who traditionally has gone through disparate locales in his games like a horny teenager goes through tissues, but they pack it with so many devious traps to flip around and baddies to chop up in such a large set of locations you'll never notice once you get going. Besides, it allows for a "just right" amount of item collection and several super-hidden spots concealing bonus costumes and concept art to give players their OCD collector fix. 

In general, that's probably the best descriptor of the game design as a whole: just right. And it leads a constant cavalcade of classic Capcom chaos! So much so that there's little to actually say about most of the moment ot moment gameplay that wouldn't just spoil the experience if you're interested after seeing the trailers. Like the Matrix, you really can't be told how awesome it is to be Strider Hiryu, you have to experience it for yourself. 

I for one, highly recommend plunking down the simoleans to give Strider a go. You'll be slicing and dicing through hordes of Russian Cyber-men within seconds, and flipping and ninja-vanishing around deadly traps while reflecting bullets into robots and summoning your holo-panther buddy to tear new holes into old foes for the next 4-9 hours depending on your difficulty and how much you want to collect.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021885430', 'num_games_owned': 915, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 932, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 932, 'last_played': 1405713852}
review:
So I just beat the game.  The best way I can explain my experience is Shadow Complex meets Ninja Gaiden.  The controls are insanely tight.   The sword swings as fast as you can press the attack button.... no waiting on animations. The graphics are vibrant and clean, with lots of pretty flashes of colors that would make any toddler drool in amazement.   The game makes you genuinely feel like you are far more skilled than you really are, mostly because you can move through most of the game without stopping.  Strider is extremely overpowered, but never to the point of feeling invincible.  

I loved this game for the most part, though I have to admit that I was disappointed with the lack of weapon choice or any sort of rpg elements.  I understand that they weren't aiming for that, so I don't really hold it against it.   While it's not my favorite metroidvania, it definetly satiates my craving for a new SotN or Super Metroid.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998159333', 'num_games_owned': 1346, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 577, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 501, 'last_played': 1405719739}
review:
Strider is a steal at $15. I got maybe 8 hours out of it playing on the normal difficulty and had a blast the whole time. For the most part, it does a great job of making you feel like a total badass ninja relentlessly slicing through foe after foe. The platforming is pretty easy as long as you're not going for a 100% completion; once you try to go for everything, you'll have to do some sections where you must freeze enemies in order to make stepping stones. Even then controlling HIryu is a breeze. The running and jumping make for some of the most entertaining movement controls I've seen since Castlevania: Symphony of the Night, and it smartly alternates between blistering action and platforming in gracious tandem. 

Strider Hiryu's latest game is a load of fun while being a great homage to the original. After a while, when you have a full range of abilities and powerups, it's easy to feel overpowered as you mow down the opposition. It's a fun Metroidvania that I wouldn't mind playing again.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995280010', 'num_games_owned': 433, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 688, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 203, 'last_played': 1427140098}
review:
The original Strider was released way back in the 80s, and supposedly it was very popular. And then, aside from a shitty knockoff and a single mediocre sequel in 2000, everyone forgot about it. Until Hiryu, the protagonist, was included in UMvC3. Riding on the resurgence of popularity, this game (2014 Strider) is released. Disclaimer: I have never played any previous Strider games, but this one is very fun. The combat is not very complex but it is enjoyable all the same. It definitely feels satisfying to cut through the hordes of enemies you come across, and the ability to control your slash direction gives you options to engage them. 2014 Strider is a BEAUTIFUL game, and the colors and flashiness add to the exciting experience. Many of the animations are homages to the original game. The exploration is also well done. Due to the fact that Hiryu can climb on 99% of the surfaces in the game, secrets can often be found in unexpected places. The levels are built, however, so that searching for said secrets never feels too tedious. Similar to games like Metroid, the entire game takes place in a single world  and so backtracking is essential to unlock everything. 

Overall 9/10, even though I've never played the original it's very obvious the developer is fond of the metroidvania games of the 80s and this reboot is very well executed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034934143', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 457, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 457, 'last_played': 1404975715}
review:
Honestly, this was a better effort than I was expecting.  The manic pace, rapid fire slashing and cartwheeling acrobatics are all intact from the arcade original.  References to that game abound, and I couldn't help but smile to see a nod to the strange NES  version many of us without access to a Genesis endured.  Boss fights are plentiful and well-designed, relying on classic pattern memorization skills to get through.

That being said, Strider has a few issues.  Instead of a linear action game, we're instead greeted by a lite Metroidvania affair.  This is fine, but unfortunately many of the "rooms" are massive and sparesely populated with enemies, making it extremely easy to blast through them with little effort from the player.  The music is also weirdly subdued and sounds as though composer Michael Mollo was trying to remix the original soundtrack in a similar way to Simon Viklund's work on Bionic Commando Rearmed.  What little I could hear of it under the chaos of battle failed to evoke a similar response; a real shame considering the original game's strange and bombastic score.

A solid effort from Double Helix.  I wish Hiryu would pop in more often.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069884248', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 246, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 246, 'last_played': 1404627118}
review:
Strider is an excellent side scrolling revamp/remake of a classic NES title from the late 1980s. You are a futuristic ninja battling against evildoers in a dystopian society.

This game is very comparable to other modern side-scrollers including the brilliant Mark of the Ninja and 360 Arcade exclusive, Shadow Complex. However, unlike Mark of the Ninja, the ninja in Strider does not rely on stealth. He relies on speed and using various abilities gained throughout the game.

Boasting excellent graphics and sound, Strider is a very smart and very fun game that I've been enjoying since I started playing. Like games of yore, Strider takes boss battles seriously and you will find a challenge early on in the game when you come across a boss. You must use strategy and learning their rhythm to defeat them. A few of the earliest bosses are relatively easy button bashers, but you will soon run into others that will give you fits.

This is a very strong effort and backed by Capcom, I hope to see more of these classic titles remade modern. I highly suggest a controller to enjoy this game to its fullest potential.

If I had any criticism of it, it would be that I wish the controls were a little tighter when evasion is important. However, that could be more down to my lack of precision than the game itself. 

If you enjoy side-scrolling action games that remind you of the great games of yesterday or even if you're too young to remember and just enjoy an action challenge, Strider could be your ticket to fun. I'm 3 hours in and only 10% complete, so I'm hopeful that there's plenty more hours to come in this very fun game.

review: First of all just hats off to Double Helix for doing right by Strider. A lot of fond memories of the Genesis/MegaDrive Strider. This ticks all, well, most, of those boxes. It's Strider. Looks, sounds and feels like Strider. You can get pretty much anywhere you'd want to get on the map. Here it really stands apart from the original. The map is no slouch. It's vast and chock full of alcoves and off the beaten path areas. The backgrounds can become somewhat same-y. It's THAT place. You know, the grey, futuristic city-dystopia with vaguely (not so vague) eastern motifs, hosted by a crew of saturday morning cartoon badguys who are all pretty cool looking, from the colour-coded grunts to the hulking bi-ped tanks, and who all blow up real good. Might have liked some more organic levels and enemy elements, and the main Strider Hiryu upgrades were too spread out, but I had a ton of fun with this. Highly recommended. 4 out of 5 grindcore muppets.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025231252', 'num_games_owned': 296, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1353, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1347, 'last_played': 1666047044}
review:
[b]A great rebirth of a classic character[/b]

Strider 2014 still holds up really well in 2019 and is one of my favorite Metroidvania styled games, regardless of some of the shortcomings of being a budget title. Strider 2014 has some of the best controls of any side scroller I've ever played, with Hiryu's movements being very precise and helping keep the game at a reasonable pace. The world is very industrial and gritty, but fits the tone of the story well and keeps itself interesting with the jawdropping background pieces. The game has so many collectibles that you'll be spending a bit of time finding them, really encouraging exploration and some light platforming in certain parts. Strider also has tons of power ups and abilities to find, making Hiryu stronger and even more fun to control, especially when you receive the catapult and double jump upgrades. Nothing feels delayed and Hiryu's attacks are swift and never get tiring killing the various opponents. Bosses and Enemies are reasonably challenging and the puzzles you do encounter are entertaining and fun to solve. 

The downsides seem to be more towards the presentation. From far away, the graphics and style are really gorgeous and the models look reasonably well done...until the camera zooms in and we get a look of how underwhelming the models actually look. A lot of the character models have expressionless faces and seem very low poly. Hiryu is rightfully the best looking model in the game. The music is also unfortunately very forgettable, at least in my case. The only song I remember clearly is the challenge completion song. I do feel like some enemies are a little too annoying to fight such as the gun turrets who could cause you to constantly be knocked down. Finally, the story is almost non existent and the cutscenes are pretty uneventful. A lot of the story is found in story intel that is spread out through the entire world. 

Conclusion, while in some places it's budget game does start to show, the gameplay is without a doubt the best part of this game. The world has a lot to explore and the challenge is really fair. When you don't zoom in on the models, the game is absolutely a treat to look at and very atmospheric. 

For anyone looking for an excellent Metroidvania game with high speed combat and fluid controls, this won't disappoint.  It is one of the best western outsourced Capcom titles and it is a shame that Double Helix was sold to Amazon not long after, would have been really nice to see this game get a larger budget sequel. 

Highly recommended, give it a shot!

author: {'steamid': '76561198038639818', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1915, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1595, 'last_played': 1574233855}
review:
I have great things to say about the new Strider; although I've not played the older games, this Strider is an excellent game in its own right and I have nothing but adoration for it.

The game throws you straight into the fray right away; you'll be able to dive right into the fast-paced slicing-and-dicing as soon as you start up the game. Did I mention that the controls are ridiculously smooth? Although Strider is not a particularly difficult game, combat is rewarding and satisfying.

The game is visually stunning, especially for a game as cheap as this. I found myself often just staring at the cityscape background, just soaking in the details. However, it can be a little jarring watching NPC's talk, however; their mouths don't exactly move...

The soundtrack is great and fun to listen to while you slash robots and other minions to pieces. The voice acting can be a little cheesy, however; one particular character's voice--Professor Schlange--will make you want to dig your eardrums out. 

Regardless, I'm merely nitpicking. Overall, Strider is a ridiculously fun game for its price, and doubly worth the investment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035368463', 'num_games_owned': 2139, 'num_reviews': 266, 'playtime_forever': 436, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 156, 'last_played': 1417865704}
review:
I never had the chance to play any of the original versions of Strider, but I got quite intrigued after watching some videos about them on YouTube and the remake delivers some really outstanding 2.5d platforming action complete with lovably cheesy voice acting.
You play as Strider Hiryu who has to infiltrate the Russian-inspired city of Kazakh City with the sole goal of killing the evil Grandmaster Meio who rules over the whole world with an iron fist.
If you've played the older games, then you will be able to get used to the controls in no time as you will be pulling off backflips, slides and whatnot that will completely decimate all the cybernetic and robotic foes that are foolish enough to stand in your way.
Another cool thing is that Hiryu swings his tonfa blade as quickly as you press the attack button, there's absolutely no delay whatsoever and this can prove extremely useful against tougher foes.
However, not all of Hiryu's abilties are unlocked at the start and many areas will be locked until you find the necessary item that is required to progress further in the game, you will be doing some backtracking too incase you want to find all the hidden bonus items that either unlock new costumes, concept art, profiles on enemies and much more.
If you love old school platformers and action games, then you simply must give this game a try, especially if you loved the Ducktales Remastered game.

review:

Some people can't even launch/play the damn thing
I died at the Ouroboros boss fight, respawned, and was invisible with the camera fixed in position

I haven't even played it for two hours yet, but this is fucking bad. But Issues aside the game IS alright. It's definitely fixed the issue in Strider 2 whereby Strider was a god damn wrecking machine and enemies never put up a resistance. Not even boses. It's kept the speed of Strider 2 whilst making combat actually...you know, combat. Not ''Strider runs through everyone slashing like a wildman and they all die''. 

They've changed the level formula, though. Rather than a straight up 2D hack and slash, you explore a larger map (think Metroid). While I would've prefered what they did in Strider 2, this isn't bad at all and they pull it off effectively. It's honestly not a bad game, but jesus fuck is the port bad. This is one of the few cases whereby I'l advise you not to give money to the developer. At least, not for the PC version. Get it on consoles instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989952883', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 309, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 309, 'last_played': 1400775276}
review:
Five hours in: in a nutshell 
•	The good, it’s really fun to play for a few min to an hour or so. The story is fine, jump puzzles and enemy swarms get interesting.
•	Expected some great Strider 8bit music, nope, it’s awful. Personal preference, open music and play some Anamanaguchi or Rymdreglage. Anything is better than the OST.
•	Could not play on a 60 hz 720 TV without blackout patches, needed to play it on a monitor & it looks great. Wanted to sit on the couch with a gamepad but the desk and pad are fine.
•	The voice acting is attempted but nothing spectacular.
•	There are dialogue popups that make tracking enemies, projectiles and landing spots tough at times.
•	If you’re a completionist, the replayability  is very high, lots of unlocks artwork, side challenges and so on. I’m just over 5 hours in and at the 30% mark so there is a solid amount of game for the $, just don’t pay full price and don’t bother with the OST.
